> On Sat, 30 Nov 2002, Keith Nasman wrote:
>> I know I've been bit more than once in not having my /home/keith
>> directory world readable and executable.
>
> Technically, your home dir doesn't need to be world readable, just
> executable so the web server can reach the public_html dir.  No one
> needs to be able to list the contents of your home dir.  The public_html
> dir does need to be readable and executable to whatever user the
> webserver runs as, however (or just make it world-readable).
> ~M
>

True. Thanks for the clarification, Matt.

Keith

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sun Dec  1 08:58:33 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sun, 1 Dec 2002 08:58:33 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] OpenOffice will not load
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0211302110270.21396-100000@main.cyber-office.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212010840440.5202-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Sat, 30 Nov 2002, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> I've been out of town a few days but I wanted to let you know also have
> started having problems with OOo starting on my system.  (I haven't made
> it to the OOo lists yet.)  At first I thought I'd upgraded something that
> may have broken something that OOo relied on but after some research I
> found there was no correlation between the two.

Rod, et al.:

  On the OO mail list I learned that others have had this experience, too. I
suspect the cause is related to the developers slavish devotion to making it
as Microsoft-like as possible. Ergo, no longer loading probably emulates
some Microsoft "feature" (such as having them shut down your software
remotely). All my opinion, of course.
 
> >   But, when I get it figured out I'll post the solution here.
> 
> Appreciated!

  I fixed it. Let me explain my initial situation, then the fix.

  Copies of the OO tarballs were downloaded to /usr1/open-office/. When I
installed the application, it created the complete directory tree
OpenOffice.org-1.0.1/ under this directory. But, because I had specified
--prefix=/usr/local/, there was a duplicate tree there, too. I don't think
it was supposed to work that way, but there we are.

  The command string attacted to an xfce panel icon used to launch OO was
/usr/local/bin/soffice. This worked fine for just shy of thee months; from
the RH 7.3 upgrade on September 5th (and following couple of weeks) until
last Monday or Tuesday, right after I sent a proposal to a client. Whew!
Then, like Congress, the application decided to go home for the rest of the
year.

  So, I took my few template files and copied them to ~/oo-backup. Using the
verable and reliable 'locate' command, I found every instance of soffice and
removed them. Both directory trees were cut for sale as Christmas trees
using 'rm -rf'. Then I downloaded a new copy of the tarball as I hadn't kept
the old one around.

  This time I more closely read the linux install instructions on the Web
site, and I followed the recommendation to do the installation in /tmp. I
still used the --prefix=/usr/local, and let 'er fly. Then I did the
workstation installation and removed the entire /tmp/OpenOffice.org-1.0.1/
source tree. The final change I made may or may not have been significant.
The Web site's instructions for those of us not using Gnome as our GUI front
end is to invoke OO as '~/OpenOffice.org-1.0.1/soffice'. I _had_ been
invoking it as '/usr/local/OpenOffice.org-1.0.1/programs/soffice'.

  Now it loads once again. When I diff the two soffice files, nothing shows
up. Why there are two copies, and why the developers recommend one over the
other I've no idea.

  Unfortunately, I was not able to produce invoices yesterday because my
restored template files are still not visible to Writer. I'm working on this
today; have to, so I will get them working again.

HTH,

Rich

From eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us  Sun Dec  1 10:23:24 2002
From: eharrison at mail.mesd.k12.or.us (Eric Harrison)
Date: Sun, 1 Dec 2002 10:23:24 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] APT-RPM
In-Reply-To: <1038751559.13156.24.camel@Balrog.jimwebb.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212011001490.17833-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>

On 1 Dec 2002, Jim Webb wrote:

>Eric,
>
>Do you only use up2date when RH notifies you that there is an errata,
>bug fix, or security fix?  I believe that is the only time that it is of
>value to utilize up2date.  Am I correct in this assumption?
>
>I've noticed that up2date addresses dependency issues well.

I primarily use up2date for errata, but it is also useful for installing
new packages & fixing dependancies.

If I wanted to install zsh, for example, I could run "up2date -i zsh" and
it would install the zsh package plus any missing dependancies.

If I tried to install a third-party rpm and it complained about a missing
dependancy, let's say it wants liblwres.so.1, I could use up2date to 
resolve the dependancy: "up2date --solvedeps liblwres.so.1"

Also note that up2date is just one part of the Red Hat Network. RHN lets
you push updates to multiple servers, document your configurations/changes,
and other such "enterprise-friendly" activities. This is very useful if you
have a big farm of servers to manage.

-Eric

It is certainly NOT meaningless.  I also have just the base packages +
updates in my sources.list also.  The Debian distribution is just larger
than the Red Hat distro.  There are a lot more software packages to
choose from, particularly in the area of development libraries and
programming languages.  Yes, many are things that "nobody will ever
need", though of the packages in that category, many are interesting
programs to read the sources to.

What is the source of those RPM packages?  Are they guaranteed to be
valid packages in any way?  How thourough is the testing of them?  How
well validated are the people who create an maintain them?  What ensures
that they do not contain trojan horses or that they install files in
correct locations?

Hmmm...  Ok, I do have a few non-official URI's in my sources.list. 
They are for the XFree86 test packages, from the Debian X maintainer's
unofficial test site, the Blackdown Java packages, the Openoffice.org
packages, and the LTSP ones.





From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sun Dec  1 14:31:57 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 01 Dec 2002 14:31:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] APT-RPM
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211302350290.5868-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0211302350290.5868-100000@k12linux.mesd.k12.or.us>
Message-ID: <1038781916.7796.20.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Sat, 2002-11-30 at 23:55, Eric Harrison wrote:
> You're trying to use packages from Rawhide? In that case you're on your
> own, no automated tool is going to help there. Rawhide constantly changes
> and offers ZERO assurances that the packages and/or package dependancies
> will actually work.

That is the nature of the "unstable" archive.  Everything is explicitly
allowed to be in flux wrt inter package dependancies, library versions,
and etc.  This is where everything gets worked out, evolved forward, and
made ready before it is frozen and stabalized for release.

The released archive ought to be very stable, with everything working
together correctly.  An upgrade from one stable release to the next
should proceed almost totally automaticly.  Almost.  There will probably
always be situations where that upgrade just CANNOT be done totally
automaticly, with no human intervention.

On Sunday 01 December 2002 17:45, Jim Webb wrote:
> I have noticed some strange characters on my man pages that make it
> difficult to read the lettering for the arguments.  What is causing this
> and how can it be fixed?
>

Assuming you're still rassling RH8, this is a Unicode bug in the KDE man page 
viewer. The default character set for RH8 is Unicode, UTF-8. The catch is not 
all apps are Unicode-aware yet. Either use yelp, or Konqueror- man:foo.

See the Release Notes on disc 1 for lots of useful information, they are also 
on redhat.com. This may help too: 
http://www.linuxplanet.com/linuxplanet/reviews/4530/2/

From mmartin at amath.washington.edu  Mon Dec  2 05:00:30 2002
From: mmartin at amath.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Mon, 2 Dec 2002 07:00:30 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] How is env initilized?
In-Reply-To: <1038425865.4997.157.camel@dereklinux>
References: <1038425865.4997.157.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <200212020700.31186.mmartin@amath.washington.edu>

Here are two path-related tips that might be related to your task.  First, if 
you are performing your backup from cron, it is a good idea to use a script 
which explicitly sets the path since cron does not read the user's 
environment.  Second, it is a good idea to only store relative paths in your 
tar archive.  That way you can restore to a temporary location without wiping 
out the system that is already there.  This gives you the option of restoring 
individual files rather than the entire content of the backup.

If you're interested in more information on my second tip and general 
information on using tar for backups, see the Chapter 12 of the Systems 
Adminstrator's Guide from the Linux Documentation Project at

http://www.tldp.org/LDP/sag/index.html

and, more specifically, Section 12.4

http://www.tldp.org/LDP/sag/x2540.html

Enjoy,

Mark

On Mon, 2 Dec 2002, Robert Kopp wrote:

> When I type $PATH at the command prompt, I'm not quite satisfied with what
> I see. If I want it different (and the changes permanent), where do I make
> the changes? I use Caldera OpenLinux 3.1, though this is probably not a
> distribution-specific issue.

Tim,

  What's not to like?

  The PATH variable is defined in ~/.bash_profile (or ~/.profile if you use
csh). When you want to add specific directories to your path variable, you
can always do so by appending; e.g., PATH=$PATH:HOME/bin:/some/place/else.

  The bash man page has details and so does the ORA nutshell book on the
bash shell.

Rich

#include <stdio.h>
#include <gsl/gsl_sf_bessel.h>

int main (void)

{
	double x = 5.0;
	double y = gsl_sf_besselJ0(x);
	printf("J0(%g) = %.18e\n", x, y);
	return 0;
}

The compiler complains that this "bessel" function is

undefined function. The function is in

/usr/local/include should be in the path, which it is
not. I used the suggested remedy to add this to the
path, but the problem persists. Could it actually be

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Mon Dec  2 11:18:35 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Mon, 2 Dec 2002 11:18:35 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Path statement
In-Reply-To: <20021202191136.7116.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>

On Mon, 2 Dec 2002, Robert Kopp wrote:

> This method of adding to the PATH works, but since it didn't solve the
> problem, I'll start from the beginning, hoping that someone can solve it.
> Just the other day, I installed (?) the GNU Scientific Library, C
> subroutines for a wide variety of scientific applications. Sure enough,
> the header files were installed where they should be. So then I copied and
> pasted the "Hello World" driver program into a text editor, to try it out:

  This is a different problem, Tim.

  Add the path where your scientific libraries are placed to
/etc/ld.so.conf. Then, as root, run /sbin/ldconfig. That rebuilds the
internal library data base. T'ain't a $PATH problem.

HTH,

Rich

Robert> the "Hello World" driver program into a text editor, to try it
Robert> out:

Robert> #include <stdio.h> #include <gsl/gsl_sf_bessel.h>

Robert> int main (void)

Robert> { double x = 5.0; double y = gsl_sf_besselJ0(x);
Robert> printf("J0(%g) = %.18e\n", x, y); return 0; }

Robert> The compiler complains that this "bessel" function is not
Robert> defined--that is, that there is a call to an undefined
Robert> function. The function is in /usr/local/include/gsl, so it
Robert> seems that /usr/local/include should be in the path, which it
Robert> is not. [...]

What you are looking for is the include path, not $PATH.  You can
compile your program above by adding a -I/usr/local/include to your
gcc command line.  Makefiles sometimes use special environment
variables to refer to these extra include directories.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Mon Dec  2 11:42:15 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon, 2 Dec 2002 11:42:15 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Path statement
In-Reply-To: <20021202191136.7116.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021202191136.7116.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200212021142.15526.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I wasn't sure you had problems compiling the test code or not when you 
said the compiler complained about something not being defined...For 
include files and the C compiler, use the -I argument that tells the 
compiler what directories to look in for finding header files. If you 
have multiple directories you can specify the -I argument multiple 
times on the command line. For telling the linker what directories to 
locate libraries in you use the -L argument

e.g.

gcc -I/usr/local/include -c world.c

Assuming you have a library named libgsl in /usr/local/lib you can link 
to it using the following command.

gcc -L/usr/local/lib -lgsl -o world world.o

Tony

P.S. I don't use GSL and so I don't know if my naming conventions are 
correct for linking the code or not but you get the general idea.

From mmartin at amath.washington.edu  Mon Dec  2 11:48:58 2002
From: mmartin at amath.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Mon, 2 Dec 2002 13:48:58 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Mailman and Postfix
In-Reply-To: <20021202200001.GB6736@dalsemi.com>
References: <20021202200001.GB6736@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <200212021348.58939.mmartin@amath.washington.edu>

I believe that this is a postfix problem.  I believe that you need to create 
an appropriate entry in the sender_canonical file, run the command "postmap 
sender_canonical" to create the corresponding aliases database, and then load 
the changes using the command "postfix reload".  I could be wrong about the 
specific file you need to edit since it has been awhile since I read through 
the postfix docs.  So look for sender_canonical in the postfix documentation 
to see if what I've said makes sense.

Good luck,

Mark

From shahms at shahms.com  Mon Dec  2 12:23:01 2002
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: 02 Dec 2002 12:23:01 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mailman and Postfix
In-Reply-To: <20021202200001.GB6736@dalsemi.com>
References: <20021202200001.GB6736@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <1038860581.10368.39.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

If you want all mail from your host to come from "lists" then you can
edit the /etc/postfix/main.cf file where it says "myorigin = " to look
like:

myorigin = lists.$mydomain
and it should work

--Shahms

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Dec  2 13:12:49 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 02 Dec 2002 13:12:49 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mailman and Exim 3 (Re: Mailman and Postfix)
In-Reply-To: <20021202200001.GB6736@dalsemi.com>
References: <20021202200001.GB6736@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <1038863569.18492.46.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Mon, 2002-12-02 at 12:00, Colin Kuskie wrote:
> The server I work on has a main name, "rock", and it's aliased to "www",
> "ftp" and last week we just added "lists" to the bunch so that we can
> run mailman.
> 
> The install went great, but when it sends out email, it comes from
> "rock" instead of "lists".  I don't know how to tell if this is
> a mailman or a postfix problem (or something else).  Does anyone
> have suggestions on:
> 
> 1) How to figure out which program is causing the problem
> 2) Maybe seen something like this and know how to fix it?

The PLUG list server's canonical name is "drizzle.pdxlinux.org".  It has
several other names, including "mail", "lists", "www", and "cvs".  The
mailer is Exim 3 (we have experimental Exim 4 packages now!), and the
mailing list manager is Mailman.

The matching exim 3 manual is at:

 http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/exim/manual.html/spec.html

... and I think that you will find that it's easy to find things in, so
you can compare what I describe here to the similar settings for
Postfix.  If anyone would like a copy of the Exim 3 configuration from
drizzle, just ask me in private email.

Exim is configured to accept mail for any of those host names -- that
is, "local_domains" is set to a list of hosts.  "qualify_domain" is set
to "drizzle.pdxlinux.org".  That is the domain that is added to all
unqualified addresses (you'll find it easily in the FM).  This is what
to change, in Exim, for all email that does not already have a "From"
with a FQDN in it, to make it say whatever you like.  (Hmmm... perhaps
on drizzle, "qualify_domain" ought to be "mail.pdxlinux.org".  Maybe
I'll change it.)

There are no header rewrite rules except for a "headers_rewrite" in the
"lists_transport" transport I have configured.  Those look like this:

  headers_rewrite = plug at pdxlinux.org plug at lists.pdxlinux.org

This is for the transition from the old address to the new one, adding
the "lists" host part to facilitate future growth or reorganization of
the pdxlinux.org domain.  (This is considered best practice.) 
Presently, drizzle will accept mail for pdxlinux.org, since there is an
MX for it, pointing to the A record for mail.pdxlinux.org, presently the
same IP as the A record for drizzle.pdxlinux.org, which is what
"hostname" reports, if you log in.)

The Mailman lists are all configured to use "lists.pdxlinux.org" as
their base domain name.  That is where all the mail coming from the
lists appears to originate from.  Thus, this setting is in Mailman, and
not in Exim.  I believe that you will most likely find the same to be
true for Mailman + Postfix.

Once again, anyone wishing a login account on drizzle, so you can
explore, email me your ssh 2 id_dsa.pub, user name, full name, and
daytime telephone number.  You may view any file on the machine that has
read permissions set.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Dec  2 13:28:28 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 02 Dec 2002 13:28:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Debian -dev packages (Re: Path statement)
In-Reply-To: <20021202191136.7116.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021202191136.7116.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1038864508.18500.60.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Mon, 2002-12-02 at 11:11, Robert Kopp wrote:
> Sure enough, the header files were
> installed where they should be. [...]

Well, sort of.  If it was me, I'd install a pre built "libgsl-dev"
package from Debian:

karlheg at bittersweet:~
% apt-cache search gsl
gsl-bin - The GNU Scientific Library (GSL) -- binary package
gsl-ref-html - The GNU Scientific Library (GSL) Reference Manual in html
gsl-ref-psdoc - The GNU Scientific Library (GSL) Reference Manual
libgsl0 - The GNU Scientific Library (GSL) -- library package
libgsl0-dev - The GNU Scientific Library (GSL) -- development package
karlheg at bittersweet:~
% su -
root at bittersweet:~
# apt-get install libgsl0-dev gsl-ref-html

... and save the trouble of maintaining a current version, etc.  It
would be installed and ready to use in less than five minutes.  This
puts the headers in "/usr/include/gsl/", findable via the standard -I
path with #include <gsl/*.h>, and puts the .so libraries in /usr/lib,
which is on the standard -L path.  You still need, of course, the
"-lgsl" on your link command line.

By the way, that documentation is installed on www.pdxlinux.org, in:

 http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/gsl-ref-html/gsl-ref_toc.html

(I've installed just about every -doc package available in the Debian
distribution!  Try the /doc/ URL once.)

If you needed to look at the source code to libgsl0 itself, you could
just type:

% apt-get source libgsl0

... and there it would be, ready for edits or rebuilding with custom
options.  (Just edit debian/rules ...)

would also eat up a huge amount of disk space for the database.

Swish++ can perform incremental updates.  It indexes PDF and PS files by using 
a "filter" specified in the config file. The filter is nothing more than a 
program used to handle that file and convert the contents to text. I think I 
am using pdftotext for PDF. It can handle gzip as well.  Looking at my setup, 
I think you could probably filter just about any extension.

From tisson.k.mathew at intel.com  Mon Dec  2 15:08:46 2002
From: tisson.k.mathew at intel.com (Mathew, Tisson K)
Date: Mon, 2 Dec 2002 15:08:46 -0800 
Subject: [PLUG] chunk_free consolidate forward clarification ( was RE: malloc and
 threads)
Message-ID: <288F9BF66CD9D5118DF400508B68C4460701D8C0@orsmsx113.jf.intel.com>

Looks like there is a bug in the chunk_free code in glibc 2.2.2 at
line:3131.When consolidating forward,I think the code is consolidating an
in-use block by looking at the
next+nextsz block's in_use_bit.

If the blocks are in the order [IN-USE] [IN-USE] [FREE]. If I'm freeing the
first IN-USE block ,consolidate forward is consolidating the second [IN-USE]
block by looking at

the [FREE] block's in-use bit.

Does anyone know if this bug is already reported and fixed? 

Here is the code from glibc:2.2.2 , malloc.c

===============================================
if (!(hd & PREV_INUSE))                    /* consolidate backward */
  {
    prevsz = p->prev_size;
    p = chunk_at_offset(p, -(long)prevsz);
    sz += prevsz;

    if (p->fd == last_remainder(ar_ptr))     /* keep as last_remainder */
      islr = 1;
    else
      unlink(p, bck, fwd);
  }

  if (!(inuse_bit_at_offset(next, nextsz)))   /* consolidate forward */
  {
    sz += nextsz;

    if (!islr && next->fd == last_remainder(ar_ptr))
                                              /* re-insert last_remainder */
    {
      islr = 1;
      link_last_remainder(ar_ptr, p);
    }
    else
      unlink(next, bck, fwd);

    next = chunk_at_offset(p, sz);
  }
  else
    set_head(next, nextsz);                  /* clear inuse bit */
============================================================================

Thanks
_tisson

Well, there are bugs in the ARM locking code.  I recommend interested
parties look at the conversation between myself and Richard Earnshaw
about this on the gcc-patches list, on Oct. 4th-7th:
  Subject: Atomic operations on the ARM

I don't believe it will affect malloc's use of locks; in short
test-and-set works but exchange-and-add is not atomic.

I'm not sure if compare_and_swap works correctly or not.  A glance
suggests that it does not.

On Mon, 2002-12-02 at 14:37, Patrick Beart wrote:

> <facetious comment>

> wants to spend at least half of their waking hours converting their 
> entire computing experience to (exclusively) Linux, so that we can be 
> just as smug as you are.   ;-)
> ----------------
> </facetious comment>

Gee, it sure is nice to see people who have such a strong grasp of the
concepts and reasoning behind PGP in general.

GPG signatures... egotistical, silly, smug?

You put your name in each of your emails to the list.  How is that
really different?  Many people append a few more bytes to their posts to
*prove* they are who they say they are.  Is this small extra token
really so silly, smug, and egotisitical?

PGP/MIME is *the right way* to do PGP signatures, which are a good thing
in general.  If you insist on using a stupid mail program, why should it
hold the rest of us back?

> 	Seriously, though, I made my requests about this PRIVATE to 
> the individuals (offenders?) involved, and off-list. Sorry to hear 
> (read) that it didn't stay that way.

I don't like it when off-list things are taken on-list, either....

> 	In the spirit of all of us - with diverse OS's and experience 
> levels - getting along, you guys COULD easily just append a KEY file 
> to the E-mail, and not a full signature.
> 	I began using PGP in 1996, so I know that this can be done, 
> and accomplish your goal of ensuring that NO ONE mistakes your E-mail 
> messages as anything but authentic and coming from you.     :-/

You aparently have no understanding of PGP.  That is sad if you've
really been using it since 1996.

Simply appending a key to the email does *nothing* to prove you are who
you say you are.  A key is a static thing - it does not change depending
on what is in the email.  A signature, on the other hand, is created
with the private key and the message.  If you change one byte in the
email, the signature would change... and since only the private key can
generate the signature, somebody else cannot just willy-nilly change the
signature to match the edited message.  Hence, PGP signing verifies the
message you received was indeed written and signed by the person who
signed it....

I think maybe what your problem is with is actually PGP/MIME, not PGP
itself.  PGP/MIME is a way of signing emails or any other MIME
messages... it uses MIME and is the 'right way' to sign an entire email,
attachments and all.  Some stupid mail clients can't properly utilize
it, though... lookOut Express being one of them.  I know from
experience, though, that you can just view an attachment without
permanently saving it somewhere on your hard disk.

Plaintext PGP is harder to do, depending on the mail client.  The
developers of Evolution, for example, decided that PGP/MIME was the
*only way* to do it, so they do not recognize nor support plain PGP
singing.

Since PGP/MIME is the right way to do it, it would make more sense for
those clients that don't properly render it to fix themselves than for
those clients which only support it to start doing things the old
fasioned way.

To sum it up, Pat:  Get a clue.  PGP helps identify that you are who you
say you are, not show your smugness.  PGP/MIME is the right way to do
things, so it makes no sense for people to revert to doing things the
old way because a few folks with stupid mail cilents cannot easily view
the messages.

-- 
Rob                                |  If not safe,
Email and Jabber:                  |    one can never be free.
athlonrob at data dot 4t3 dot com  |




From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Mon Dec  2 15:42:41 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 02 Dec 2002 15:42:41 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: (forw) Re: Thanks for the PGP signature files
In-Reply-To: <p05100300ba118b3ad112@[192.168.3.1]>
References: <20021112120402.A15889@kippered.herring.org>
	<20021112202606.GI13278@wirex.net>
	<20021202125435.D32455@defiant.ncplus.net> 
	<p05100300ba118b3ad112@[192.168.3.1]>
Message-ID: <1038872561.762.191.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

Patrick,

I generaly stay out of such issues but if you would be so kind I would
like some clarification in this matter.

In your email you state:

    ``Guess that you "hard-core Linux" guys don't care about Eschelon
    too much. Can't claim that your E-mail messages didn't come from
    you, when they contain an authenticating PGP/GPG signature, can
    you?''

This seems to be an attack. What's not clear to me is exactly whom you
are attacking, ``hard-core Linux guys,'' or people who include their
PGP/GPG signature in their emails. Knowing that these encryption
techniques also exist (and are widely used as they are a standard) for
Windows and other platforms, I am having trouble equating the entire
Linux community with PGP/GPG users.

Would you please help me reconcile this?

Further, you make mention of Eschelon...

    ``Guess that you "hard-core Linux" guys don't care about Eschelon
    too much.''

I sense that there is some background information that I am not privy to
so I cannot comment on Eschelon itself other than to say that if they
are adhering to the same standards as the rest of us (including PGP/GPG)
then there should not be a problem. Otherwise the signature will appear
as text at the bottom of the message.

When you say, 

    ``Can't claim that your E-mail messages didn't come from you,[sic]
    when they contain...PGP/GPG signature,''
    
well, I guess that's pretty much the point. Signatures are the author's
honest assertion that the messages are authentic. Far from being
``egotistical,'' it is in my view an indication that the author clearly
takes responsibility for his communication and is a gaurantee to the
recipient that the message is genuine.

I personally am reassured when I see the PGP/GPG information at the
bottom of an email message, whether it is an attachement or not; even if
I do not take the time to authenticate against it I use the signature as
a contributing factor for determining the authenticity of the message. I
check all keys, however, for critical messages.

Of course this may be a moot argument as I am still unsure if you are
talking about ``text PGP'ers'' or the Linux community on the whole.

Finally you make the following argument:

    ``In the spirit of all of us - with diverse OS's and experience
    levels - getting along, you guys COULD easily just append a KEY file
    to the E-mail, and not a full signature.''

I agree with you that we should all work to make things as easy to as
wide an audience as possible...but not at the expense of security.
 
The fact that an individual can attach the signature as a file isn't the
point. The truth is that they're playing by the rules. If on the
delivery side you've chosen a system based on ``what's popular'' rather
than functionality and standards adherence, then it seems you've only
given yourself rope with regard to others who do adhere to the standard.

Besides, if your client were open source you will likely find a module
that enables PGP decryption. Short of that you could write your own,
have someone do it for you, or at the very least submit it as a feature
request. 




-Cooper

> Cooper:
> 	Certainly ... since you asked ...
> 
> 	I'm simply pointing out that "joe E-mail sender" can claim 
> that a particular message (which might be construed by the Escheleon 
> spy network as "subversive") was not sent by him, but was "spoofed" - 
> that is unless he goes to the trouble of "signing" it with PGP/GPG, 
> as some PLUG-ers seem so intent on doing.

That *IS* the point. If all valid communications from someone *ARE* signed, then a spoofed one, that is *NOT* signed can all the more easily be dismissed or otherwise discounted as invalid and not from the apparent author. 

You can't prove where a message actually came from, unless it's signed, and that private key has not been compromised. That's a point that many people just don't get. 

> 	Like many of you, I'd like to see ALL programs conform to the 
> relevant RFC's. However, unfortunately, many do not - Microsoft's 
> programs, in particular.

So, it's your assertion that because many mail programs are broken, everyone should cow to the broken programs and not use the abilities in their non-broken programs. 

That's sort of like arguing with the judge that everyone drives 75, so you shouldn't have been given a ticket for it. 

It's more a responsibility of the authors of the broken programs to fix them. They will only do this if enough of their customers demand it. For Qualcomm to say it's not possible is completely bogus. It may not be easy for them, and they may not have enough incentive to do so, yet, but it's far from impossible. The properly working programs prove that it can be done. 

I'm not even going to go into Microsoft, they're broken by default, and don't seem to care. 

> 	My position is that it's "egotistical" to assume that such 
> broken programs can be avoided by most computer users, and that those 
> people who insist that everyone use a RFC-compliant MUA aren't being 
> realistic, much less helpful. Moreover, I feel that it's 
> "egotistical" to believe that your particular E-mail is SO special, 
> that you (someone) has to make SURE that everyone knows that YOU sent 
> it.

It's also egotistical to complain to folks about non-standards compliant programs, because the standards compliant programs "break" them. It's not the standards compliant programs fault that what you choose to use is broken. 

> 	Those of us who use "popular" E-mail programs should NOT have 
> to delete/trash as many as a dozen "Untitled" or "Unknown" text files 
> every day - just because a very few people on this list think that 
> PGP/GPG is "cool" and somehow necessary to their computing 
> experience. The list does not support HTML E-mail postings, due to 
> that same reasoning.

Why do you bother to trash them? They aren't very big, and the effort to trash them probably outweighs the space they take up.

--------------------------------------------------------------

	It may be possible to correct the problem by adding

would expect that information to be provided by the router, and not be
something I put into /etc/hosts, unless the router's supposed to be in
there in some way.

My /etc/networking file reads:

NETWORKING=yes
HOSTNAME=avatar

My /etc/hosts file reads:

127.0.0.1	localhost.localdomain	localhost
192.168.0.254	nec	nec

box.)

My /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts/ifcfg-eth0 file reads:

DEVICE=eth0
BOOTPROTO=dhcp
ONBOOT=yes
DHCP_HOSTNAME=avatar
USERCTL=no
PEERDNS=no
TYPE=Ethernet

Typing the command, hostname returns dhcppc3.

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Mon Dec  2 17:19:29 2002
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Mon, 2 Dec 2002 17:19:29 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Changing computer name
In-Reply-To: <3DEC02F7.8E3139C1@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <20021203011929.48949.qmail@web10404.mail.yahoo.com>

Richard,

My /etc/sysconfig/network file is:

  NETWORKING=yes
  HOSTNAME=arthur

I didn't use a FQDN, but if you want, just make up one, like
dell.richard.com or whatever. It can be anything since it's on your
private LAN.

If your IP is set statically, you can add a line to your hosts file,
like:

  192.168.0.10   dell.richard.com   dell

I'm not sure if this is the correct way to do it, but that's how it is
on my four Linux boxes at home, and it works.

-Scott

On Mon, 2002-12-02 at 16:29, Patrick Beart wrote:

> 	This would be a fine and noble thing, if it weren't for the 
> fact that (as far as I can tell) ALL - or nearly all - of the major 
> MUA's are "broken" with respect to the RFC's that specify how a 
> program should handle PGP/GPG "signatures".
> 	The dashed line(s) that comes before and after such 
> signatures set off the "signature" file and are rendered as a 
> separate attachment when received by the Eudora, MS Outlook Express, 
> and (I believe) MS Outlook mail agents. That would seem to account

> program cannot be changed to "fix" this problem.
> 	Like many of you, I'd like to see ALL programs conform to the 
> relevant RFC's. However, unfortunately, many do not - Microsoft's 
> programs, in particular.

If you're going to argue against the use of something so vehemently, you
should have a 'ing clue what you're talking about.

The dashed lines are *not* the cause of the stupid MUA's showing an
attachment.  It has to do with PGP/MIME, a way of signing emails so the
entire message - including any possible attached files - is signed.

I would be very very disgusted in any MUA that interpreted dashed lines
like that as an attachment - that's more broken than most get (although
a similar trick can be used to fool OE into thinking a usenet post is
MIME-encoded).

> 	My position is that it's "egotistical" to assume that such 
> broken programs can be avoided by most computer users, and that those 
> people who insist that everyone use a RFC-compliant MUA aren't being 
> realistic, much less helpful. Moreover, I feel that it's 
> "egotistical" to believe that your particular E-mail is SO special, 
> that you (someone) has to make SURE that everyone knows that YOU sent 
> it.

The mail clients are broken - why are you using them?  Hell, AOL even
renders them properly.

"Because everybody else is doing it" just doesn't quite hold up.

And again, you misunderstand the reasons for PGP signing of emails.  I
also can see you aren't interested in the reasons... 

> -->	Perhaps - as I requested in my earlier post - some savant can 
> provide a (complete?) list of the E-mail programs that DO NOT 
> separate PGP/GPG "signatures" as attached text files? Naturally, such 
> a list should include programs available for non-Linux OS'es.

Well, I'll start the list - I know AOL is able to properly understand
PGP/MIME.  I think Netscape/Mozilla does as well, but I'm not sure.

Pine understands them, Mutt does, Evolution does, KMail does, Sylpheed
does... I haven't run in to a Linux client that didn't understand
PGP/MIME.

> >I personally am reassured when I see the PGP/GPG information at the
> >bottom of an email message, whether it is an attachement or not; even if
> >I do not take the time to authenticate against it I use the signature as
> >a contributing factor for determining the authenticity of the message. I
> >check all keys, however, for critical messages.
>
> 	If the message is THAT critical, then you and the sender 
> should encrypt the ENTIRE message, and use Public/Private key 
> combinations between you.

Again, more misunderstanding.  You clearly have no understanding of PGP.

Encrypting a message over a public mailing list is very rude.  If you
mearly want to be sure of the identity of the sender, not necessarily
keep the contents secure from prying eyes, encryption is overkill and
stupid.

Encryption and signing, while based on similar technology, have two very
different uses.  Signing verifies the integrity of the data and the
identity of the sender.  Encryption keeps all but those who are supposed
to have access the data away from it.


> 
> >Finally you make the following argument:
> >
> >     ``In the spirit of all of us - with diverse OS's and experience
> >     levels - getting along, you guys COULD easily just append a KEY file
> >     to the E-mail, and not a full signature.''
> ... snip...
> >
> >The fact that an individual can attach the signature as a file isn't the
> >point. The truth is that they're playing by the rules. If on the
> >delivery side you've chosen a system based on ``what's popular'' rather
> >than functionality and standards adherence, then it seems you've only
> >given yourself rope with regard to others who do adhere to the standard.

This whole 'attach the key to the email' thing is stupid - Patrick
*must* have mismatched terms, I hope.

And, PGP/MIME does just that - it attaches the signature to the email as
opposed to putting it inline.


> >Besides, if your client were open source you will likely find a module
> >that enables PGP decryption. Short of that you could write your own,
> >have someone do it for you, or at the very least submit it as a feature
> >request.

Gotta love closed-source software.  ;-)

> 	Not all of us  - "us" being defined as everyone on the PLUG 
> mailing list - can afford to be exclusively Linux. Many of the PLUG 
> members that I know, use "mixed" environments to do their work. IMO, 
> the PLUG list should be accommodating in this regard.

Are you required to use Outlook or Outlook Express for email?  If so,
whatever for?

If you're in a mixed environment, why don't you do your email in Linux,
where all the clients aren't broken?

Or, if you're stuck in Windoze and can't figure out a way to deal with
this (an added two clicks to view an email message)... perhaps AOL would
be more to your liking.  I can help you get that set up if you like...

> 	Those of us who use "popular" E-mail programs should NOT have 
> to delete/trash as many as a dozen "Untitled" or "Unknown" text files 
> every day - just because a very few people on this list think that 
> PGP/GPG is "cool" and somehow necessary to their computing 
> experience. The list does not support HTML E-mail postings, due to 
> that same reasoning.

*View* the attachment instead of downloading it.  That puts it in a temp
folder and opens it immediately.  No mess.  If you insist on using
braindead MUA's, at least use them as inteligently as possible.

Since this *is* a Linux users group - and nearly all Linux mail clients
aren't broken in this regard - banning PGP/MIME signatures would be a
very strange thing to do.  Those who insist on using stupid mail clients
can click those extra two clicks to view the attachment.

From rsteff at attbi.com  Mon Dec  2 18:28:53 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Mon, 02 Dec 2002 18:28:53 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Logging in to headless systems
Message-ID: <3DEC16E5.CB1DE369@attbi.com>

I've heard about headless systems and how they can be administered
remotely. What concept do I read up on to understand how to use one
linux system to login to another via ethernet? I know how to do it with
telnet, but I want to know what else is available for both text and
graphical sessions. I googled for "remote login" for linux, but didn't

From mmartin at amath.washington.edu  Mon Dec  2 18:14:55 2002
From: mmartin at amath.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Mon, 2 Dec 2002 20:14:55 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Logging in to headless systems
In-Reply-To: <3DEC16E5.CB1DE369@attbi.com>
References: <3DEC16E5.CB1DE369@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <200212022014.55897.mmartin@amath.washington.edu>

You can use openssh for both text and graphical remote logins.  In fact, I 
strongly discourage you from using telnet to connect to any system connected 
to the Internet and recommend ssh instead.  If you have a network that is not 
attached to the Internet, using telnet is okay but is still a bad habit.  By 
"graphical login", I'm assuming that you mean being able to run X 
applications remotely.

See http://www.openssh.org for details or, if you have a Linux box with 
openssh (or non-open ssh for that matter) installed nearby, type

man -k ssh

to see a list of relevant man pages, which can subsequently be viewed by 
typing

man command_name

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Mon Dec  2 18:49:07 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 02 Dec 2002 18:49:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Logging in to headless systems
In-Reply-To: <3DEC16E5.CB1DE369@attbi.com>
References: <3DEC16E5.CB1DE369@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1038883751.760.213.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

Dick,

You're looking for the secure shell, or ``SSH.'' Secure shell offers you
a way to log in securely using a key-based authentication system and
encrypted communications over the network.

In the practical sense, once it's set up, it's really easy to use and it
also automatically exports the display of an application you run from a
remote machine to the machine you are on.

See the following link for details:

http://www.linuxdocs.org/HOWTOs/MindTerm-SSH-HOWTO/


-Cooper

Works for me:

karlheg at bittersweet:~

bittersweet
karlheg at bittersweet:~

bittersweet

kernel.hostname = bittersweet
kernel.domainname = hegbloom.net
karlheg at bittersweet:~
% cat /etc/resolv.conf
domain intra.hegbloom.net
search intra.hegbloom.net hegbloom.net lts.hegbloom.net uml
nameserver 127.0.0.1

Robbert van Andel wrote:
> Okay, I spoke too soon.  I tried setting up my printer and came up with
> an error message when starting lpd.  The error I got was robbert
> Get_local_host: 'localhost' IP address not available.  I had to reset my
> hosts and network files back to localhost to get lpd to start properly. 
> Not sure why.  Any suggestions on how to work around this?




I've had good luck by adding an alias to /etc/hosts
like so,

127.0.0.1	rufus.localdomain	localhost	rufus

you don't want to do away with localhost

After this log out and stop X and do,
# service network restart



Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

> hosts and network files back to localhost to get lpd to start properly.

Does your /etc/hosts still have localhost in the 127.0.0.1 line?

AFAIK, you can (should?) list multiple names in a single line, i.e. you 
should list dell in addition to localhost, rather than replacing 
localhost.

  return 0;

>

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Mon Dec  2 23:42:46 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon, 2 Dec 2002 23:42:46 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Path statement
In-Reply-To: <20021203072918.13017.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021203072918.13017.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200212022342.46469.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I think you need to also add an "-lgslcblas" argument when you link 
things to create the executable to pickup the addtional library. 
Depending on the complexity of a given application you'll have 
numberous -L directives if you have a number of directories containing 
libraries in them. You will also have numberous -l<library-name> 
directives as well one for each library your using functions/methods 
from in your code.

Tony

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Tue Dec  3 01:14:35 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 03 Dec 2002 01:14:35 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] emacs tip - comment syntax and highlighting for text conffiles
Message-ID: <1038906875.18500.108.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Many conffiles use "#" as a comment character.  They are not written in
any normal programming language, and so there's not a built in font lock
mode or comment start expression defined for them...

At the end of any file, in emacs, you can place a "local variables"
section that sets up some buffer-local variables for that file.  This
feature is documented in the manual:

http://www.pdxlinux.org/cgi-bin/info2www?(xemacs21/xemacs)File+Variables

The similar is also true for GNU Emacs, of course, and I gather that
even Vim supports a similar feature.

There is a buffer local variable called "comment-start" that is used by
the "comment-region" function.  When it's set, you can highlight a
region, and use "M-x comment-region" to comment that section off.  "C-u
M-x comment-region" will uncomment it.

Another buffer local, font-lock-keywords, controls syntax highlighting. 
You can read it's extensive documentation by using "F1 v".

So here's what I do for conffiles that use # for comments that I also
want highlighted as comments, to make them more visually distinct:

# Local Variables:
# mode: text
# comment-start: "# "
# font-lock-keywords: (("#.*$" 0 font-lock-comment-face t))
# End:

I also like to put:

(define-key global-map [(control ?\;)] #'comment-region)

... in my startup file.  (~/.xemacs/init.el)  That binds C-; to the
comment-region.command.  The mnemonic is that ";" starts a comment in
Lisp, the native language of the emacsen.





From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Tue Dec  3 01:49:28 2002

Whoever wrote that misunderstands the purpose of LD_LIBRARY_PATH.  That
environment variable is used at runtime by the dynamic linker, not at
compile time.  You can find out about it in the "ld.so" man page.

 http://www.pdxlinux.org/cgi-bin/man2html?ld.so

Also see:

 http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/rutebook/html/node26.html

I had a Dell Inspiron of recent vintage at my last place of employment and 
mostly hated it.  It was chock full of bleeding-edge, windoze-specific 
hardware and wasn't very stable under either Linux or Win2k.  I was also 
involved in setting up several other such laptops within the company and 
there were several serious problems that we never resolved under Red Hat 7.x 
or Mandrake 7.x, 8.x, mostly related to X.  The situation is probably better 
now that XFree 86 4 has been around for awhile and I can't say anything 
specific about the model you're considering.  But I would personally be very 
hesitant before purchasing a new-ish Dell laptop for running Linux.

Just one man's opinion,

Mark

From mark at linuxhardware.net  Tue Dec  3 09:54:55 2002
From: mark at linuxhardware.net (Mark Griskey)
Date: Tue, 3 Dec 2002 09:54:55 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Swish++ is very good. (Re: Search engines, robots.txt)
In-Reply-To: <1038909139.18496.123.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
References: <20021202084327.19428.qmail@web9604.mail.yahoo.com> <1038868411.18492.75.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net> <1038909139.18496.123.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <200212030954.55534.mark@linuxhardware.net>

If you are compiling from source, you may need to lower the Word_Threshold 
value in config.h.  I have found that even on the most robust Linux machines, 
the default is too high, which according to the comments, was set for a Sparc 
machine running Solaris.  Also be sure to make sure the defined temp 
directory is adequate.  Actually, Swish++ won't compile until you define this 
variable. 

Also, you can play around with the parameters in config.h, it defines things 
such as what characters are letters, how many consecutive consonants a word 
may have, etc.  This is very useful if you need to tailor the search to fit 
your needs. ( We needed to be able to search for ISBN numbers. )

Mark

From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Tue Dec  3 10:02:30 2002

At my work, we have purchased many Dell laptops over the last few
years. Some have been very solid, but we've had a couple lemons. One
was a refurbished laptop, and we had the motherboard replaced FOUR
times for various reasons, in about a one year period. The last time
they replaced it, they ran some more tests, which showed the
motherboard to be fine, but the memory failed. They replaced that too,
and now it is finally a stable machine.

One other machine had a problem with the pointing stick causing the
mouse to drift. It was intermittant, and when it started drifting, it
would accelerate. Soon it was like a video game trying to click on
"Shut Down" or any other settings.

We have always purchased the expensive ($300) extended 3 year onsite
warranty for most of the business laptops, and we've had to take
advantage of the warranty on several of the machines. However, the
other 2/3 of the Dell laptops we've purchased have been great.

We have set up Linux on three or four of them, and haven't had any
major problems.

The Inspirons are designed more for the gamer or hacker or home user,
with less reliability but lots of bells and whistles. The Latitudes are
business machines, generally leaner but more stable and tested.

-Scott

From mmartin at amath.washington.edu  Tue Dec  3 10:04:12 2002
From: mmartin at amath.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Tue, 3 Dec 2002 12:04:12 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Path statement
In-Reply-To: <20021203072918.13017.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021203072918.13017.qmail@web9605.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200212031204.12175.mmartin@amath.washington.edu>

Here are the steps you need to follow.

1. Making Libraries Accessible to the Linker: As root, add /usr/local/lib to 
/etc/ld.so.conf and then execute the command "ldconfig".  I believe that 
someone already suggested this to you.  For more details about this step, 
read the ldconfig man page.

2. Compiling Object Files: When you compile the object files, make sure that 
your header files are accessible to the compiler by including -I arguments 
that specifiy where to find the header files.  Here is an example of 
compiling

gcc -c my_program.c -I/usr/local/include -I/usr/local/include/gsl 
-I/home/my_home_dir/my_other_include_directory

This will produce an object file called my_program.o.

3. Linking Object Files into an Executable File: In the linking phase, you 
need to make sure to tell the linker which libraries to use and, if 
necessary, where to find them.  The -l and -L flags specify the libraries and 
their possible locations, respectively.  Here is an example of a command to 
link the object files my_program.o, function1.o, function2.o into the 
executable file my_program

gcc -o my_program my_program.o function1.o function2.o -lm -lgsl -lgslblas 
-L/usr/local/lib/gsl-1.2 -L/home/my_home_dir/my_other_library_directory

The flags -lm, -lgsl, -lgslblas tell the linker to search the math, GSL, and 
GSL BLAS, libraries, respectively, for functions that are not found in the 
object files.  The specific libraries that you use for your task depend on 
which BLAS libraries you are using with GSL.

There are other compiler and linker flags that you might eventually find 
useful also.  See the gcc, ld, and ldconfig man pages for details.

It probably won't be fun but I strongly suggest carefully reading through the 
sections of the gcc man page that pertain to these flags as well as the 
ldconfig man page.  You should probably also consult a Linux/UNIX-specific 
book that describes how to use gcc because you seem to be missing the big 
picture.  For a good, quick overview, I suggest reading parts of the "Linux 
Programmer's Reference" published by Osborne or reading parts of "Beginning 
Linux Programming" published by WROX, just to take 2 somewhat arbitrary 
examples from my book shelves.

Mark

From danh at fork.com  Tue Dec  3 10:39:52 2002
From: danh at fork.com (Dan Haskell)
Date: Tue, 3 Dec 2002 10:39:52 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Linux on RS-6000
In-Reply-To: <1038426306.1261.45.camel@red>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0212031008530.26371-100000@cohiba.fork.com>

First off, I don't speak for my large blue employer.

On 27 Nov 2002, Randal T Pluimer, wrote:

> I think IBM has a port of Red Hat that runs on it.  Can't say exactly
> which one. Read an article somewhere with a list of ports to
> proprietary hardware. That was definately on there. I will see if I
> can dig it up again.

There are flavors of Linux that run on pSeries. I don't think IBM is
behind any of them. They have ported Linux to all of their platforms -
except pSeries. In lieu of supporting Linux on p they have tried to make
the native Unix (AIX) as Linux friendly as possible. However, in September
they announced a *plan* to offer it:

http://www.eweek.com/article2/0,3959,538818,00.asp

That said, Suse, Yellow Dog and Rock all offer Linux distributions that
run on RS6k hardware. I know *nothing* about Rock. I do know people who
have installed Suse and Yellow Dog. I don't think there is a port of
RedHat.

On 27 Nov 2002, Ed Sawicki wrote:

> On Wed, 2002-11-27 at 11:35, stuart mathews wrote:
> > What model is the RS/6000?
> 
> I'm trying to determine that now. I don't think it's a pSeries
> because it's an older machine but I really don't know. I'll
> post another message here with the specifics as soon as I know.

pSeries is just a marketing label. Last year all IBM RISC boxes were
magically transformed into pSeries boxes. In similar fashion all AS400s
became iSeries, all PCs became xSeries, and all 390s became zSeries. I'm
not sure it does you any good to know what model it is (unless it is a
really old one) - you just need a distribution built for PowerPC.

Hope that helps.

Dan

Messages such as the one quoted below have been very
helpful to me in using the GNU Scientific Library, as
you can see from what follows:  

[rtk at openlinux rtk]$ gcc gslfirst.o -o gslfirst
gslfirst.o: In function `main':
gslfirst.o(.text+0x1c): undefined reference to
`gsl_sf_bessel_J0'
[rtk at openlinux rtk]$ gcc -L/usr/local/lib -lgsl
-lgslcblas gslfirst.o -o gslfirst
[rtk at openlinux rtk]$ ./gslfirst
J0(5) = -1.775967713143382920e-01

This is a cumbersome way to do it, however, so I am
hoping that advice such as that contained in the
message below will allow me to avoid typing so much.
The provider of a different package advised users to
put the library search path into LD_LIBRARY_PATH in
.profile_bash, but I don't seem to have such a file at
all.

--- Mark Martin <mmartin at amath.washington.edu> wrote:
> Here are the steps you need to follow.
> 
> 1. Making Libraries Accessible to the Linker: As
> root, add /usr/local/lib to 
> /etc/ld.so.conf and then execute the command
> "ldconfig".  I believe that 
> someone already suggested this to you.  For more
> details about this step, 
> read the ldconfig man page.
>

---------- Forwarded message ----------

Hi all,

If you write long documents, use Linux, and need an outline processor, you 
might like the new VimOutliner 0.2.0. It uses VI keystrokes plus some 
enhanced commands to perform outliner functions such as indent, exdent, 
collapse, expand -- either by individual trees or outline wide. 

Because it's based on quick-editing Vim, VimOutliner is an incredibly 
productive outline processor.

If you used the old VimOutliner, you'll like this one much better. 
VimOutliner 0.2.0 has a vastly improved collapse/expand that truly hides all 
subservient headlines, without the irritating "shadow lines" of the previous 
version. Also, this version has color coded levels, a simple install script, 
and several other features.

Although it's not part of the VimOutliner 0.2.0 distribution, I've written a 
VimOutliner to LyX Book Class converter, and if anyone wants it I'll be glad 
to slap the GNU GPL on it and make it available on the VimOutliner website.

If you use Linux and need an outline processor, check out VimOutliner.

http://www.troubleshooters.com/projects/vimoutliner/

Thanks

Steve

I wasn't suggesting that you were running out of memory, but that maybe
you should rule out a bad memory stick, it is easy enough to test.

Randal gave me another idea; I have had to "killall java" (I have
blackdown java installed) several times, though it was related to
Mozilla, not Opera.  My machine would start to get sluggish, I would ps
-Al and see a LOT of java processes, one or two would be hogging the CPU
cycles.  "Killall java" and my machine is back to normal.

The next thing that you need to learn is how to create a makefile.  Then you 
won't have to retype the flags repeatedly.  At the very least, you could 
create a script to perform the compilation and linking.  I again suggest that 
you consult the references that I mentioned or some other similar text.  
There is also an excellent online manual for make at

http://www.gnu.org/manual/make/html_chapter/make_toc.html

The file is called .bash_profile not .profile_bash.  If a file is missing, you 
can always simply create it.  Of course, advice about bash is only relevant 
if bash is your shell.  If so, there is an excellent man page on bash.  You 
might want to read it too.

Mark

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Tue Dec  3 12:04:54 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Tue, 3 Dec 2002 12:04:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Path statement
In-Reply-To: <20021203192111.82589.qmail@web9607.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021203192111.82589.qmail@web9607.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <200212031204.54918.aschlemm@attbi.com>

For managing the compile and linking process so you don't have to type 
extremely complex commands yourself you should learn how to use "make". 
This is what large non-IDE based projects tend to use to manage the 
build process. 

You can write a script to do the basic steps for your and I've seen this 
done on projects by people that didn't want to make the effort have an  
an effective build process. That's not to say I haven't written my 
share of shell and/or Perl scripts that help in the build process but 
the scripts were invoked by "make" typically. 

I've come into some fairly large projects and the standard way they were 
building things up until my arrival entailed running a script which 
blew away all of the .o and .so files and then recompiled everything. 
It only took 30-60 minutes each time anyone wanted to compile the  
system depending on how may other people were recompiling everything 
concurrently. 

I spent my first week or so on the project creating Makefiles which 
depending on the number of files that changed the rebuild time would be 
a matter of 1 minute or less time if only a few files needed to be 
compiled and and new executables created. Certainly if some top-level 
.h file changed that all of the C/C++ files were using was changed 
required everything to be recompiled and so the build took quite a bit 
longer.

Learning how to use "make" and creating a working "Makefile" is not easy 
as it requires you to learn how to write your own makefiles which 
require you to specifying targets and prerequisites.

http://www.gnu.org/manual/make-3.79.1/make.html

Tony

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Tue Dec  3 12:09:11 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 03 Dec 2002 12:09:11 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Web Mail question : How to change the link to start
	OpenOffice instead of AbiWord
In-Reply-To: <5.1.1.6.0.20021203184216.02abecd8@pop.net-yan.com>
References: <5.1.1.6.0.20021203184216.02abecd8@pop.net-yan.com>
Message-ID: <1038946151.18500.136.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Tue, 2002-12-03 at 02:43, Stephen Liu wrote:
> While viewing web mails on a website such as lycos.com, yahoo.com, 
> hotmail.com, etc. clicking their attached documents will start 
> 'AbiWord'.  But unfortunately some documents created with MSOffice could 
> not be read exactly in AbiWord in its original form, particularly, a 
> table.  The document must be read in OpenOffice to maintain its original shape.
> 
> Kindly advise how to change the link to start OpenOffice instead of AbiWord

Either use the browser's helper applications configuration, the Gnome
control center file associations one, or fix it in /etc/mailcap or
~/.mailcap.

On a Debian GNU/Linux system, /etc/mailcap is managed by the
"mime-support" package, which provides "update-mime".  It has a man page
which describes it's use and tells something about the format of entries
in a mailcap file.

hwtools - Collection of tools for low-level hardware management

"memtest86" must be run instead of the OS.  It is booted either from a
floppy, or from the boot loader (Lilo or Grub).

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Tue Dec  3 12:45:47 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 03 Dec 2002 12:45:47 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Java plugin missing or moved, access via symlink? (Re: Opera-6.0.3
 crashing constantly)
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212030835550.25476-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212030835550.25476-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1038948347.18500.156.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Tue, 2002-12-03 at 08:39, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Has anyone seen this behavior before?

Yes, just yesterday, with Mozilla.  I had just upgraded Java from
j2re1.3 to j2re1.4, and the symlink in /usr/lib/mozilla/plugins that
leads to the actual plugin had not been updated to point to the new
location.  Since it had not changed, Mozilla still thought it had a Java
plugin, registered during previous runs.  Whenever I would click on a
link to a page with a silly java applet (see below) it would crash.

Apparently, Mozilla does not have very good exception handling in that
area.  I need to report this as a bug...  Both against Mozilla, and
against that j2re1.4 Debian package.  (It tries to run the
"update-alternatives", but that had no effect for some reason I could
not quickly deduce.)

The solution was to fix the symlink and restart Mozilla.  Accessing
"help | about plugins" told me that it now could "see" the version 1.4
java runtime plugin.  Access to a page with a silly java applet worked
again, with no crash.  Check your setup, by listing plugins, etc, and
looking around in the plugin directories, and see whether all is in
order.  Perhaps the crash you are experiencing has similar causes.

Silly java applets...  Why does http://www.portlandstatebookstore.com/
need a java applet for the menu on the left?  An HTML table and perhaps
a little javascript (ecmascript) would have sufficed quite nicely.  When
I click on that java applet, the entire page refreshes anyhow, so it's
not like it makes the interface any nicer.  It's not even a tree menu! 
(and a tree menu can be done without a Java applet anyhow.)

That's right!  I've got all my projects on *SCSI* disks, and use
Makefiles for nearly everything! ;-)

More seriously, I believe you can bypass the need for adding anything
to ld.so.conf or LD_LIBRARY_PATH by using an -rpath specification to
ld.  You can do this from a gcc command-line by using the -Wl,<foo>
option.  See docs for details.  I've never used this feature directly,
but I've seen reference to it scroll past on many a "make install" for
GNU and similar packages.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Tue Dec  3 13:22:20 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Tue, 3 Dec 2002 13:22:20 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Path statement
In-Reply-To: <86el8yj03z.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
References: <20021203192111.82589.qmail@web9607.mail.yahoo.com> <200212031204.54918.aschlemm@attbi.com> <86el8yj03z.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>
Message-ID: <200212031322.20318.aschlemm@attbi.com>

I've found the LD_LIBRARY_PATH variable useful in certain situations 
where the directory paths were slightly different between our 
development/test systems and the actual production servers. Being able 
to specify a LD_LIBRARY_PATH variable meant that our system would still 
run since all of the our required shared libraries could be found at 
runtime.

Tony

> Anthony> For managing the compile and linking process so you don't
> Anthony> have to type extremely complex commands yourself you should
> Anthony> learn how to use "make".  This is what large non-IDE based
> Anthony> projects tend to use to manage the build process.
>
> That's right!  I've got all my projects on *SCSI* disks, and use
> Makefiles for nearly everything! ;-)
>
> More seriously, I believe you can bypass the need for adding anything
> to ld.so.conf or LD_LIBRARY_PATH by using an -rpath specification to
> ld.  You can do this from a gcc command-line by using the -Wl,<foo>
> option.  See docs for details.  I've never used this feature
> directly, but I've seen reference to it scroll past on many a "make
> install" for GNU and similar packages.

-- 
Anthony Schlemmer
aschlemm at attbi.com




From mark at linuxhardware.net  Tue Dec  3 13:22:24 2002
From: mark at linuxhardware.net (Mark Griskey)
Date: Tue, 3 Dec 2002 13:22:24 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Swish++ is very good. (Re: Search engines, robots.txt)
In-Reply-To: <1038949552.18500.165.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
References: <20021202084327.19428.qmail@web9604.mail.yahoo.com> <200212030954.55534.mark@linuxhardware.net> <1038949552.18500.165.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <200212031322.24192.mark@linuxhardware.net>

On Tuesday 03 December 2002 01:05 pm, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> What exact change did you make to make it work for ISBN numbers, please,
> in case I want to index BibTeX files with ISBN numbers in the entries?

I changed the value of Word_Min_Vowels (The minimum number of vowels a word 
must have in order to be indexed) to 0.  I read somewhere the source code 
that any character that is not a vowel (defined as aeiouy) is considered a 
consonant.  Since our ISBN numbers are all numeric, with a few exceptions, I 
had to lower it to 0.  I also raised the Word_Max_Consec_Consonants (...this 
many consecutive consonants) to 10.  These changes were made to index 
bibliographic information for about 10,000 scientific titles that are often 
searched for using the ISBN, the title, or a committee member's name.  We 
have not encountered any adverse effects but changing the vowel/consonant 
values.  

> Do you know if the filters get run more than once, so that, for
> instance, a .ps.gz file gets first unzipped and then has pstotext run on
> it, or will I need a special filter set up for .ps.gz files?

I am not sure on this one, but would be curious to know if it does require a 
special filter.  

Mark



-- 
------------------------
Mark Griskey
www.linuxhardware.net

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Tue Dec  3 13:47:55 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 03 Dec 2002 13:47:55 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Emacsen (IDE) (Re: Path statement)
In-Reply-To: <200212031204.54918.aschlemm@attbi.com>
References: <20021203192111.82589.qmail@web9607.mail.yahoo.com>
	 <200212031204.54918.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1038952075.14896.20.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Remember the emacs tip of the day I posted last night re "local
variables"?  Well, another very useful buffer local variable is
`compile-command'.  Use it like this if you like, for simple one file C
programs:

// Local Variables:
// compile-command: "gcc-3.2 -o alloc_thread -O2 alloc_thread.c -l pthread"
// End:

What that does is give a default command for when you use "M-x compile".
That also can be used for non compiled stuff where you run a script or
something, though more often what you want then is
"after-save-commands.el", part of XEmacs.  (M-x customize-variable,
After-save-alist)

> I'm impressed that you ever had Mozilla work with Java.  Mine crashes
> every time I hit an applet.

I installed Mozilla 1.2 and the Blackdown j2re1.4 from Debian packages. 
Mozilla from unstable, and Blackdown Java from:

deb ftp://metalab.unc.edu/pub/linux/devel/lang/java/blackdown.org/debian unstable main non-free

I think that with a fresh install, the needed symlinks will be created
as advertised.  For some reason, it did not work right when I upgraded. 
I've reported the problem to the maintainer.

The symlink is:

karlheg at bittersweet:~
% ls -l /usr/lib/mozilla/plugins/java*
lrwxr-xr-x    1 root     root           35 Dec  2 20:17 /usr/lib/mozilla/plugins/javaplugin_oji.so -> /etc/alternatives/javaplugin_oji.so
karlheg at bittersweet:~
% ls -l /etc/alternatives/javaplugin_oji.so 
lrwxr-xr-x    1 root     root           59 Dec  3 13:31 /etc/alternatives/javaplugin_oji.so -> /usr/lib/j2se/1.4/jre/plugin/i386/mozilla/javaplugin_oji.so

If you are installing from RPM or non-package manager binaries, creating
the similar symlink should enable Java to function, I would guess.

On Sun, 2002-12-01 at 13:23, Eric Harrison wrote:
> On 1 Dec 2002, Jim Webb wrote:
> 
> >Eric,
> >
> >Do you only use up2date when RH notifies you that there is an errata,
> >bug fix, or security fix?  I believe that is the only time that it is of
> >value to utilize up2date.  Am I correct in this assumption?
> >
> >I've noticed that up2date addresses dependency issues well.
> 
> I primarily use up2date for errata, but it is also useful for installing
> new packages & fixing dependancies.
> 
> If I wanted to install zsh, for example, I could run "up2date -i zsh" and
> it would install the zsh package plus any missing dependancies.
> 
> If I tried to install a third-party rpm and it complained about a missing
> dependancy, let's say it wants liblwres.so.1, I could use up2date to 
> resolve the dependancy: "up2date --solvedeps liblwres.so.1"
> 
> Also note that up2date is just one part of the Red Hat Network. RHN lets
> you push updates to multiple servers, document your configurations/changes,
> and other such "enterprise-friendly" activities. This is very useful if you
> have a big farm of servers to manage.
> 
> -Eric

On Tue, 2002-12-03 at 13:43, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > > Do you know if the filters get run more than once, so that, for
> > > instance, a .ps.gz file gets first unzipped and then has pstotext run on
> > > it, or will I need a special filter set up for .ps.gz files?
> > 
> > I am not sure on this one, but would be curious to know if it does require a 
> > special filter. 
> 
> Ok, I'll try and remember to report the result back here.

It does.  As long as you have a filter set up for .gz, and another for
.ps, it will apply each of them in turn, then index the ps file.

News to me.  I didn't elect for the extended coverage when I bought my 
Satellite 1715xcds two years ago.  Last week a few of the keys stopped 
working so I checked the literature that came with the thing.  Since this 
was their bottom-of-the-line model, the factory warr was only 1 yr.  (Other 
models were 3 yr.)  I called tech support and played dumb, sure enough 1 yr. 
  They suggested I take it to a factory authorized yadda.

Traced the problem down to an intermittent connection in the keyboard cable. 
  Online prices were ~$80 so I decided to try and fix it.  After I came home 
with some mod wire, it must have decided I was serious and started working 
again.  Shrugged and put the screws back in.

Moral:  The extended warr would not really have been worth in in my case, 
but if the lcd fails that's another story.  The thing only cost $899 so an 
extra $200 for the extra coverage seemed excessive and I'm no road warrior 
and it has a pretty easy life.  If I were ever to lay out $2000 for a 
notebook, I would definately get the extra coverage, but it sounds like your 
deal is keeping the machine in the "disposable" range.

> On Sat, 30 Nov 2002, Roderick A. Anderson wrote:

> > it to the OOo lists yet.)  At first I thought I'd upgraded something that
> > may have broken something that OOo relied on but after some research I
> > found there was no correlation between the two.
>
> Rod, et al.:
>
>   On the OO mail list I learned that others have had this experience, too.
> I suspect the cause is related to the developers slavish devotion to making
> it as Microsoft-like as possible. Ergo, no longer loading probably emulates
> some Microsoft "feature" (such as having them shut down your software
> remotely). All my opinion, of course.
>
> > >   But, when I get it figured out I'll post the solution here.
> >
> > Appreciated!
>
>   I fixed it. Let me explain my initial situation, then the fix.
>
>   Copies of the OO tarballs were downloaded to /usr1/open-office/. When I
> installed the application, it created the complete directory tree
> OpenOffice.org-1.0.1/ under this directory. But, because I had specified
> --prefix=/usr/local/, there was a duplicate tree there, too. I don't think
> it was supposed to work that way, but there we are.
>
>   The command string attacted to an xfce panel icon used to launch OO was
> /usr/local/bin/soffice. This worked fine for just shy of thee months; from
> the RH 7.3 upgrade on September 5th (and following couple of weeks) until
> last Monday or Tuesday, right after I sent a proposal to a client. Whew!
> Then, like Congress, the application decided to go home for the rest of the
> year.
>
>   So, I took my few template files and copied them to ~/oo-backup. Using
> the verable and reliable 'locate' command, I found every instance of
> soffice and removed them. Both directory trees were cut for sale as
> Christmas trees using 'rm -rf'. Then I downloaded a new copy of the tarball
> as I hadn't kept the old one around.
>
>   This time I more closely read the linux install instructions on the Web
> site, and I followed the recommendation to do the installation in /tmp. I
> still used the --prefix=/usr/local, and let 'er fly. Then I did the
> workstation installation and removed the entire /tmp/OpenOffice.org-1.0.1/
> source tree. The final change I made may or may not have been significant.
> The Web site's instructions for those of us not using Gnome as our GUI
> front end is to invoke OO as '~/OpenOffice.org-1.0.1/soffice'. I _had_ been
> invoking it as '/usr/local/OpenOffice.org-1.0.1/programs/soffice'.
>
>   Now it loads once again. When I diff the two soffice files, nothing shows
> up. Why there are two copies, and why the developers recommend one over the
> other I've no idea.
>
>   Unfortunately, I was not able to produce invoices yesterday because my
> restored template files are still not visible to Writer. I'm working on
> this today; have to, so I will get them working again.
>
> HTH,

package owns that program, so you can install it.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Wed Dec  4 06:15:14 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Wed, 4 Dec 2002 06:15:14 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] permissions -- ugh
In-Reply-To: <20021204013117.F32455@defiant.ncplus.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212040610160.5779-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Wed, 4 Dec 2002, Bruce Kingsland wrote:

> permissions on /home/seti is 744, and is at least that on all the
> other files and directories below that. But I can't read a file that
> is not in the /home/seti dir. How come?

Bruce,

The /home/seti directory will need need to have the execute bit set 
for group and others, e.g.,

  chmod go+x /home/seti

The reason is that you need to be able to 'execute' the directory in 
order to read the files in it. The same thing will be true of 
subdirectories in the /home/seti tree.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

Or something to that effect. In short, the Klez worm found the list's email
addy in someone's address book or browser cache and masqueraded an email to
our friends in Redmond.

Sandy

From russj at dimstar.net  Wed Dec  4 09:44:53 2002

Subject: [PLUG] Connecting two networks.
Message-ID: <3DEE3F15.3080501@dimstar.net>

My son has a network in his house.

I have a network in my house.

Both are connected to the internet.

I'd like them to be able to talk to each other, like a VPN.

We both have Netgear routers (RT-311) between the DSL modems and the hub 
serving each network, so I can forward ports from the router to a 
computer inside the router.

Has anyone else done this, and what sort of experience did you have?

What package did you use?

Thanks in advance for any information.

From derek at infotects.com  Wed Dec  4 11:51:03 2002
From: derek at infotects.com (Derek Loree)
Date: 04 Dec 2002 11:51:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Unknown activity on DSL
In-Reply-To: <3DEE3F15.3080501@dimstar.net>
References: <3DEE3F15.3080501@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <1039031462.4993.256.camel@dereklinux>

Hi All,

This may be slightly off topic, but I need to be hit with the clue stick
(again).

At home, I have a Cisco 678 DSL "modem", with two "real" ip addresses,
one for a server and one for my firewall.  Recently I've noticed much
more activity than usual (both the WAN and LAN activity lights are
flashing several times a second, all of the time).  At first I just
thought that my son wasn't logging off of the on-line game he's been
playing, but this morning after he left for school I noticed that it was
still being active.  I checked, and he had logged off.  

So, I fire up etherreal to capture packets on the private side of my
firewall.  Nothing showed up besides the usual ARP and DHCP stuff. 
Well, that is odd, so I installed and fired up sniffit on the other side
of my firewall and the only thing it sees is the ssh connection that I
used to connect to the box.  I did create some traffic and saw it, so I
know that the sniffer is working.


My question is:  What could be causing this activity and is there a way
to confirm this?

I called my ISP, and they can offer no help, except to call the phone
company, saying something about an ATM heartbeat.  I think that a
heartbeat to the "modem" would not show up as LAN activity though and a
heartbeat of several each second is going overboard, even for Qwest. 
Anyway, I'd rather ask this fine list, I think I will get much better
answers.

TIA

Derek Loree




From octopus024 at yahoo.com  Wed Dec  4 12:24:14 2002
From: octopus024 at yahoo.com (Scott VanHoosen)
Date: Wed, 4 Dec 2002 12:24:14 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Connecting two networks.
In-Reply-To: <3DEE3F15.3080501@dimstar.net>
Message-ID: <20021204202414.79789.qmail@web10404.mail.yahoo.com>

Russ,

I'm not sure exactly what you mean by "talk to each other" but here's
what I do.

I have a Linux workstation at work, and several Linux workstations and
servers at home. My home network is behind a D-link router, which
forwards port 22 (ssh) to my home Linux workstation. That way, while at
work or at a friend's house, I can ssh into my home Linux workstation,
and from there ssh into all my other Linux boxes.

I can send or receive files remotely using scp as well.

I believe that you can mount NFS shares over the internet, though I
haven't tried it yet. I hope this helps.

-Scott
