I didn't understand this so I experimented a little

$ touch "1 2"

$ ls
1 2 

$ for i in `ls` ; do echo $i  ; done
1
2

Ok that didn't work as explained but

$ for i in * ; do echo $i  ; done
1 2

OK so * generates what is needed

$ for i in * ; do echo $i | sed 's/ /_/g'  ; done
1_2

so I think this works

$ for i in * ; do if [ "$i" != `echo $i | sed 's/ /_/g'` ] ; then mv "$i" `echo $i | sed 's/ /_/g'` ; fi ; done

$ ls 
1_2

why is this?

Thank you
Russell

On 25 Nov 2002 11:56:11 -0800, Karl M. Hegbloom said:


>  The problem is that when the shell globs, it won't get the file names
>  with spaces in them -- they'll be split on IFS, which contains a space!
>  
>  You have to walk the directory with Perl, or use an explicit list of
>  file names, either with spaces "\" escaped, or inside a perl script.

From rsteff at attbi.com  Wed Dec  4 16:55:11 2002
From: rsteff at attbi.com (Richard Steffens)
Date: Wed, 04 Dec 2002 16:55:11 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Red Hat 8.0 Performance Comparison
Message-ID: <3DEEA3EF.C5B94556@attbi.com>

I spoke too soon the other day when I thought that the new kernel I
compiled for my desktop machine combined with some additional memory
solved that machine's performance problem. Alas, it still feels too slow
to me.

I won't call this a benchmark, since that implies more accuracy in the
measurements than I tried to make, but here are the results of a simple
test I did with two machines, my laptop, and my desktop. The purpose of
this post is to see if anyone can point me towards the information I
need to learn how to improve the performance of the machines under Red
Hat 8.0, especially the desktop machine.

The test involved starting a terminal, starting Mozilla, and connecting
to http://jigzone.com. On right side of their home page, there are
several images which, when clicked, take you to a page with a java app
that turns that image into a jig saw puzzle. For the "benchmark" part of
the experiment, I typed "date" in the terminal, clicked on the 48 state
US map puzzle, waited for it to finish loading, and typed "date" on the
terminal again. Then I computed the difference in time between the
output of the two "date" commands.

I repeated the test on each machine running Windows 98SE and using the
time command in a DOS window. In each case, the installation of Win98 is
the one provided by the manufacturer of the machine. In the case of the
Red Hat installations, the one on the laptop is the default installation
from the Red Hat CD's, while the one on the desktop is the kernel I
compiled the other day specifying that I have an AMD K6-2 processor, and
leaving all the other options in their default condition.

The laptop is a Thinkpad 390X, with a 400 Mhz Celeron and 96 Mb of RAM.
The desktop is a special from Bi-Mart a couple of years ago called an
Avatar VBOX, and has a 550 Mhz K6-2 with 192 Mb of RAM. The numbers in
the table are the elapsed seconds between running the date, or time
commands.

		thinkpad	avatar
Red Hat 8.0	23		35

Win 98SE	13		11

I would expect the avatar, with the 550 Mhz K6-2, to run a little bit
faster than the thinkpad, with the 400 Mhz Celeron, and under Win 98SE
that is the case. I'm curious about why the results are 1) slower under
Red Hat 8.0, and 2) why the avatar is so much slower than the thinkpad
under Red Hat 8.0. Hopefully, I'll learn what options to tweak when I
next compile the kernel so I can get better performance out of the
avatar.

Any ideas?

-- 
Regards,

Dick Steffens
http://rsteff.home.attbi.com/



From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Wed Dec  4 17:07:19 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 04 Dec 2002 17:07:19 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Email on Linux vs MS
In-Reply-To: <3deea0a1.4506.0@pcez.com>
References: <3deea0a1.4506.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <1039050439.1417.17.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

Stuart,


Your instincts about using Linux as a mail server are correct. The
primary mailing application for Linux--Sendmail--has proven itself for
over 25 year in enterprise and academic use.

But you don't have to be a large business to run it. I use Sendmail for
as my personal email. Mail gets sent to a server in the garage running
on an AMD 450.

There are other excellent email servers available. Exim is is an
example.

I would like to just offer you two things overall. 

First, I built a Sendmail mail server for a company I used to work for.
I left the company before that server (also running FTP, File and Print
services) ever saw a minute of downtime.

Second, when you use Exchange server for your mail system you will run
into several issues. Chief among them is trying to gel Exchange 2000
Server's Active directory paradigm with older clients.

A company I know of with 1600 seats is learning this the hard way. It's
a mess. Believe me.

The primary argument against using Linux for your mail server is a
perceived lack of group collaboration tools. Look to Ximian's Connector
to solve this. Evanite Fiber did, and they've never looked back. 

So overall you can really heap on the reliability and reduce
infrastructure entanglements by using Linux.

Oh, and by the way, you can use a lot less machine to do the same work
primarily as the server does not need to run the GUI or unnecessary
background processes.

Look, Microsoft's done here. Email services are increasingly becoming a
commodity. I have solid information to the effect that large
organizations are making pointed migration plans to Linux. Put this
email in your ``predictions'' subfolder: your customer will look ``so
yesterday'' within five years if you go with MS. That's a promise.


Best,


Cooper

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Wed Dec  4 17:08:45 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Wed, 4 Dec 2002 17:08:45 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Email on Linux vs MS
In-Reply-To: <3deea0a1.4506.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212041651100.31188-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Wed, 4 Dec 2002, stuart mathews wrote:

> Sorry for this vague request.  I am looking for some direction.

Stuart,

  Go West young man.
 
> An associate of mine and I are trying to help someone identify the optimal path
> for creating a custom-built email system that will forward / route lots of emails.
>  She had assumed the solution would be deployed on Microsoft technology.  As
> a Linux newbie, my instinct is telling me the would be better served to deploy
> this solution on Linux, but I don't know enough about email systems or Linux.
> 
> Can someone give me some pointers on why Linux would be superior for this?

  You'll get a lot of answers that cover every possible aspect, and then
some. I'll try to focus on a few, key issues to get you thinking. Once you
have more specific questions you'll get more specific answers. It would also
help to understand the setting of the "custom-built email system that will
forward / route lots of emails". But, let me offer some thoughts.

  A linux based solution offers these broad advantages: choices (lots of
'em); no viruses; detailed control that's easy to understand, implement and
maintain; low cost (none); runs on all sorts of hardware; easy to keep
secure and upgrade; and works as you work.

  The linux mail system consists of several categories of components. I
assume that you're considering a business system (and not a spam factory!)
and you'll have your own domain name, static IP address and mail server. The
mail server (or Mail Transfer Agent, MTA) is the heart of the system. The
old workhorse is sendmail. Newer, more powerful and easier to use options
abound. I use postfix (as do many others), but there's exim, qmail, smail
and others. The MTA will screen messages it receives before passing them on.
It then sends the message on to the next stage. For outgoing mail that's the
recipient's MTA, for incoming mail it's the MDA.

  The Mail Delivery Agent (MDA) does the local routing (or forwarding, if
necessary) to the recipient's mail box. procmail is the most commonly used
MDA; I don't know that else is out there, but I'm sure there are
alternatives.

  Once the message is in a user's mailbox you'll find a plethora of Mail
User Agents (MUAs). In the Microsoft world there's Outlook/Outlook Express,
Eudora and (perhaps?) Netscrape or mozilla. In linux you have choices for
text-based MUAs (pine, elm, mutt) and graphic-based MUAs (sylpheed, mozilla,
Kmail, evolution, whatever Gnome provides, and many others). Each user can
pick the MUA of her/his choice and it doesn't matter to the system.

That's a start,

Rich

From alan at clueserver.org  Wed Dec  4 08:48:46 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (alan)
Date: Wed, 4 Dec 2002 08:48:46 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Email on Linux vs MS
In-Reply-To: <3deea0a1.4506.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212040842510.27290-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>

On Wed, 4 Dec 2002, stuart mathews wrote:

> Sorry for this vague request.  I am looking for some direction.
> 
> An associate of mine and I are trying to help someone identify the optimal path
> for creating a custom-built email system that will forward / route lots of emails.
>  She had assumed the solution would be deployed on Microsoft technology.  As
> a Linux newbie, my instinct is telling me the would be better served to deploy
> this solution on Linux, but I don't know enough about email systems or Linux.
> 
> 
> Can someone give me some pointers on why Linux would be superior for this?

Mail under Linux is stable. Mail on Microsoft is not.

I ran the perl5-porters list (over 2,000 subscribers) a couple of years 
back on Linux using a P75 with 80megs of memory.  The response time for 
the entire list was about 10 minutes for the average message.  (That is 
very fast for a mailing list that size.)

The *only* reason people run Exchange is if they need the calender 
functions or they like spending money for software that corrupts itself.

And remember, you cannot buy just one Exchange license.  You have to have 
another for the backup server.  When Exchange corrupts the user e-mail 
database (which happens about once a month or more), you cannot restore a 
single user at a time.  You have to restore to a seperate Exchange server 
and use voodoo-like import/export tricks to get the mail moved over.

Microsoft for mail is just BAD. Plain and simple.





From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Wed Dec  4 17:35:12 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 04 Dec 2002 17:35:12 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Red Hat 8.0 Performance Comparison
In-Reply-To: <3DEEA3EF.C5B94556@attbi.com>
References: <3DEEA3EF.C5B94556@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1039052112.1371.56.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

Dick,

Yeah. I have a couple: 

1.) There's a real-time kernel patch by Robert Love that I have found
improves foreground processes significantly. The new kernels have the
option for the patch built into the compiler options, labeled,
``Preemptible Kernel'' under the ``Processor Type and Features''
section.

2.) Make sure that you are using DMA access by default. This is also
compiled as an option in the kernel. With newer kernels, this option is
checked by default.

3.) Make sure support for your motherboard's IDE chipset is compiled in.
You can find a list of supported chipsets (select the one you need)
under the ``ATA/IDE/MFM/RLL support/IDE,ATA and ATAPI Block Devices''
section.

4.) See this great article from IBM for manipulating your PCI bus.
Basically, you allow each device full rights to the data bus for a
longer period before it has to relinquish control to another device. In
your case, pay special attention to your video card and Ethernet
controller settings:

http://www-106.ibm.com/developerworks/opensource/library/l-hw2.html?dwzone=opensource
  
5.) make sure your computer is using swap. Given your memory upgrade I
doubt this is the case but it never hurts to check.

6.) If your video card uses an Nvidia chipset then be sure to download
and install the kernel modules (drivers) for it and configure X11 to
take advantage of them. I can offer you an X11 configuration file that
will work with this hardware, just copy and run!


-Cooper

On Wed, 4 Dec 2002, Anthony Schlemmer wrote:

> When I first read about what sort of hoops an admin had to go through to 
> restore an Exchange server I was totally baffled as to why any 
> organization would invest money in such a system. Email has become a 
> fairly important business tool and I can't belive that any company 
> wouldn't want that system running on the most reliable platform 
> available i.e. Unix or Linux IMHO.

The reasons for this are that people who understand the problems and 
technologies are no longer the people who actually make the decisions.

A number of years ago, computers became "buzzword complient".  Managers 
could impress their friends by the size of their IT budgets. (Not that 
they knew how to use it...)  They were told by Microsoft sales people that 
in order to be "cool" they had to run Exchange for mail.  Because they 
wanted to be in the "in-crowd" and wanted to make their golfing buddies 
think that they were clued, they told their IT staff to use it or else.  
When told just how much their Microsoft habit was costing, they went into 
denial. They would just lash out at the IT department until they went away 
and/or gave up.

There is no good reason to run it, but so many upper management types have 
been conned into doing it it is hard to get them to change to something 
stable.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Thu Dec  5 03:11:42 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 05 Dec 2002 03:11:42 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Email on Linux vs MS
In-Reply-To: <3deea0a1.4506.0@pcez.com>
References: <3deea0a1.4506.0@pcez.com>
Message-ID: <1039086702.2248.69.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Wed, 2002-12-04 at 16:41, stuart mathews wrote:
> Sorry for this vague request.  I am looking for some direction.

They went that-a-way, pardner!

> An associate of mine and I are trying to help someone identify the optimal path
> for creating a custom-built email system that will forward / route lots of emails.
>  She had assumed the solution would be deployed on Microsoft technology.  As
> a Linux newbie, my instinct is telling me the would be better served to deploy
> this solution on Linux, but I don't know enough about email systems or Linux.
> 
> 
> Can someone give me some pointers on why Linux would be superior for this?

I cannot make a comparison between the Microsoft platform and Linux, or
between Linux and commercial Unix, since I have only experience with
Linux.  I do have some experience with both Sendmail and Exim 3 however.

Sendmail
========

Sendmail has a bad reputation amoung some, and a good one amoung
others.  Many people believe that it is difficult to configure.  On a
recent Debian GNU/Linux installation, Sendmail is a lot easier to use
than it is on the Red Hat setup I examined.  The reason for this is that
the Debian maintainer has put an aweful lot of work into making it easy
to use.  If you must use Sendmail for some reason, then Debian is the
platform of choice for it.  (But look into Exim!)

There is a pretty decent "sendmailconfig" script that asks some
questions and builds a starter "/etc/mail/sendmail.mc" for you, for
instance.  That happens automaticly when you install the package.  In
most cases, you don't need to do any more configuration at all.  Also,
there's a very good "/etc/mail/Makefile", and a "sendmail.conf" used by
the init.d scripts as well as some admin commands provided by the
package.  It allows you to configure multiple queue groups, and whether
to run Sendmail from inetd or as a daemon, and to run the queue from
cron or by the daemon.

If you never muck around with sendmail.cf (which is a major taboo since
that breaks upgrades) and only edit the sendmail.mc, trusted-users, etc.
files, you can just type "make" and it will rebuild the sendmail.cf and
all the lookup tables, then prompt you to restart the daemon.  To do
much customization, you will need to read the bat book.

Exim
====

Exim 3 (and Exim 4) is a lot easier to figure out.  The Sendmail book is
quite thick.  It's configuration language is turing complete...  You
could probably implement Sendmail Lisp in it.  The Exim book is much
lighter and less daunting.  There is also a great online documentation
for it that puts an index in a frame on the left and the text on the
right.  I think that Exim does everything you'll ever need and that
since it's a lot easier to figure out, you're better off with it.

It was fairly easy to get Spamassassin and Amavis + a virus scanner
working under Exim.  RTFM, and it's not hard to figure out.

Others
======

I never did figure out qmail, and it's licence is restrictive, so it got
crossed off the list right away.

Postfix seems to be popular amoung the Mandrake people -- I gather that
it's what MD installs by default.  Similarly, Exim is popular on Debian
machines, since it's their default mailer.  On Debian, Exim "Just Works"
for the vast majority of installations, with no configuration required
beyond the questions asked by it's postinstall script.

I found Postfix to be slightly more difficult to figure out that Exim. 
I never really could get Postfix to work right wrt header rewriting and
intranet domain masquerading.  Supposedly, Postfix's multi process
design is more secure than the monolithic Sendmail or Exim.  The
argument is that Sendmail runs as root, and so if there's ever a buffer
overrun exploit, you can get rooted.  Exim runs as "mail" on Debian, and
IIRC, Postfix also runs as a non-root user, as does qmail, so if they
get cracked, at least the attacker is not given root.

I personally have not ever gotten down and dirty into the source code of
any of them, so cannot really make any FUD free statement regarding
actual system cracker proof security.  I think that actual cracking of
servers is relativly rare anyhow.  Some people are way too paranoid
about that issue than they need to be, IMO.  But that's how they make a
living.

IMAP
====

For IMAP, I've used only uw-imapd, since it Just Works out of the box
with standard login accounts.  It is what is used on
drizzle.pdxlinux.org.  The only configuration I had to do was to have it
allow plain passwords (but only over SSL) and to put the folder base in
the user's "Mail" directory to keep $HOME tidy.  A simple "apt-get
install uw-imapd" gets it up and running in short order.

For a dedicated email server where mail is expected to be kept on the
server and accessed via IMAP, and where the vast majority of users will
not have login access to that server, then Cyrus IMAPd is generally what
people use.  It is non-trivial to get up and running...

Cyrus IMAPd (via SASL) can be set up to obtain authentication data from
an Active Directory or LDAP server on your LAN, if you install the right
packages.  (Everything you need for that is part of Debian GNU/Linux,
already built and ready to install and use. You'll need libpam-ldap and
libnss-ldap, I'd guess...  I have not actually finished my research in
this area and have not yet configured a Cyrus IMAPd.)  It can also
obtain authentication data from the standard passwd database, or with
the kerberos system.

Cyrus supports the SEIVE server side mail filtering language.  I believe
it is the first IMAP to do so.  I have not used it...  Cyrus also lets
you set up shared mail folders.  Such a folder could be used to
implement rudimentary shared calendaring, by using the normal
peer-to-peer but emailing to a shared mailbox where everyone must check
in and update their Evolution calendar manually from the messages left
there.

There is also a suite called Courier that looks promising.  It has SMTP
and IMAP, plus calendaring, and web mail.  All are available from
Debian, so you can quickly try them that way if you like.  (Did I
mention that I'm a Debian advocate?)

Mail Server
===========

If it was me, I'd start with a minimal Debian 3.0 (Woody/stable)
install, and go with Exim 3 and either Cyrus IMAPd (harder) or uw-imapd
(easier, less capable) depending on how many users, etc.  I would
install Apache 1.3, optionally with libapache-mod-ssl, and Squirrelmail
for web email access.  Since Squirrelmail accesses the mailboxes via
IMAP, it should play well with other mail user agents that also use
IMAP.  I have not done much wrt testing uw-imapd with multiple clients
on the same account concurrently...  I would imagine that Cyrus is much
better in this area.

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu Dec  5 09:13:25 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 05 Dec 2002 09:13:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RedHat 8.0 manpage issue...
In-Reply-To: <200212050900.24997.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: <3DEEFDE8.90008@cribbins.net> 
	<200212050900.24997.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1039108405.1854.8.camel@cooper.cooper.stevenson.name>

Check out your TERM veriable:

echo $TERM

If it comes back as `linux' (it probably will) then you're golden. If
not, set the TERM variable to a `common denominator' value:

export TERM=vt100

or 

export TERM=linux

If either of the statements above fixes it, make your changes permanent
in /etc/inittab after having made a backup copy:

   cp /etc/inittab /etc/inittab.0


-Cooper

From windon at windon.net  Thu Dec  5 09:44:30 2002

Russ Johnson wrote:
> Has anyone else done this, and what sort of experience did you have?

All of the ideas presented thus far in the thread have merit.  I've used 
many of them and set up a few.

One that I did not see mentioned (though it wouldn't be the first time I 
missed a post in my plethora of email) is IPSec.  I assisted in setting 
this up once between three locations, each with their own unique 
192.168/16 address schema.  Once it was set up, we could browse the 
private LAN of the other two locations as if they were local.

I did find it difficult to set up even with the GUI provided by the 
package.  Perhaps it was because I didn't really know what I was doing 
at the time.  *shrugs*

> What package did you use?

I used a now defunct firewall product who's source code has been eaten 
up and destroyed by a large corporation who fears Linux.

> Thanks in advance for any information.

Good Luck,

Chesley

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Dec  5 10:10:24 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 5 Dec 2002 10:10:24 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Unknown activity on DSL
In-Reply-To: <1039031462.4993.256.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <20113-57408@sneakemail.com>

On 4 Dec 2002, Derek Loree derek-at-infotects.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Well, that is odd, so I installed and fired up sniffit on the other
> side of my firewall and the only thing it sees is the ssh connection
> that I used to connect to the box.  I did create some traffic and saw
> it, so I know that the sniffer is working.
> 
> My question is:  What could be causing this activity and is there a way
> to confirm this?

It sounds like you've done all the right things.  It's strange that you
don't see the traffic on the public side of your firewall.

Does your modem's link/activity indicator for the "PC" (firewall) side
show activity?  If you only see the activity upstream from the modem, you
probably will never be able to tell what it is without your own DSL
analyzer.  ;-)

If you see activity downstream from the modem, perhaps your sniffer isn't
working as well as it might appear.  Are you running SniffIt on a Windows
system?  I've had problems sniffing non-IP traffic on Windows before.  

Were you sniffing from your firewall itself, or from a third system
connected into the network?  I've had problems with some firewall software
dropping packets before they get to the sniffer (this was on Solaris,
though).  If it's a third system connected to the network make sure your
hub is really a hub.  I've seen LOTS of "hubs" that are really using
switching hardware, sometimes in bizarre ways (i.e. Linksys).  It
sometimes helps to power-cycle your hub right before sniffing.

Unless you can see the traffic, it'll be real hard to figure out what it
is.  ;-)

  -- Steve

On Thu, 2002-12-05 at 10:12, Russell Evans wrote:

> in the pool with out a lease.

AFAIK, the dhcp server is not enabled, and I know I haven't made any
configuration changes to it.  Another argument against this, is that if
dhcp was enabled, it would be in conjuction with NAT, so the address
pool would be private addresses, and the only addresses the "modem" can
see are public, which means that the 678 can't see any addresses in its
DHCP pool (if it does have a pool).

Thanks for the suggestion, process of elimination helps too.

On 5 Dec 2002, Derek Loree derek-at-infotects.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> The box that runs SniffIt does not have any firewall rules running
> while I do the sniffing.  I really want to see those packets.  Good
> point about the hub, but I ran "known" traffic through it and was able
> to see that.

You might try a restart on the hub, or even try a different brand
hub.  I've seem some truly strange things with consumer-grade hubs and
packet capture such as every-few packets go to all ports, but most
don't.  Only the uplink port goes to all other ports, etc.

This may not be possible if things have to keep running, but you might try
connecting the modem directly to your sniffer PC via a crossover and see
if the activity blinks continue.  That would eliminate any possiblity of
hub-related silliness.

Another option would be to try a different sniffer just in case some wierd
sniffer bug is involved.

  -- Steve

From flee at aracnet.com  Wed Dec  4 21:04:32 2002
From: flee at aracnet.com (Felix Lee)
Date: Wed, 04 Dec 2002 21:04:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] File renaming scripts?
In-Reply-To: <E18Jhox-0006rP-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org> on Wed, 04 Dec 2002 13:48:32 PST.
Message-ID: <200212050504.gB554XO01590@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

"Russell Evans" <revans at e-z.net>:
> $ for i in `ls` ; do echo $i  ; done
> $ for i in * ; do echo $i  ; done

the important thing to know is when the shell splits a
string into a list of "words".  The 'for' statement
iterates over a list of words.

globbing happens after a statement has already been split
into a list.  the '*' in the list gets replaced with a list
of filenames, so the for statement will iterate over all the
filenames.  spaces in the filenames don't matter.

backquote substitution happens before a statement gets split
into a list.  the output from `ls` is a stream of text, just
a single string.  the shell then splits that string at every
space to get a list of words.

if you have filenames with spaces, then the splitting won't
be what you want, because the output from `ls` does not
unambiguously delineate filenames.

this is a ubiquitous problem that arises out of the unix
philosophy that output from programs should be usable both
by humans and by other programs.  there are some awkward
cases like spaces or newlines in filenames that never got
resolved well, mainly because they used to be rare.
--



From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Dec  5 14:03:08 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 5 Dec 2002 14:03:08 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Unknown activity on DSL
In-Reply-To: <1039119458.4998.290.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <32656-69052@sneakemail.com>

On 5 Dec 2002, Derek Loree derek-at-infotects.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> On Thu, 2002-12-05 at 11:45, Steve Bonds wrote:

> Not that I want you to point fingers, but do you know what brands are
> the worst and what ones are the best; as far as "hub-like" behavior
> goes?

I've had especially poor luck with Linksys in this regard.  I've had good
luck with Netgear and 3Com hubs, though I've heard reports from people
using 3Com hubs of packet capture problems.

I think many times it depends on who made the chips inside the hub and
which revision you were lucky enough to get.  Nice, eh?

> > Another option would be to try a different sniffer just in case some wierd
> > sniffer bug is involved.
> 
> Another good idea, have you had better results from one particular
> sniffer?

I've had good luck using tcpdump to capture and ethereal to
display.  Using ethereal to capture would probably work identically since
they both make the same libpcap calls.

Another hub-related issue: usually dual-speed hubs only send all the
non-broadcast traffic to other stations running at the same
speed.  I.e. don't try to sniff 10base traffic with a 100base card unless
you force it down to 10base.  Note that most DSL modems run 10baseT.  The
crossover cable connection will fix this problem.

One other thing I thought of-- some NICs don't like to go into promiscuous
mode.  (They say they went into promiscuous mode, but they really
didn't.  Your simple test should have caught this unless you were sending
the traffic to your network monitoring station.)

  -- Steve

Bash and Zsh both support array variables.  They don't quite work the
same in both shells.  I found that they work better in Zsh... that was
quite some time ago and I've not written huge amounts of shell code.

One problem I had was due to my misunderstanding of globbing, I think. 
I thought that filling the array with the results of a glob would make
it split the file names on spaces, and give me an array with broken file
names in it.  Perhaps now if I went back, I could make that script I
tried to write that day work.  I might not even need the array variable,
though perhaps I might, if I don't want to glob more than once for a set
of files I process twice or something.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Thu Dec  5 14:48:04 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Thu, 5 Dec 2002 14:48:04 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Why Everyone Should Learn to Program
In-Reply-To: <1039126957.2250.133.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212051439150.1977-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 5 Dec 2002, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

> These are perfect examples of what I started talking about in another
> branch of this thread...  "non-technical" people often don't really know
> how to use the computerized office tools very well.

  There are two issues here, Karl, and you've hit on one of them. There is a
skill set in using computer applications -- and the computer system itself
-- that should be part of everyone's capabilities. We don't let people
drive a car or a boat or pilot a plane without some level of instruction and
demonstration of competence in the mechanics of using the equipment. I agree
that this needs to be taught to _everyone_. (I don't want to see them all
programming, but that's a different thread.) Those of you in the CS/IT/MIS
and SysAdmin professions see the results of letting anyone behind the wheel
of a computer. The results can be quite ugly.

  The second issue is different and, for some of us, of equal or greater
importance than is the first issue. Teaching someone the mechanics of using
a word processor does not make him/her a writer. Similarly, learning the
mechanics of the appropriate applications does not make one an artist
(graphic or fine art), statistician, spatial analyist or page layout guru.
On this issue, the computer is simply a tool that takes the mechanical
drudgery out of the intellectual task. It allows more focus on the expertise
just as using a four-function calculator minimizes (or eliminates)
arithmetic errors, but it takes different skills to know which keys to push
to get the correct answer.

  I'm bothered by the second issue.

Rich

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Thu Dec  5 15:14:22 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Thu, 5 Dec 2002 15:14:22 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why Everyone Should Learn to Program
In-Reply-To: <1039126957.2250.133.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212040842510.27290-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org> <1039104286.3276.11611.camel@obelisk.spek.org> <1039126957.2250.133.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <200212051514.22841.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Thursday 05 December 2002 14:22, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> On Thu, 2002-12-05 at 08:04, Brent Rieck wrote:
> > On Thu, 2002-12-05 at 03:17, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > > Doesn't it just bug the shit out of you when some dope
> > > PRINTS an email?

No, why should it? There are all kinds of reasons for making hard copies, 
that's why we have printers attached to computers.

> They just plain don't know any different.  They've never been exposed to
> other, better, ways of doing things.  All they've ever used is Windows,
> and they don't have a computer at home.  They are not given admin
> priveledges on the computer they use at work, and know very little about
> what actually occurs inside the computer.
>Why Everyone Should Learn to Program:

I don't agree that learning to program makes a person a more skilled computer 
user. It's a different skill set. It won't make a person a better accountant, 
or writer, or better at analyzing and managing data. Where it may be useful 
is teaching people to think analytically. But it won't make them better at 
using applications. Training in the applications does that. 

In fact, I argue the opposite: that having a broad set of skills and life 
experiences makes programmers write better programs. How can you write good 
code without an understanding of what will work well, and be practical? How 
can you write good code if you have contempt for your users? How can you 
write good code without understanding the profession you are writing for, 
whether it be accounting, publishing, graphics, etc? Kind of like building a 
house without understanding what the people who live in them will need. Which 
is the standard, very few houses are designed sensibly. Just like most 
computer programs.

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Thu Dec  5 15:47:31 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Thu, 5 Dec 2002 15:47:31 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Unknown activity on DSL
In-Reply-To: <1039129294.4998.314.camel@dereklinux>
Message-ID: <11373-85694@sneakemail.com>

On 5 Dec 2002, Derek Loree derek-at-infotects.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

> Is there a non-GUI mode for ethereal?  I really like the program, but
> it is a hassle if there is no x-server on the box.  I guess I should
> figure out how to dump on the sniffing box, and move the dump to my
> workstation for display by ethereal.

It's easy.

On the sampling system:

# tcpdump -s 2048 -n -i eth0 -w /tmp/packetcap-001.tcpdump
.... capture for a while ...
^C

On the nice, fancy X-Windows system:

# scp user at sampling:/tmp/packetcap-001.tcpdump /tmp/.
# ethereal -t a -r /tmp/packetcap-001.tcpdump &

I'll let you refer to the appropriate man pages to see what the options
do.  One comment-- the "2048" is quite oversized for an ethernet network,
but will catch really strange things should they happen.  ;-)

  -- Steve

I don't attend PLUG meetings because it is an inconvenient location no matter 
what means of transportation I use. Coming from Beaverton, it's a hassle, 
driving or transit. I'll choose a 20-minute drive in my gas-hog import 
minivan over a 60-minute multi-transfer smoke-belching-bus/MAX adventure any 
day. Especially for an evening meeting. Yeah, I know the streets o Portland 
are safe as the streets of heaven, and all those scary people riding the Max 
are really angels at heart. Like the SOB who tried to pickpocket my backpack, 
or the gang o hoodlums who were set to rob all the passengers, until a timely 
flood of cops changed their plans. It's starting to smell like Seattle 
transit, every public facility up there stinks of urine. I ride transit at 
least once a week, don't give me lies about how great it is. 

My van gets pretty good mileage, 18 in town, 25 on the highway. It hauls 
camping gear and pulls a boat quite handily, as well as a heavy power 
wheelchair. My sweetie needs the wheelchair. I know, she should figure out 
how to ride a bicycle or something, but the wheelchair is what she chooses to 
use.

I'll hang my head in shame in a daily 30-second ritual over my evil ways.

Carla

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Thu Dec  5 23:03:52 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 05 Dec 2002 23:03:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why Everyone Should Learn to Program
In-Reply-To: <200212051514.22841.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
References: 
	 <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212040842510.27290-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>
	 <1039104286.3276.11611.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
	 <1039126957.2250.133.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <200212051514.22841.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>
Message-ID: <1039158231.2250.178.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Thu, 2002-12-05 at 15:14, Carla Schroder wrote:
> On Thursday 05 December 2002 14:22, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > On Thu, 2002-12-05 at 08:04, Brent Rieck wrote:
> > > On Thu, 2002-12-05 at 03:17, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > > > Doesn't it just bug the shit out of you when some dope
> > > > PRINTS an email?
> 
> No, why should it? There are all kinds of reasons for making hard copies, 
> that's why we have printers attached to computers.
> 
> > They just plain don't know any different.  They've never been exposed to
> > other, better, ways of doing things.  All they've ever used is Windows,
> > and they don't have a computer at home.  They are not given admin
> > priveledges on the computer they use at work, and know very little about
> > what actually occurs inside the computer.
> >Why Everyone Should Learn to Program:
> 
> I don't agree that learning to program makes a person a more skilled computer 
> user. It's a different skill set. It won't make a person a better accountant, 
> or writer, or better at analyzing and managing data. Where it may be useful 
> is teaching people to think analytically. But it won't make them better at 
> using applications. Training in the applications does that. 
> 
> In fact, I argue the opposite: that having a broad set of skills and life 
> experiences makes programmers write better programs. How can you write good 
> code without an understanding of what will work well, and be practical? How 
> can you write good code if you have contempt for your users? How can you 
> write good code without understanding the profession you are writing for, 
> whether it be accounting, publishing, graphics, etc? Kind of like building a 
> house without understanding what the people who live in them will need. Which 
> is the standard, very few houses are designed sensibly. Just like most 
> computer programs. 

How can I design better software if the people I'm writing it for have
no real concept of what computer programming is, or of what really goes
on inside a computer?  What I mean is, that if they have some knowledge
of the process and of what is possible, they can provide better
requirements process input and feedback.

Everyone should learn to program, but not everyone will become a
professional programmer.  Every driver should know how a car works, but
not very many will ever become mechanics or automobile engineers.  Many
more will learn a little about maintaining and tuning their auto than
will become design engineers.  Not every Emacs user will hack Emacs'
out-of-the-box internals.  Every Linux user should be capable of
troubleshooting and providing useful bug reports and design feedback,
but not all will develop the skills required to actually fix the
software internals when they are broken.

The other thing is that the most useful software is designed to be user
extensible with an embedded programming language of some kind.  Every
Emacs user should learn some Lisp and be capable of using it on
occasion, for instance.  The tool is just orders of magnitude more
useful then.  An accountant should be capable of performing some
customization of the software used to perform that job, provided it
supports that.  In this sense, learning to design and write programs is
application training.  Knowing how to do it, and expecting that good
software will allow this sort of end-user customization is another thing
that learning to program does for a computer user.

http://www.htdp.org/

From merlyn at stonehenge.com  Thu Dec  5 09:02:48 2002
From: merlyn at stonehenge.com (Randal L. Schwartz)
Date: 05 Dec 2002 09:02:48 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] File renaming scripts?
References: <20021124235522.GA13873@feather.net> <3DE27C55.6030103@pacifier.com> <20021125114708.K70200@cogit8.org> <1038254171.11834.13.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net> <mailman.1039040227.26408.plug@lists.pdxlinux.org>
Message-ID: <86smxc7613.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>

>>>>> "Russell" == Russell Evans <revans at e-z.net> writes:

Russell> so I think this works

Russell> $ for i in * ; do if [ "$i" != `echo $i | sed 's/ /_/g'` ] ; then mv "$i" `echo $i | sed 's/ /_/g'` ; fi ; done

Russell> $ ls 
Russell> 1_2

Russell> why is this?

That's all fine and good until you get a filename with a newline in
it.  Yes, it can happen.  Yes, you don't want to be creating a
security hole or breakage when it does.

I'd suggest instead:

perl -e 'for (@ARGV) { ($new = $_) =~ s/ /_/g; rename $_, $new unless -e $new }' *

As far as I know the RCA box is just the cable modem. It may or may not 
have a port filtering capability. I've had cable modem service for 
nearly 3 years and I don't know anything about my RCA modem. I've never 
been able to figure out how to connect to any sort of online 
configuration for it or anything.

It's a war zone on ATTBI's network with script kiddies and others 
probing around for open ports like crazy. I've only had Linux and 
OpenBSD systems connected to my cable modem and have always used a 
firewall.

I do squelch some of the firewall logging to ignore the many port 80 
probes as well as all of broadcast noise that goes along with a cable 
network. The broadcast noise is the worst with my firewall filtering 
out many 1000's of packets. 

Tony

On Thu, 2002-12-05 at 23:25, Preston Crawford wrote:
> I like it. I don't think it's a lie to say it's a great system. Am I
> stupid, then, I guess?

No, you're not stupid, but I don't agree that it's a great system,
merely a comparatively pretty okay system.  It is a very poor system for
those that live in the suburbs; Tri-Met serves the close in Eastside and
the (very) close in Westside very well, get beyond that and expect a
bus/max trip to take 2 to 3 times longer than a car trip would (not
counting finding parking at your destination).  7 years of riding the
bus into downtown from Beaverton showed me that.  Even worse is trying
to get from one suburb location to another - my commute from my house in
Beaverton to PCC Sylvania was 1.25 hours (including the 15 minute walk
to the bus station), when I could get a ride that time was shaved down
to 15 minutes.  Even worse than *that* is getting from one suburban
location to another suburban location on the opposite side of town, my
daily commute from Beaverton to beyond the Airport one summer a few
years ago now ate 4 hours of my day, every weekday; by car it would've
only eaten 1 hour of my day.

Poor suburban service (which is admittedly expensive to run) compounded
with the fact that Tri-Met keeps reducing the usefulness of their maps
by making them more and more diagrammatic and less and less
representational (particularly irksome because it's a completely
avoidable issue) making it harder to find out how to get to a location
using the bus, as well as completely different schedule layouts
depending on if you're looking at them online or on paper, poor night
and weekend service, and NEVER being on time, make Tri-Met look just
okay in my eyes.  And I'm the type of person that doesn't mind (that
much) when somebody sits down next to me who's body odor could be
measured in parts per ten, or planning in the additional time it takes
to ride Tri-Met; forget about it for most people.

About the diagrammatic maps: Because their maps are now diagrams rather
than maps I have to use a real map along with the Tri-Met route diagrams
to try and interpolate where the bus ACTUALLY goes and how close that is
to my destination; were I just driving I'd often be there by the time I
figured out what bus(ses) I have to take to get there.

A significant reason for moving to NW PDX was so I could avoid the bus
completely and walk to work downtown.

--Brent

The RCA box is the cable modem.  It's just a layer two bridge with an IP for 
managment purposes.  There is NO security built into this box.

Your customer will need to purchase a hardware firewall (best) or a software 
firewall.

The actual problem (and I have verified this myself) is the local being
set to UTF8 (probably en_US.UT8) and the culprit is the LANG variable,
setting it to just en_US should solve the man problems.

> Check out your TERM veriable:
> 
> echo $TERM
> 
> If it comes back as `linux' (it probably will) then you're golden. If
> not, set the TERM variable to a `common denominator' value:
> 
> export TERM=vt100
> 
> or 
> 
> export TERM=linux
> 
> If either of the statements above fixes it, make your changes permanent
> in /etc/inittab after having made a backup copy:
> 
>    cp /etc/inittab /etc/inittab.0

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Dec  6 09:14:50 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 09:14:50 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Proprietary Software & the GPL
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212060851080.5304-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

  Mark Rosen's column at the rear of the latest (Jan. '03) "Linux Journal"
started me thinking about application development on linux. I know (or have
strong reason to believe) that there are no lawyers, attorneys, or
cousellors among the denizens of this list, but some of you work for ISVs
so you may have some insight useful to me.

  The context is this: I'm porting a C library from DOS/Windows to linux
with the original author's permission. My original intention was to use this
library (or libraries, actually) as the core of approximate reasoning models
I would develop to address environmental concerns on behalf of clients. I
would write the models (in C) and use gtk+/gdk for the UI. Because the
application would not be distributed I had no concerns about license issues.
However, I can now see advantages of selling copies to regulatory and
resource agencies, and training them in the proper use of the models. I have
no intention of releasing the whole application under the GPL; it will
remain proprietary.

  Where I'd appreciate your _thoughtful_ comments are on these issues: as
Rosen wrote, linking to a GPL'd (or LGPL'd) library does not modify any of
that original, open source code so it's almost certainly not a derivative
work. Using GNU tools (make, gcc, etc.) to build the models also does not
make my applicaton a derivative of each or any of them. So I can keep my
models closed source and proprietary because the only included open source
components are the libraries I used to create my own application interface.

  This seems to be established, but I don't know for certain. The terribly
expensive, excessively poor quality accounting software I purchased a couple
of years ago is certainly closed source and propietary although it has both
a ncurses interface and a tcl/tk interface. Other proprietary applications,
I'm sure, also use these multiplatform tools for the user interface without
license violations.

  As a very litteral, straight-line thinking scientist, Rosen's contention
that using a library is not creating a derivative from it makes perfect
sense to me. If, for the purposes of my application, I modified or enhanced
gtk+ or gdk, then I would have created a derivative work, but not otherwise.

  Considered opinions, please.

Rich




From mindglow at got-roots.com  Fri Dec  6 09:33:38 2002
From: mindglow at got-roots.com (Doug Davis)
Date: 06 Dec 2002 09:33:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Proprietary Software & the GPL
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212060851080.5304-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212060851080.5304-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1039196018.2371.6.camel@alvin.energy.nrgroot.com>

On Fri, 2002-12-06 at 09:14, Rich Shepard wrote:

> However, I can now see advantages of selling copies to regulatory and
> resource agencies, and training them in the proper use of the models. I have
> no intention of releasing the whole application under the GPL; it will
> remain proprietary.
> 

On an ethical level, I think that you are doing a huge disservice to the
community that you so often speak highly of. Why do you think it is
moral to not release back to the community in the same spirit that the
GPL libraries and tools were gifted to you? The community only works if
people give as well as take. Are you only a taker or do you want to put
your money where your mouth is? Consider whatever potential revenue that
you may lose as payment for the many times you used other people's work
gratis. Sell your training and implementation on these tools to the
agencies if you need a revenue stream.

-- 
Doug Davis <mindglow at got-roots.com>

Just to give you real world results. I drove to work (downtown from SW 
185th) yesterday, and rode the Max today.

Driving:

Left house: 8:15
Arrived Work: 8:47
Elapsed: 32 minutes.

This included the time walking to my car, parking in a garage, and 
walking a block to work.

I avoid most of the Sunset parking lot by driving through Beaverton up 
Canyon Rd. So I don't get on 26 until Sylvan. I'll hate that when they 
turn on the meter at that on ramp. Talk about planned congestion.

Max:

Left house: 8:06
Parked car at Willow Creek: 8:15
Max arrives: 8:23
Arrive Pioneer Square: 8:53
Arrive Work: 8:59
Elapsed: 53 minutes.

This includes the time walking to my car, the time walking to and 
waiting for the Max, and the time walking the four blocks from the Max 
to work. The trip outlined here is typical for a morning, rush hour 
commute from Willow Creek transit center. I've been doing this for 
almost 4 years.

I don't think nearly a doubling of my travel time as "very little longer 
than driving".

From russj at dimstar.net  Fri Dec  6 09:51:59 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Fri, 06 Dec 2002 09:51:59 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Why Everyone Should Learn to Program
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212040842510.27290-100000@ebersisk.clueserver.org>	 <1039104286.3276.11611.camel@obelisk.spek.org>	 <1039126957.2250.133.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>	 <200212051514.22841.pluglist@bratgrrl.com> <1039158231.2250.178.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <3DF0E3BF.7080802@dimstar.net>

Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

>How can I design better software if the people I'm writing it for have
>no real concept of what computer programming is, or of what really goes
>on inside a computer?  What I mean is, that if they have some knowledge
>of the process and of what is possible, they can provide better
>requirements process input and feedback.
>
Obviously, you've never worked for a real developer, or with 
professional programmers.

Many of the programmers I've worked with have no idea how to set up 
networking in any OS. Many of the programmers I've worked with know how 
to write code, but couldn't install Windows by clicking "Next" all the 
way through the installation. They are quite good at what they do. 
However, they choose to write code, not spend time learning how the 
interface to set up their system works. Why? Because that part of the OS 
isn't germain to the task at hand. How to plug an IP into Windows, 
Linux, Solaris, or AIX doesn't matter one bit when it comes to the 
application they are programming. Knowing the TCP/IP stack and how to 
access it IS needed. Knowing how to configure the TCP/IP stack is 
irrelevent, as it better work BEFORE the application is installed.

I can set up a network, and install many different OSes, but I can't 
write anything more than a very trivial program in C++. I'm better in 
Perl, but that's because I have a need for perl in my real job. 

>Everyone should learn to program, but not everyone will become a
>professional programmer.  Every driver should know how a car works, but
>not very many will ever become mechanics or automobile engineers.  Many
>more will learn a little about maintaining and tuning their auto than
>will become design engineers.  Not every Emacs user will hack Emacs'
>out-of-the-box internals.  Every Linux user should be capable of
>troubleshooting and providing useful bug reports and design feedback,
>but not all will develop the skills required to actually fix the
>software internals when they are broken.
>
We've had this discussion before, and I still disagree with you.

The user of the software doesn't need to know how the program works 
internally. Users KNOW what they want, and they will ask for it. It's 
the job of the programmer to turn those requests into code that performs 
the requested functions.

Just as it's the job of the mechanic to fix the squeak coming from "back 
there".

In a perfect world, everyone would be completely self sufficient, and we 
wouldn't have to rely on our fellow human beings to get on with our 
lives. It just doesn't work that way in the real world. When I was 
running the auto parts store I used to help manage, one of the first 
instructions I would give to new employees was, "If you haven't done it 
before, ASK!." I'd rather they ask and get help (relying on me or 
another, more experienced co-worker) than attempt to muddle through 
until they're frustrated, and the customer is pissed off.

Russ

Driving: (More subjective)
Morning: 25 minutes - 45 minutes
Evening: 30 minutes - 1.25 hours

more.

Disadvantages: Some people annoy me.  ~2 extra hours each day.

Advantages to auto: Quicker. Easier to run errands.
Disadvantages: Other drivers. more stress.

the time to spare.  But then again, my Intel contract is up next month so it's a

If I worked downtown, then MAX is the way to go. slower, but way cheaper when
parking is factored in.

Mike De La Mater <mikedela at ipns.com> wrote:

> What's the hardware that comes with new attbi service?
>
> I've got a customer with a 6 month old attbi install, win98 and no
> anti-virus software. It was riddled with virii, now it won't connect
> with the net.
>
> They tell me it has a firewall, but I dn't know what the RCA box in
> the line is.
> Anybody out there know?

As far as I know, there is no firewall in the cable modem, your
customer's RCA box. Mine is a model DCM235, which I got from attbi to
replace the one installed by TCI back when the service was introduced. I
used ZoneAlarm on my Windows machine until I got my router, a Netgear
RT314. I haven't had any intrusion problems since installing the it. The
only problem I do have is that once a week or so, I have to power down
and restart the router. I think it's related to the lease expiring on my
attbi ip address. There may be a way to handle that without going
through the shut down, but I haven't taken the time to get out the
documentation CD and look it up. It's pretty easy to pull the power plug
out, wait a few seconds, and put it back in. That may not be an
acceptable practice for your customer, so you should take that into
account when recommending a solution. There have also been a few
occasions when I've had to pull the power plug from the cable modem to
reset it. The power button doesn't do anything, as far as I've noticed!
I've never pursued why that power cycling is necessary; it's only
happened two or three times in the past year.

If you want more details about the Netgear router, contact me off list
and we'll figure out a way to send you the information.

From ckuskie at dalsemi.com  Fri Dec  6 10:19:32 2002
From: ckuskie at dalsemi.com (Colin Kuskie)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 10:19:32 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Proprietary Software & the GPL
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212060851080.5304-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212060851080.5304-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <20021206181932.GC14799@dalsemi.com>

On Fri, Dec 06, 2002 at 09:14:50AM -0800, Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
>   Where I'd appreciate your _thoughtful_ comments are on these issues: as
> Rosen wrote, linking to a GPL'd (or LGPL'd) library does not modify any of
> that original, open source code so it's almost certainly not a derivative
> work. Using GNU tools (make, gcc, etc.) to build the models also does not
> make my applicaton a derivative of each or any of them. So I can keep my
> models closed source and proprietary because the only included open source
> components are the libraries I used to create my own application interface.

You may want to spend some time looking through the
linux-kernel-mailing-list archives because they do a lot of very
similar work, and while Linus is also not a lawyer, his latest
interpretation of the GPL says that linking to a binary only driver
(like from Nvidia) is no protection from the GPL.  So if you release
your interface under the GPL, you could be clobbering the library.

Also, your preferences for license may be moot, since you're porting
someone else's work.  The IP in the library is still the original
authors unless he's assigend it over to you.

There's a great CGI based quiz on the GNU site that may help shed some
light on issues, as well as essays on LWN.

The Kompany has a hybrid model.  I think that all of their products are
open-source, but not GPL.  Many of the products are for-pay.  This
provides them a revenue stream but allows for bug fixing and code
review by others.

I think in short, despite the flames you'll get from those who believe
solely in free software above all, none of us would deny you a right to
make a living but my personal hope is that you take this opportunity to
give back to the free/open software community at large in some way.

Good luck, and may the asbestos in your MUA be thick!
Colin

On Fri, 2002-12-06 at 09:33, Doug Davis wrote:
> On Fri, 2002-12-06 at 09:14, Rich Shepard wrote:
> 
> > However, I can now see advantages of selling copies to regulatory and
> > resource agencies, and training them in the proper use of the models. I have
> > no intention of releasing the whole application under the GPL; it will
> > remain proprietary.
> > 
> 
> On an ethical level, I think that you are doing a huge disservice to the
> community that you so often speak highly of. Why do you think it is
> moral to not release back to the community in the same spirit that the
> GPL libraries and tools were gifted to you? The community only works if
> people give as well as take. Are you only a taker or do you want to put
> your money where your mouth is? Consider whatever potential revenue that
> you may lose as payment for the many times you used other people's work
> gratis. Sell your training and implementation on these tools to the
> agencies if you need a revenue stream.

I've heard even programmers need to eat.

It was the GNU developers' right to release the source code to the
things they developed.

It is Rich's right to release the source code to what he develops... but
not a responsibility.  Ethically, how can you guilt him in to releasing
something he has worked quite hard on - then only making money providing
support for it... something that, once the source is out, somebody else
could quite easily do?

Naw, giving away something like that just doesn't make sense.  Perhaps
after he has made a reasonably level of revenue, if he is actually the
license holder (as he is porting from a different library - he could be
held by an NDA or something similar) he would release the source... but
let the guy make a few bucks.  :-)

And, to Rich, I am almost certain you can link against GPL'd libraries
without any problem.  If you distribute the binaries, you may need to
also distribute the source *for the GPL'd stuff* ... and if you modify
any of the GPL'd libraries, you need to release the source, but you
should be able to link against it without concern.

Subject: [PLUG] procmail country question
In-Reply-To: <1428.208.151.243.124.1039197505.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>; from robby@planetargon.com on Fri, Dec 06, 2002 at 09:58:25AM -0800

Message-ID: <20021206103056.A23628@kippered.herring.org>

regexp are your friend (or worst enemy)...


:0
* ^From.*\.pl$
{
    LOG="(.pl) "
    # EX_NOUSER = 67 from sysexits.h
    EXITCODE = 67
    :0
    /dev/null
}


Note that the period before the "pl" is escaped so that it's not interpreted
as a regexp (match one anything). Note also that the extended regexp token
for end of a line "$". That's where you tripped. `man procmailrc' for more
details.

Sandy

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Dec  6 10:45:50 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 10:45:50 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Proprietary Software & the GPL
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212060851080.5304-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <9100-10935@sneakemail.com>

On Fri, 6 Dec 2002, Rich Shepard rshepard-at-appl-ecosys.com |PDX Linux| wrote:

>   Where I'd appreciate your _thoughtful_ comments are on these issues:
> as Rosen wrote, linking to a GPL'd (or LGPL'd) library does not modify
> any of that original, open source code so it's almost certainly not a
> derivative work. Using GNU tools (make, gcc, etc.) to build the models
> also does not make my applicaton a derivative of each or any of them.
> So I can keep my models closed source and proprietary because the only
> included open source components are the libraries I used to create my
> own application interface.

Summary:
  + GPL-- don't try linking it
  + LGPL-- you should be OK
  + Using GNU tools-- you are almost certainly OK

This might help:

"The GNU Project has two principal licenses to use for libraries. One is
the GNU Library GPL; the other is the ordinary GNU GPL. The choice of
license makes a big difference: using the Library GPL permits use of the
library in proprietary programs; using the ordinary GPL for a library
makes it available only for free programs."

from http://www.gnu.org/licenses/why-not-lgpl.html.

My understanding is that you cannot link a non-GPL program to a GPLed
library.  The GPL FAQ seems pretty clear on this:

http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-faq.html#LinkingWithGPL

The terms of the LGPL appear to allow linking into a non-[L]GPLed program,
but the legalese in that section is particularly confusing.  It would
appear that it's possible in at least some circumstances to create a
linked program that violates the LGPL.

Using GNU tools to build non-GNU software seems to be an unambiguous
"OK".  http://www.gnu.org/licenses/gpl-faq.html#CanIUseGPLToolsForNF has
more info.

Generally speaking, even if you accidently violate the GPL, the worst that
is likely to happen is you would be asked to stop distribution until you
can replace the [L]GPLed code with your own.  You would not be forced to
open your source code, mostly because that would be a PR disaster for the
Free Software Foundation and would turn businesses away from the GPL even
more.  (I doubt such a thing would even be enforceable, so I wouldn't
worry too much about it.)

As usual, don't construe this as legal advice and check with your own
lawyers.

  -- Steve

On Fri, 2002-12-06 at 10:26, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Fri, 2002-12-06 at 09:33, Doug Davis wrote:
> > On Fri, 2002-12-06 at 09:14, Rich Shepard wrote:
> > 
> > > However, I can now see advantages of selling copies to regulatory and
> > > resource agencies, and training them in the proper use of the models. I have
> > > no intention of releasing the whole application under the GPL; it will
> > > remain proprietary.
> > > 
> > 
> > On an ethical level, I think that you are doing a huge disservice to the
> > community that you so often speak highly of. Why do you think it is
> > moral to not release back to the community in the same spirit that the
> > GPL libraries and tools were gifted to you? The community only works if
> > people give as well as take. Are you only a taker or do you want to put
> > your money where your mouth is? Consider whatever potential revenue that
> > you may lose as payment for the many times you used other people's work
> > gratis. Sell your training and implementation on these tools to the
> > agencies if you need a revenue stream.
> 
> I've heard even programmers need to eat.
> 
> It was the GNU developers' right to release the source code to the
> things they developed.
> 
> It is Rich's right to release the source code to what he develops... but
> not a responsibility.  Ethically, how can you guilt him in to releasing
> something he has worked quite hard on - then only making money providing
> support for it... something that, once the source is out, somebody else
> could quite easily do?
> 
> Naw, giving away something like that just doesn't make sense.  Perhaps
> after he has made a reasonably level of revenue, if he is actually the
> license holder (as he is porting from a different library - he could be
> held by an NDA or something similar) he would release the source... but
> let the guy make a few bucks.  :-)
> 
> And, to Rich, I am almost certain you can link against GPL'd libraries
> without any problem.  If you distribute the binaries, you may need to
> also distribute the source *for the GPL'd stuff* ... and if you modify
> any of the GPL'd libraries, you need to release the source, but you
> should be able to link against it without concern.
My point was that Rich's primary employment (as he has said many times)
is environmental consulting, not professional programming. He relies on
free software to run his business as well as free support from this
list. I don't think all software should be free, but when you are
adamantly against software that isn't open source for your personal use,
but then don't give the community the same consideration that you used
to your advantage, I just don't think it is right. I am pretty sure that
Rich can legally do what he is planning to do, but I don't think he is
returning the spirit of the gift. No one is denying that he needs to
eat, but it seems wrong to take out more than you give if you can afford
to do otherwise.


-- 
Doug Davis <mindglow at got-roots.com>




From richard.langis at sun.com  Fri Dec  6 11:15:23 2002

The problem is that he's PORTING a legacy DOS/Win library to linux with 
the original author's permission.

That author may not WANT his code to be GPL'ed.  The fact that Rich is 
wanting to do this for him is enough - if, later on, the ORIGINAL author 
decides to release his code (and Rich's ported source) to the GPL, then 
so be it.

But it is definitely NOT up to Rich as to wether the ported code gets 
released into the GPL.  All he wanted to know is if it would be okay to 
use GPL apps/libraries/code to create the frontend to his ported app.

-R

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Dec  6 12:24:41 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 12:24:41 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Proprietary Software & the GPL
In-Reply-To: <20021206181932.GC14799@dalsemi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212061212530.5923-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 6 Dec 2002, Colin Kuskie wrote:

> You may want to spend some time looking through the
> linux-kernel-mailing-list archives because they do a lot of very
> similar work, and while Linus is also not a lawyer, his latest
> interpretation of the GPL says that linking to a binary only driver
> (like from Nvidia) is no protection from the GPL.  So if you release
> your interface under the GPL, you could be clobbering the library.

  Thanks, Colin. Actually, I don't want to release any of it under the GPL.
_IF_ I end up selling specific-purpose models, then I want it closed source
and for a price.
 
> Also, your preferences for license may be moot, since you're porting
> someone else's work.  The IP in the library is still the original
> authors unless he's assigend it over to you.

  That's correct. My concern was linking the gdk/gtk+ libraries for my UI
rather than re-inventing the wheel. 

> I think in short, despite the flames you'll get from those who believe
> solely in free software above all, none of us would deny you a right to
> make a living but my personal hope is that you take this opportunity to
> give back to the free/open software community at large in some way.

  My point is that there is nothing to give back. I described the software
in my original message and it is so esoteric and of non-general use that no
one picked up on it. I'll bet few understand what an "adaptive reasoning"
model represents. Tools to describe fuzzy sets and to implement fuzzy logic
would have a very limited audience. It's important only to those who
manipulate linguistic variables (a collection of fuzzy sets) to evaluate
inherently imprecise real-world attributes. However, that audience would not
include any SysAdmin or application coder. The code -- in part -- was made
available in 1994 to the DOS/Windows world and we've not seen a big rush to
put out products using it. As a matter of fact, there are very few
practicioners in the business/scientific world, despite the fact that such
models are built into mechanical control systems that are commonly used.

  If I offered it back, almost everyone would wonder what the heck it is,
then shrug and go on with their own life.
 
> Good luck, and may the asbestos in your MUA be thick!

  I have a very thick skin: I'm an environmental consultant, remember? :-)

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Dec  6 12:30:10 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 12:30:10 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Removing previous kernels
In-Reply-To: <1039200902.8903.69.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212061226220.5923-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 6 Dec 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> I've upgraded the kernels in RedHat 8.0 . Is it possible or necessary to
> remove the previous kernels as I use the newest upgraded kernel.

  Possible, yes; necessary, no.

> If so how do I safely remove said kernels from /dev/hda1 that they're
> sitting on? In recent upgrade attempts I'm told that there isn't space
> available on that partition.I haven't installed the kernel debug or doc
> pkgs. I don't really need those for home desktop , do I?

  If you read the instructions on www.kernel.org you see that you can build
the new kernel anywhere you want. You should have sufficient room in /boot
for both kernels. You need to point links to the new kernel and modules
instead of the old ones. And, you need to tell LILO or grub where to find
each kernel. Then you can boot either one.

  In real life you don't want to remove a known-working kernel until you
prove that your new one also works flawlessly. Then you can 'rm -rf
/usr/src/<old-kernel> if you so desire.

  This has been a very superficial and imcomplete answer.

Rich

From 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com  Fri Dec  6 12:49:59 2002
From: 1s7k8uhcd001 at sneakemail.com (Steve Bonds)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 12:49:59 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] RPM controlled? (Re: Removing previous kernels)
In-Reply-To: <1039206689.2248.221.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <16654-87684@sneakemail.com>

On 6 Dec 2002, Karl M. Hegbloom karlheg-at-pdxlinux.org |PDX Linux| wrote:

> On Fri, 2002-12-06 at 11:02, Steve Bonds wrote:

> > I generally just "rm" the files out of /boot to avoid having RPM do
> > something stupid and remove a file I want to keep.
> 
> If you installed the kernel with RPM, you should also remove it that
> way.  It won't remove anything it does not own.

The problem is the way RedHat upgrades the kernel.  It overrides a lot of
the safeties build into RPM in order to allow people to have multiple
copies of the same package (kernel) installed.  While it usually behaves
intelligently on removal, it could get real ugly if it didn't.

I agree that the "cleanest" way to uninstall is to use RPM.

  -- Steve

PS: I just ran a file list on a RedHat 7.3 kernel package, and it looks
like it shouldn't remove anything unpleasant except possibly /dev/shm.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Fri Dec  6 13:00:29 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 06 Dec 2002 13:00:29 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Mailcap entries for OpenOffice.org, "mime-support", "update-mime"
In-Reply-To: <1039190326.1340.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1039159750.1498.19.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <1039159750.1498.19.camel@localhost.localdomain>
	 <5.1.1.6.0.20021206165337.00b35a18@pop.net-yan.com>
	 <1039190326.1340.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1039208428.30118.14.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Fri, 2002-12-06 at 07:58, Stephen Liu wrote:
> What I need is to start OpenOffice to read OfficeXP file attached to a
> webmail on Internet, not download it first and then read.

If you are browsing with Konqueror, then the setting is in the KDE
control panel, for file associations.  But Mozilla (New Netscape) does
not look there for it's own file associations.  You must configure that
through it's own settings dialog...

I believe that both Netscape 4.7 and Mozilla (Galeon ???) will use the
information in "/etc/mailcap" as well.  On a Debian GNU system, mailcap
is managed by the "mime-support" package's "update-mime" utility.  Many
packages that provide viewers and such call on "update-mime" in their
post install script to add entries.  Below are the entries from my
machine that pertain to OpenOffice.org.  I think you can just paste them
into "/etc/mailcap" (create it if it does not exist) and restart
Mozilla.  I don't know if these all work correctly or not.  If any of
them turn out to be wrong, it's a bug against the Debian openoffice
packages.

application/vnd.sun.xml.calc; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="OpenOffice.org 1.0 Spreadsheet"; nametemplate=%.sxc
application/vnd.sun.xml.calc.template; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="OpenOffice.org Spreadsheet Template"; nametemplate=%.stc
application/vnd.sun.xml.draw; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="OpenOffice.org 1.0 Drawing"; nametemplate=%.sxd
application/vnd.sun.xml.draw.template; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="OpenOffice.org Drawing Template"; nametemplate=%.std
application/vnd.sun.xml.impress; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="OpenOffice.org 1.0 Presentation"; nametemplate=%.sxi
application/vnd.sun.xml.impress.template; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="OpenOffice.org Presentation Template"; nametemplate=%.sti
application/vnd.sun.xml.writer; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="OpenOffice.org 1.0 Text Document"; nametemplate=%.sxw
application/vnd.sun.xml.writer.global; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="OpenOffice.org 1.0 Master Document"; nametemplate=%.sxg
application/vnd.sun.xml.writer.math; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="OpenOffice.org 1.0 Maths Document"
application/vnd.sun.xml.writer.template; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="OpenOffice.org Text Document Template"; nametemplate=%.stw
application/x-staroffice; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="StarOffice 5.0"
application/vnd.stardivision.calc; openoffice '%s';edit=openoffice '%s';test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ;description="StarCalc 5.0"; nametemplate=%.sdc
application/vnd.stardivision.chart; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="StarChart 5.0"; nametemplate=%.sds
application/vnd.stardivision.draw; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="StarDraw 5.0"; nametemplate=%.sda
application/vnd.stardivision.impress; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="StarImpress 5.0"; nametemplate=%.sdd
application/vnd.stardivision.math; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="StarMath 5.0"; nametemplate=%.sdf
application/vnd.stardivision.writer-global; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="StarWriter 5.0 Master Document"; nametemplate=%.sgl
application/vnd.stardivision.writer; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != "" ; description="StarWriter 5.0"; nametemplate=%.sdw
application/msword; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != ""; nametemplate=%s.doc; description="Microsoft Word Document"
application/msexcel; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != ""; nametemplate=%s.xls; description="Microsoft Excel Document"
application/mspowerpoint; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != ""; nametemplate=%s.xls; description="Microsoft PowerPoint Document"
application/vnd.ms-word; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != ""; nametemplate=%s.doc; description="Microsoft Word Document"
application/vnd.ms-excel; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != ""; nametemplate=%s.xls; description="Microsoft Excel Document"
application/vnd.ms-powerpoint; openoffice '%s'; edit=openoffice '%s'; test=test "$DISPLAY" != ""; nametemplate=%s.xls; description="Microsoft PowerPoint Document"

Be aware that your email displayer may have word wrapped those long
lines!!!  Each lines begins with a MIME type like:

application/vnd.sun.xml.calc

... and extends all the way until the next MIME type, which is on a new
line.

> copies of the same package (kernel) installed.  While it usually behaves
> intelligently on removal, it could get real ugly if it didn't.

Red Hat sucks.

> I agree that the "cleanest" way to uninstall is to use RPM.

The cleanest way, in my expert opinion, is to back up your personal
data, flat the box, and install Debian on it.

> PS: I just ran a file list on a RedHat 7.3 kernel package, and it looks
> like it shouldn't remove anything unpleasant except possibly /dev/shm.

They put device nodes in the RPM archive itself?  That's totally BOGUS. 
Device nodes should be created by a call to MAKEDEV from the postinstall
script.  And MAKEDEV should be a no-op when devfs is in use.
