From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Dec  6 14:00:54 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 06 Dec 2002 14:00:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Proprietary Software & the GPL
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212061212530.5923-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212061212530.5923-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <86k7imiz8p.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   Thanks, Colin. Actually, I don't want to release any of it
Rich> under the GPL.  _IF_ I end up selling specific-purpose models,
Rich> then I want it closed source and for a price.

You don't say specifically what "it" is in this context, but whatever
parts you get under GNU GPL or LGPL, you need to maintain that in
those parts upon redistribution.
 
CK> Also, your preferences for license may be moot, since you're
CK> porting someone else's work.  The IP in the library is still the
CK> original authors unless he's assigend it over to you.

Rich>   That's correct. My concern was linking the gdk/gtk+ libraries
Rich> for my UI rather than re-inventing the wheel.

It looks like GTK+ is licensed under the GNU LGPL, so as long as you
follow it's requirements, you are probably okay.  I'd suggest you read
the license to make sure you understand its requirements.

BTW, just because the software is a library, doesn't mean that the
LGPL applies.  You aren't allowed to link willy-nilly to GPL code just
because it's a library.  IANAL, but my understanding is that if your
software _depends_ on GPL'd software, then it is effectively
derivative whether it includes any or not.

Remember that the GPL doesn't exist _just_ to keep you from having to
reinvent the wheel.  The pain of reinventing the wheel (and especially
of _knowing_ you are reinventing) is _intended_ as an inducement to do
the Right Thing.

CK> I think in short, despite the flames you'll get from those who
CK> believe solely in free software above all, none of us would deny
CK> you a right to make a living but my personal hope is that you take
CK> this opportunity to give back to the free/open software community
CK> at large in some way.

Rich>   My point is that there is nothing to give back. I described
Rich> the software in my original message and it is so esoteric and of
Rich> non-general use that no one picked up on it. [...] 

That is not at all the point.  If there is enough to sell, there is
enough to "give back".  It doesn't matter whether it is a general
purpose tool or not.  The point is that the people who eventually use
it be able to fix it or adapt it to their specific needs without
necessarily your involvement.  By selling a closed-source tool, you
not only prevent that, but you also weaken its credibility by
preventing people from evaluating whether your program actually does
what you claim it does.


--

                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!'' 
                                        -- Burl Ives as Rufus Hennessy



From sandbox at pacifier.com  Fri Dec  6 14:15:03 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Fri, 06 Dec 2002 14:15:03 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RPM controlled? (Re: Removing previous kernels)
References: <16654-87684@sneakemail.com>
Message-ID: <3DF12167.1050507@pacifier.com>

Steve Bonds wrote:

> The problem is the way RedHat upgrades the kernel.  It overrides a lot of
> the safeties build into RPM in order to allow people to have multiple
> copies of the same package (kernel) installed.  While it usually behaves
> intelligently on removal, it could get real ugly if it didn't.
> 
> I agree that the "cleanest" way to uninstall is to use RPM.


The kernel packages are special in RedHat land in that you can remove them 
by full name.  Normally rpm won't accept something like

# rpm -e some_package-2.12.14

instead, you would have to do

# rpm some_package

obviously, when you have used rpm to install two kernels and want to get rid 
of one,

#rpm -e kernel

would be unpredicatble and undesirable, so instead you do

# rpm -e kernel-2.4.12-4

(whatever the unwanted version is).


I have accidently upgraded a kernel (-u) instead of installing (-i) and it 
worked.  I did reboot as soon as I could say "crap!" but it worked--no idea 
how...

--
Cheers,
Kyle Accardi

Rich,
    1. Seems to me that fuzzy stuff has been out there  a long time now and 
there very likely is some open stuff in some stage of development.  For 
example, I once did a baby system in Python.  If you don't worry about or 
postpone the syntactic sugar it's not very hard to do.
   2.  Keep in mind you can often split the problem into _data_ and a control 
system.  The thing you would want to keep proprietary would be the data you 
develop.  Sharing the development of the control system with other users in 
other knowledge domains would benefit you.
  3. If you developed a mixed system, you could allow your clients to access 
it as clients to your server which you would keep and maintain on site.  
Supporting in software is not something you want to do.

From hapibeli at attbi.com  Fri Dec  6 15:28:37 2002
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)
Date: 06 Dec 2002 15:28:37 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Kernel removal
Message-ID: <1039217317.8903.79.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Thanks Rich & Steve. What think you of these methods, particularly the
synaptic one?
Dirk

#1;
Let me start with a disclaimer - I've only done this one time and not on
a
RH installation.  That said, make sure that the symlink /usr/src/linux
points to the source files of the kernel you intend to keep.  Then, rm
the
tree of the source(s) you wish to discard.  Also, rm the related files
in
/boot - which is probably the partition that is squawking about
inadequate
space.

JimW


#2;
I'm also running Red Hat 8.0 and have upgraded the kernels.  I did
install synaptic and apt-get.  I used synaptic to select the older
kernels to remove, and it passed the remove request to apt-get, which
passed it to rpm.  It edited the grub config file for me too.

On 6 Dec 2002, AthlonRob wrote:
> For me, I have to drive up to Sherwood to catch a bus.  That's 20-30
> minutes there.  Then it takes "an hour" (scheduled time) to get up to
> PSU.  In reality, it takes between an hour and one and a half hours.
> 
> Driving takes 45 minutes to an hour... rarely does it take a full
> hour.

You can read on the bus or use a cellphone without endangering anyone and
maybe get to know some people that you wouldn't otherwise meet.  If you
drive, your time is spent driving and maybe listening to something.  If
you take the bus, your options are much wider.

And you're building up habits and tolerances that will allow you to live
in a diverse and condensing world without shutting yourself up in little
private steel containers.

> > Oh, and thanks for the "fresh air", drivers.  Mighty kind of you.
> 
> Me, my suburban (15/18), and my '89 Dodge Spirit (20/30 while eating a
> quart of oil every 500 miles) say "You're welcome"  :-)

I'm not sure how a person can joke about their destructive habits, but I'm
the sort of person that thinks of criticism as an opportunity for
improvement.

> As Carla was saying, though, find me a vehicle that meets my needs and
> doesn't use so much gas - and I'd happily trade in.

First, I think you might have to re-evaluate your definition of "needs" if
you are truly concerned with adopting more sustainable practices in life.

Second, a private motor vehicle that uses less gas does almost nothing
progressive.  Decreasing emissions per trip sounds like a step in the
right direction, but it's a little like a person who is racing toward
Canada at 100mph and trying to get to Mexico by slowing to twenty.  
You're still going in the wrong direction.

> Money is definitely a concern, though, so it can't be too expensive.  

You have no idea how expensive your cars are.  First, your roads are
maintained through the wear and tear of hundreds of thousands of private
vehicle trips mostly through the state general fund.  Second, the cost of
your refined petroleum products is reduced drastically by pressures
exerted through the world's largest and most sophisticated terrorist
organization (I'm referring, of course, to the Pentagon system).  Third,
the very cost of your vehicle is subsidized through corporate welfare and
inhumane "trade" agreements.  And last but not least by far, the cost of
cleaning up the waste from your vehicle from production, through its
useful life and maintenance, to its final resting place are covered, once
again, by the public as a whole.  If you were presented with the ACTUAL
cost of exclusive use and operation of a motor vehicle, you'd probably
say, "I can't afford to drive", too.

J.

From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Dec  6 15:56:26 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 15:56:26 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG meeting
In-Reply-To: <1039197557.12971.11.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On 6 Dec 2002, AthlonRob wrote:
> On Fri, 2002-12-06 at 02:52, Josh Zeckser wrote:
> > Yeah, no kidding. I am a lot more scared of the people driving the cars
> > than I am of the people on the bus. People on the bus can't just
> > accidentally kill someone just by not paying attention.
> 
> You mean... except for the bus driver, right?

While admitting that there are bus drivers who don't always make the very
best decisions with regard to their behavior in traffic, I think it's very
important to point out that a bus driver is AT WORK behind the wheel.  
The driver is not rushing to get to work and (hopefully, of course)
concentrating on doing the job at hand with all the dilligence and care
that you or I would take to carry out the duties of our chosen profession.

The driver is not in a rush (the schedules are amply padded and
reasonable) and the route, including lane changes, is predetermined.

I think there are many reasons to believe that a bus driver is far less
likely to stop paying attention on a given trip than a personal vehicle
operator.

Hell, I was walking down the sidewalk a while back and a woman drove out
of a parking lot (on her daily commute, clearly) and nearly ran into me as
I crossed the lot's egress.  I shouted (mostly out of fear -- a fight or
flight response), "Watch it!"
She had her window down and laughed, saying, "I wasn't paying attention."  
She thought it was very amusing that she lost her concentration so
thoroughly.
I replied, in the most snide tone I could muster, "Heh heh!  That's really
funny.  It's not like you could kill someone with that or anything."

A second anecdote.
Whilst riding my bicycle a few weeks ago, a woman changed lanes without
signalling and nearly ran me off the road.  I caught up to her window at
the light and said, "You realize you could kill somebody with that
thing."
She was a middle-aged woman driving an SUV.  She looked pale at my comment
and said, "I sure hope not."
I said, "You're pushing a ton of steel around with that gas pedal.  Even
at low speed, that's more force than you need to squish a human being
flat."
She apologized and said she never thought of it that way.

Last Tuesday, I saw her staring out the window of the 70 bus on the same
route at about the same time of day.

J.

trucks and other petroleum-drinking vehicles.

Give me a viable and reasonable alternative and I will seriously consider
it.

And you're building up habits and tolerances that will allow you to live

> > Oh, and thanks for the "fresh air", drivers.  Mighty kind of you.

I'm not sure how a person can joke about their destructive habits, but I'm
the sort of person that thinks of criticism as an opportunity for
improvement.

> As Carla was saying, though, find me a vehicle that meets my needs and
> doesn't use so much gas - and I'd happily trade in.

First, I think you might have to re-evaluate your definition of "needs" if
you are truly concerned with adopting more sustainable practices in life.

Second, a private motor vehicle that uses less gas does almost nothing
progressive.  Decreasing emissions per trip sounds like a step in the
right direction, but it's a little like a person who is racing toward
Canada at 100mph and trying to get to Mexico by slowing to twenty.
You're still going in the wrong direction.

> Money is definitely a concern, though, so it can't be too expensive.

You have no idea how expensive your cars are.  First, your roads are
maintained through the wear and tear of hundreds of thousands of private
vehicle trips mostly through the state general fund.  Second, the cost of
your refined petroleum products is reduced drastically by pressures
exerted through the world's largest and most sophisticated terrorist
organization (I'm referring, of course, to the Pentagon system).  Third,
the very cost of your vehicle is subsidized through corporate welfare and
inhumane "trade" agreements.  And last but not least by far, the cost of
cleaning up the waste from your vehicle from production, through its
useful life and maintenance, to its final resting place are covered, once
again, by the public as a whole.  If you were presented with the ACTUAL
cost of exclusive use and operation of a motor vehicle, you'd probably
say, "I can't afford to drive", too.

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Dec  6 16:20:08 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 16:20:08 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Kernel removal
In-Reply-To: <1039217317.8903.79.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212061611550.6749-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 6 Dec 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> Thanks Rich & Steve. What think you of these methods, particularly the
> synaptic one?

Dirk,

  I've know nothing of synaptic. No comment.
 
> #1; Let me start with a disclaimer - I've only done this one time and not
> on a RH installation.  That said, make sure that the symlink
> /usr/src/linux points to the source files of the kernel you intend to
> keep.  Then, rm the tree of the source(s) you wish to discard.  Also, rm
> the related files in /boot - which is probably the partition that is
> squawking about inadequate space.
 
  This is the basic idea. I _always_ keep the kernel.org Web page open as I
go through the process because I'm not doing it every day.
 
> #2; I'm also running Red Hat 8.0 and have upgraded the kernels.  I did
> install synaptic and apt-get.  I used synaptic to select the older kernels
> to remove, and it passed the remove request to apt-get, which passed it to
> rpm.  It edited the grub config file for me too.

  I run apt-get but I don't let it "upgrade" the kernel. That's too
important to not have under your direct control at all times.

  The other option, which I did all of one time, is to get the Red Hat
kernel rpms for the new kernel. This is the simplest upgrade path, but you
get what you have because you do not go through menuconfig and set
everything yourself.

  The key to the package upgrade is to _install_ the new kernel, not
_upgrade_ or _freshen_ the existing one. When you run 'rpm -ivh
kernel-*.rpm' you install the new kernel in parallel with the existing one.
Then you copy the boot image into /boot, modify grub/lilo and pick the one
to boot. As with the other methods, when you're comfortable that the new
kernel is working properly you can remove the old one.

  FWIW, my /boot partition is 25M and I've not run out of room as long as I
build a bzImage.

Rich




From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Dec  6 16:23:59 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 16:23:59 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Kernel removal
In-Reply-To: <1039217561.8903.85.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212061621080.6749-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 6 Dec 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> The kernel packages are special in RedHat land in that you can remove them
> by full name.  Normally rpm won't accept something like
> 
> # rpm -e some_package-2.12.14
> 
> instead, you would have to do
> 
> # rpm some_package

  Not quite. When you install a package you'd type something like:

rpm -ivh opera-6.11-20021129.3-shared-qt.i386.rpm

  But, when you want to remove that package, you'd type:

rpm -e opera-6.11-20021129.3

  You do need to specify the version, but not the entire string.

Rich

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Dec  6 17:26:59 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 17:26:59 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Easiest way to get printing going (ideally on Debian)?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0212061710020.23580-100000@tpol.peak.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212061721420.6749-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On Fri, 6 Dec 2002, Eric House wrote:

> Unlike me, she needs to print.  And I've never set up printing from
> Linux before.  Specifically, she needs to do formatted wordprocessing
> and print the results in such a way that they look "professional",
> i.e. as if they'd been done in Word.

  Take a look at LyX. It's not a word processor but a gui front end to the
TeX typesetting system. No word processor produces printed output that looks
"professional"; LyX produces typeset output that _is_ professional. To
print from LyX one uses lpr to print postscript or pdf files. You can also
get html output.
 
  On the other foot, if she needs to import and export winWord docs as well
as turning in printed products then I strongly recommend either
OpenOffice-1.0.1 or AbiWord-1.0.3. The former is easier to use with a wide
range of fonts; the latter is smaller and faster.

  As far as I know, both use lpr to print their postscript output. Several
years ago I replaced lpr with CUPS, but the output string in all three
applications is 'lpr -Plaser5_ps', or whatever printer definition I want to
use.

  Take a look at /etc/printcap (and the man page).

HTH,

Rich

To me, 50 minutes on a train or bus is 50 minutes I get to read, relax and
watch the scenery roll by as I listen to my headphones. Spending that same

for an hour a day on the bus, that's 1 less hour I need to have at home to
get the reading and relaxing I need squeezed into my day. For my part, I
replace that time with time exercising. Not a bad trade-off in my book.
You just can't see it from my perspective, I guess, but to me riding the
train, reading a book is actually MORE efficient. I'm making better use of
my time.

Kinda hard to help with information this scant...

    * What changed since htaccess was working?
      - Apache upgrade?
      - httpd.conf mucking?
    * What are the perms of the .htaccess files?
    * What are the perms of the directories in which they reside?
    * Give an example of one that isn't working and anything in httpd.conf
      that relates to the directory for that .htaccess file
    * Where in httpd.conf have you set AccessFileName? i.e., is it global or
      bounded by <Directory></Directory>?
    * You mentioned Front Page (scary). Are you sure httpd.conf doesn't have
      DOS line termination?
    * What's the result of `service httpd configtest'?
    * What version of Apache are you running?
    * What linux distro? Kernel version?

cheers,
Sandy

From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Fri Dec  6 21:48:13 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: 06 Dec 2002 21:48:13 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] File Sharing
In-Reply-To: <1039238990.1714.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1039238990.1714.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1039240093.13347.18.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Fri, 2002-12-06 at 21:29, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> I have a pretty good understanding of sharing files between a linux and
> windows machine, but what I have not been able to find out on the
> internet is how to share files between two linux machines.  Does anyone
> have any recomendations on accomplishing this?  I'd like to set
> something up that I can use nautilus or some other gui interface.  I
> tried using Samba but get an error stating "Could not display smb:
> because no host("null") could be found.

SMB usually works well... if browsing it via smb:// doesn't work (if
you're using slackware and konqueror, Pat just added support in
-current) then you can also mount the shares via smbmount.

Another option, which is less secure, is NFS.

You should be able to find walk-throughs and all sorts of information
about SMB and NFS via google.  It is your friend.  :-)

2 is totaly independent of anything else you choose, and should work for
all printing situations.  There are two options, one is LPR, which I
have NO clue how to do, I belive it's an old Berkley thing.  The one

drivers installed if need be.  It has a nice web interface for setting
up printers.  Go to http://www.cups.org for information on installing,
though if I remember on debian it's just an apt-get install cups and
cups-gimpprint (or something like that).





From jeme at brelin.net  Fri Dec  6 22:11:35 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)

Subject: [PLUG] Free time wasted costs what?

This isn't difficult arithmetic, Russ.

On Fri, 6 Dec 2002, Russ Johnson wrote:
> However, that doesn't change the fact that my travel time is WAY up
> when compared to driving. Nearly double. Jeme says 23 minutes (or
> something like that).

I wrote 21 minutes because you wrote that the public transit commute was
53 minutes and the private vehicle commute was 32 minutes.  I just
subtracted.

And to say that it's "nearly double" is to give a margin of error greater
than 50%.  In order to be double, the difference would be 32 minutes.  
The actual difference is 21 minutes.  You're 11 minutes shy of doubling.  
And 11 is more than 50% of 21.

> Well, that's nearly 50% of 53 minutes.

Actually, 21 minutes is less than 40% of 53 minutes.

> When we're talking an hour, 23 minutes is close enough to 50%.

21 minutes (and even 23!) is much closer to a third of an hour than half.

But we're not even talking about an hour.  That would be to overestimate
by greater than 10%.  And calling 21 minutes 50% of an hour is an error of
more than 40%.

You don't build bridges, I hope.

J.

From revans at e-z.net  Fri Dec  6 22:39:40 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Fri,  6 Dec 2002 22:39:40 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] File Sharing
In-Reply-To: <1039238990.1714.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1039238990.1714.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <E18KZ43-0000Gs-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

Most Linux Distributions come with Openssh. Some also come with gftp. If you
make sure that sftp-server is in the path sshd was compiled with, this is not
the regular path, you can use these in a very secure way to move files around.
This is the path documented in the sshd_config that came with my distribution;
PATH=/usr/bin:/bin:/usr/sbin:/sbin.  The default location for sftp-server in my
distribution was /usr/lib/ssh/sftp-server. I simply copied this file into
/usr/bin and restarted sshd and was able to move files around. I'm not sure if
restarting was necessary.

The older Openssh versions used a separate sftpd and ssh1. The issues with the
older Openssh and with ssh1 not being secure mean that you probably need
upgrade if you're still using it.

If your distribution comes with gftp, I would suggest getting the latest
version as large file support is now available and it definitely uses ssh2.  
This bit me once. I was transferring 4G files and they were truncated at 2.1G.
This was a gftp issue not a file system issue. http://gftp.seul.org/

Thank you
Russell

Robbert,

I've been using Samba for the last several months to network between my
Linux and Windows machines, as well as between my Linux and Linux
boxes. It works fine.

I just recently started playing with NFS, which is actually much
simpler and easier to set up. It has some security issues, but if
you're on a trusted network, then it shouldn't be a major problem. The
problem, as I understand it, arises when a user is logged in as root on
one machine, then logs into the other machine where he's not supposed
to have root access. Like I said, I'm kinda new at it, but I found it
very easy to set up and use.

When I get something like NFS working, I take some simple notes so I'll
be able to do it again more easily next time. If you want, I can email
you my notes on setting NFS (about one page). I just don't want to send
it to the list in general, and interfere with all the people debating
politics, mass transit, and fuel economy. :)

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Sat Dec  7 05:19:44 2002
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (mmartin at u.washington.edu)
Date: Sat, 7 Dec 2002 07:19:44 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] RPM controlled? (Re: Removing previous kernels)
In-Reply-To: <3DF12167.1050507@pacifier.com>
References: <16654-87684@sneakemail.com> <3DF12167.1050507@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <200212062033.31784.mmartin@amath.washington.edu>

Using -U has the same result as using -i except that it overwrites files from 
the old package.  Kernels are installed into /boot with names that specify 
the kernel version and therefore won't overwrite the older kernels.

By the way, Mandrake doesn't "override" any RPM "safeties" when you install 
multiple kernel versions using RPM.  It allows multiple kernel versions to 
coexist without difficulty (but I suspect that Red Hat does too).

If you installed a kernel using RPM, you should remove it using RPM too.  You 
should be able to safely do this using the longer name for the package as 
Kyle suggested.  Otherwise, if you manually remove the kernel, the removed 
kernel package will remain in the RPM database and cause confusion later, 
unless you make sure that you have removed all of the files corresponding to 
the package and manually remove the corresponding entry from the RPM 
database.

Mark

You only need to specify enough to uniquely identify the package.  A complete 
file name will never work because the entry in the RPM database is the 
package name (including version number), not the file name.

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Sat Dec  7 05:20:29 2002
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Sat, 7 Dec 2002 07:20:29 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Kernel removal
In-Reply-To: <1039217317.8903.79.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1039217317.8903.79.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <200212062113.51491.mmartin@amath.washington.edu>

You guys are making this WAY too complicated.  When you install a new kernel 
package on an RPM-based system (assuming that you're using lilo),

1. Install the corresponding kernel package(s) using the -i flag.  (-U is 
superfluous but generally harmless.)

2. Look at /etc/lilo.conf to make sure that the new kernel has a stanza in the 
file.  If not, add one.  If this is necessary, it is easily done by copying 
one of the old stanzas and making appropriate modifications.  Most recent 
kernel RPM packages will add appropriate stanzas to /etc/lilo.conf for you.

3. Run lilo.  Make sure that the name that you (or the kernel package) gave 
the new kernel appears in the lilo output.  If not or if lilo complains, then 
there is a mistake in /etc/lilo.conf.  Fix any mistakes and rerun lilo.

4. Reboot and select the new kernel in the lilo boot screen to test it.

5. If the system comes up without difficulty, you'll probably want to make the 
new kernel the default kernel (if the RPM package hasn't already done this 
for you).  If so and if necessary, edit the entry in /etc/lilo.conf to make 
the corresponding stanza the default stanza and/or change the symlinks 
/boot/vmlinuz, /boot/System.map, /boot/initrd.img, /boot/config to point to 
the files corresponding to the new kernel.  Then rerun lilo.  If necessary, 
fix any mistakes in lilo.conf and rerun lilo until it runs successfully.

6. If you want to remove the old kernel, use RPM with the -e flag and a long 
enough version of the old kernel package name to distiguish it from any other 
installed kernel package names.

Using grub rather than lilo is even easier since you only have to add an entry 
corresponding to the new kernel to /boot/menu.lst rather than having to run a 
program every time you change the configuration file.

Even if you completely obliterate your kernel package, it isn't the end of the 
world.  You can always boot from a floppy or installation CD and reinstall 
the kernel package using the RPM binary that is on your hard drive via the 
chroot command.  You might notice that this means that it's a good idea to 
have a floppy or CD lying around when doing any serious fooling around with 
your system.

I hope that this dispells at least some of the confusion.

Mark

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Sat Dec  7 09:01:41 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Sat, 7 Dec 2002 09:01:41 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] File Sharing
In-Reply-To: <1039238990.1714.5.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212070855150.9785-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

On 6 Dec 2002, Robbert van Andel wrote:

> I have a pretty good understanding of sharing files between a linux and
> windows machine, but what I have not been able to find out on the
> internet is how to share files between two linux machines.  Does anyone
> have any recomendations on accomplishing this?  I'd like to set
> something up that I can use nautilus or some other gui interface.  I
> tried using Samba but get an error stating "Could not display smb:
> because no host("null") could be found.

  You can do this with samba, but I'm not the one to tell you how. However,
remember that linux is capable of both client-server and peer-to-peer
networking.

  For the latter I use nfs. On the machine with directories or files you
want to share/use/whatever on other hosts, edit /etc/exports to make those
directories available. For example, on one of my machines I have:

[rshepard at caddis ~]$ less /etc/exports 
/usr2   192.168.55.0/24(rw,no_root_squash)
/usr3   192.168.55.0/24(rw,no_root_squash)
/usr4   192.168.55.0/24(rw,no_root_squash)

  On another machine the /etc/fstab file has these entries:

caddis:/usr2            /mnt/usr2       nfs     rw,rsize=8192,wsize=8192 0 0
caddis:/usr3            /mnt/usr3       nfs     rw,rsize=8192,wsize=8192 0 0
caddis:/usr4            /mnt/usr4       nfs     rw,rsize=8192,wsize=8192 0 0

  Now I can access any directory or file on /mnt/usrX from the local
machine.

  For executables, it works the same way. Here, /home is exported from the
server/workstation so that's the directory used regardless of the host on
which we log in. I don't know how good nautilis is at working across the
network, but I put a copy of sylpheed and mozilla on each host.

HTH,

Rich

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Dec  7 11:22:32 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)

Subject: [PLUG] NFS Illustrated
In-Reply-To: <20021207092308.59343.qmail@web10411.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021207092308.59343.qmail@web10411.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1039288951.30115.70.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

I highly recommend "NFS Illustrated", which you will find at Powell's
Technical Bookstore, to anyone who wants to know the nitty gritty
details about how NFS works.  Knowing the protocol and packet exchange
timeline is very useful when it comes to troubleshooting NFS setup
problems.  At least once since I've read it, I've grabbed it off the
shelf to check a packet exchange timeline diagram, to see which end of
the connection the problem was at.  I was able to fix the broken NFS in
less than 5 minutes, where before I read that book, it would have taken
10 or 15 minutes of trial and error guesswork.

Here's a BibTeX entry for you TeXknowphiles:

@Book{callaghan00:_nfs_illus,
  author =	 {Brent Callaghan},
  title = 	 {NFS Illustrated},
  publisher = 	 {Addison Wesley},
  year = 	 2000,
  series =	 {professional computing series},
  ISBN =	 {0-201-32570-5}
}

From mmartin at amath.washington.edu  Fri Dec  6 19:13:51 2002
From: mmartin at amath.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 21:13:51 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Kernel removal
In-Reply-To: <1039217317.8903.79.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1039217317.8903.79.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <200212062113.51491.mmartin@amath.washington.edu>

You guys are making this WAY too complicated.  When you install a new kernel 
package on an RPM-based system (assuming that you're using lilo),

1. Install the corresponding kernel package(s) using the -i flag.  (-U is 
superfluous but generally harmless.)

2. Look at /etc/lilo.conf to make sure that the new kernel has a stanza in the 
file.  If not, add one.  If this is necessary, it is easily done by copying 
one of the old stanzas and making appropriate modifications.  Most recent 
kernel RPM packages will add appropriate stanzas to /etc/lilo.conf for you.

3. Run lilo.  Make sure that the name that you (or the kernel package) gave 
the new kernel appears in the lilo output.  If not or if lilo complains, then 
there is a mistake in /etc/lilo.conf.  Fix any mistakes and rerun lilo.

4. Reboot and select the new kernel in the lilo boot screen to test it.

5. If the system comes up without difficulty, you'll probably want to make the 
new kernel the default kernel (if the RPM package hasn't already done this 
for you).  If so and if necessary, edit the entry in /etc/lilo.conf to make 
the corresponding stanza the default stanza and/or change the symlinks 
/boot/vmlinuz, /boot/System.map, /boot/initrd.img, /boot/config to point to 
the files corresponding to the new kernel.  Then rerun lilo.  If necessary, 
fix any mistakes in lilo.conf and rerun lilo until it runs successfully.

6. If you want to remove the old kernel, use RPM with the -e flag and a long 
enough version of the old kernel package name to distiguish it from any other 
installed kernel package names.

Using grub rather than lilo is even easier since you only have to add an entry 
corresponding to the new kernel to /boot/menu.lst rather than having to run a 
program every time you change the configuration file.

Even if you completely obliterate your kernel package, it isn't the end of the 
world.  You can always boot from a floppy or installation CD and reinstall 
the kernel package using the RPM binary that is on your hard drive via the 
chroot command.  You might notice that this means that it's a good idea to 
have a floppy or CD lying around when doing any serious fooling around with 
your system.

I hope that this dispells at least some of the confusion.

Mark

From mmartin at amath.washington.edu  Fri Dec  6 18:33:31 2002
From: mmartin at amath.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Fri, 6 Dec 2002 20:33:31 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] RPM controlled? (Re: Removing previous kernels)
In-Reply-To: <3DF12167.1050507@pacifier.com>
References: <16654-87684@sneakemail.com> <3DF12167.1050507@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <200212062033.31784.mmartin@amath.washington.edu>

Using -U has the same result as using -i except that it overwrites files from 
the old package.  Kernels are installed into /boot with names that specify 
the kernel version and therefore won't overwrite the older kernels.

By the way, Mandrake doesn't "override" any RPM "safeties" when you install 
multiple kernel versions using RPM.  It allows multiple kernel versions to 
coexist without difficulty (but I suspect that Red Hat does too).

If you installed a kernel using RPM, you should remove it using RPM too.  You 
should be able to safely do this using the longer name for the package as 
Kyle suggested.  Otherwise, if you manually remove the kernel, the removed 
kernel package will remain in the RPM database and cause confusion later, 
unless you make sure that you have removed all of the files corresponding to 
the package and manually remove the corresponding entry from the RPM 
database.

Mark

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Dec  7 12:15:57 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 07 Dec 2002 12:15:57 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Package name and version conventions
In-Reply-To: <1039217317.8903.79.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1039217317.8903.79.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1039292156.30118.94.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

I don't know how Red Hat does it, or how RPM expects the names to work,
but I do know the Debian + dpkg way.

The file name of a deb package relates directly to the package name and
version number.  These are specified by the Debian Policy Manual:

 http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/debian-policy/policy.html/

The package name must be at least two characters long, and start with a
letter.  It must be lower case letters, numbers, plus ".-" only.  In the
.deb file name, the version number is separated from the package name by
an "_" character.  Inside the .deb, it's stored in a separate field of
the "control" file.

So, to find the package name and version, you split on the "_"
character.  When a package name has a version number of some kind in it,
that's a good indication that it's possible to install more than one
version of that software at a time.  The package will be set up so that
it installs in a disjoint set of locations to the other versions.  This
is mostly for kernels, kernel modules, and shared libraries.

The version number part has two fields also, separated by a "-"
character. (Recall that the version number part is to the right of the
"_" and to the left of the ".ARCH.deb" part.)  The first part of a
version number is the upstream version.  The second part is the Debian
build or release number.  Often there is a need to rebuild and
re-release the same upstream release, to correct problems, make
improvements, or build against newer shared libraries.

Inside the .deb, in the "control" file, the source of the meta data read
by the "apt" system, often the "Version:" will contain an epoch number
also.  An epoch is a number prefix separated from the rest of the
version string by a ":".  This is used when the upstream numbering
system has changed in such a way that what is really a newer version
appears to the .deb version sorting code to be an older release.  In
that case, the maintainer will tack on an epoch number to make it sort
as a newer release.  Epoch's are explained in the Debian Policy Manual,
and in the packaging manuals.

I imagine that the policy and packaging manuals for Debian are worth
reading even if you don't use Debian and only create RPM packages.  The
general guidelines likely apply.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Dec  7 12:23:27 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 07 Dec 2002 12:23:27 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Kernel removal
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212061611550.6749-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212061611550.6749-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1039292606.30118.102.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Fri, 2002-12-06 at 16:20, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   I run apt-get but I don't let it "upgrade" the kernel. That's too
> important to not have under your direct control at all times.

If you do use "apt-get" to upgrade or install a kernel, don't blame
"apt" if that fails, since it's not in control of what might go wrong --
that's a function of the particular package being installed or
upgraded.  Apt organizes the list of packages in dependancy order, and
computes the list of "dpkg" or "rpm" commands to run.

Inside each .rpm (?) or .deb are "maintainer scripts" that run at
particular points during the installation.  Also inside there is an
archive containing the actual files to be installed.  The archive
determines where they go, and the scripts determine what setup steps are
done before and after the install, and before and after the removal of a
software package.

It's likely the post install script that is responsible for listing the
new kernel with Grub or Lilo, for instance.  And it's the layout of the
file archive that determines whether or not that package will clash with
files already installed on your computer.  When that clash is expected,
the package's control data must declare that, or the package manager
should halt with an error.  There is not any way it can detect whether a
maintainer script is in error, however, unless that script exits with an
error code.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Dec  7 12:34:41 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 07 Dec 2002 12:34:41 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RPM controlled? (Re: Removing previous kernels)
In-Reply-To: <200212062033.31784.mmartin@amath.washington.edu>
References: <16654-87684@sneakemail.com> <3DF12167.1050507@pacifier.com>
	 <200212062033.31784.mmartin@amath.washington.edu>
Message-ID: <1039293281.30115.113.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Fri, 2002-12-06 at 18:33, Mark Martin wrote:
> Using -U has the same result as using -i except that it overwrites files from 
> the old package.  Kernels are installed into /boot with names that specify 
> the kernel version and therefore won't overwrite the older kernels.

Debian's "dpkg" does not have a separate "upgrade" and "install"
concept.  When you install something for which a version is already
there, it "simply" performs an upgrade.

> By the way, Mandrake doesn't "override" any RPM "safeties" when you install 
> multiple kernel versions using RPM.  It allows multiple kernel versions to 
> coexist without difficulty (but I suspect that Red Hat does too).

This is not a function of RPM, but rather a function of how that
software has been packaged.  The archives inside of the two RPM's must
contain disjoint file sets for this to work, and the RPM's names must be
different.  Probably the upsream kernel version and perhaps some build
configuration information are encoded in it's package name.  (eg:
kernel-image-2.4.18-smp-i686)

If that is not the case, that the kernel package's name is different
from that of other kernel packages, then I think it's a broken design. 
If that "longer name" to rpm you tell of means adding the package
version number to the package name, then it's a broken design.  If what
it does is allow a unique prefix to mean a fully written package name,
then "alright", that's ok... the kernel packages must have that upstream
version information encoded in them like I say above.

With "dpkg", if two separate packages contain non disjoint file sets, or
subsets of their file sets are not disjoint, the newer package is
required to "Conflict" with the older one, and may optionally "Replace"
it.  Does RPM have this?

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0212071308170.24118-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

This has nothing to do with the kernel or its configuration.
I've modified the subject line appropriately.

On Sat, 7 Dec 2002, Rich Shepard wrote:
>   Only nfs-mounted partitions from remote hosts are backed up on the
> server -- the box with the tape drive and BRU. Is the lack of a
> complete backup of the other workstation something that needs to be
> addressed?

I personally don't see why you'd care to back up pre-compiled binaries
that are always available for download or that you already have on
CD.  Restoration time isn't that much greater than re-installation time if
you just accept default options and then restore your settings from
backup.

If you backup /etc and /home and a few bits from /var (and whatever other
little smattering of configuration data you might keep elsewhere), that
should cover you.  A cleverly written tar command line could pack it up
appropriately so that a fresh install can turn into your particular server
with a tape and a single command run from /.

For configuration files, though, you might consider keeping them in a CVS
repository and using Makefiles to control their checkout and placement in
a virgin filesystem.  That way, you could install a new system, check your
config files out of CVS and do "make mail" to rebuild your mail server or
"make rich-desktop" to rebuild your desktop host and so on.  You keep
single copies of the config files that do not vary from host to host.  It
might also be interesting to check in the default configuration files and
simply cut branches in the CVS tree for each host or host type.

J.

     Jeme A Brelin
    jeme at brelin.net

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Sat Dec  7 14:45:50 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 07 Dec 2002 14:45:50 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] pdxlinu.org login, mail, and web site accounts
In-Reply-To: <32228.63.164.145.161.1039300535.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
References: <20021207092308.59343.qmail@web10411.mail.yahoo.com>
	 <1039289125.30119.73.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <32228.63.164.145.161.1039300535.squirrel@mail.robbyrussell.com>
Message-ID: <1039301150.30115.183.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Sat, 2002-12-07 at 14:35, Robby Russell wrote:
> How can I go about getting an account?

Send me your user name, full name, daytime phone number, and SSH 2
"id_dsa.pub", and I'll create an account for you.

After you log in the first time, do:

% echo '<password>" > ~karlheg/DropBox/<userid>
% chmod go-rw ~karlheg/DropBox/<userid>

... where <password> is your IMAP password, and <userid> is your login
user ID.  I will erase it right after I set your IMAP password.

That password will work with IMAP over SSL on port 993, IMAP with TLS on
port 143, and with Squirrelmail at https://mail.pdxlinux.org/. 
Alternativly, you may use a .forward file, which you must create after
you log in.  You will have <userid>@pdxlinux.org for email then.  (You
won't need the Yahoo anymore, unless you want to separate "business"
(plug) from personal mail.)  Please be sure to check the mail
regularly.  There are no quotas, but please be neiborly.

You can use scp or gFTP and SSH2 to copy your web stuff over to your
~/public_html, or you may run XEmacs on drizzle.pdxlinux.org once you
log in.

Be aware that it's a Celeron 400 something, and not super fast.

Hi all!

I recently installed SMB on my machine and it appears as though my conf is
not behaving properly. I have pasted it below to see what you all have to

http://www.opensource.apple.com/projects/documentation/howto/html/osxsmb.htm
l

I used a combination of that file and what prefs I already had set up in the
Samba Sharing package I got from sourceforge to create the file below.
However, my wintendo still can't work it out. Can anyone tell me what's
wrong with what I have in the .conf file? I'd appreciate it.

-Kelly

#
# *********************************************************************
# **                       /etc/samba/smb.conf                       **
# *********************************************************************
# **                                                                 **
# **  Configuration file for Samba SMB server                        **
# **                                                                 **
# **                                                                 **
# *********************************************************************
#

# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
#  Global configuration options
# ---------------------------------------------------------------------
[global]
        # basic options
        netbios name            = ENID
        workgroup               = DEPECHE
        server string           = Samba %v

        # misc options
        hide dot files          = yes

        # logging options
        log level               = 2
        log file                = /var/log/samba-%m.log
        max log size            = 512
        debug timestamp         = yes
        syslog                  = 1


# --------------------------------------------------------------------
#  Home share configuration
# --------------------------------------------------------------------
[homes]
        comment                 = "Home directory for %u on %L"
        path                    = /Users/%u
        browseable              = no
        guest ok                = no
        read only               = no
        create mask             = 644
        directory mask          = 755


# --------------------------------------------------------------------
#  BoxSet MP3s share config
# --------------------------------------------------------------------
[BoxSet]
        comment                 = "Main MP3 Share"
        path                    = /Volumes/BoxSet/
        browseable              = yes
        guest ok                = no
        read only               = no
        create mask             = 777
        directory mask          = 777

# --------------------------------------------------------------------
#  Yoko share configuration
# --------------------------------------------------------------------
[YokoMP3s]
        comment                 = "Secondary MP3s"
        path                    = /Volumes/Yoko
        browseable              = yes
        guest ok                = no
        read only               = no
        create mask             = 777
        directory mask          = 777

# --------------------------------------------------------------------
#  /Users/Shared config
# --------------------------------------------------------------------
[Shared]
        comment                 = "Users-Shared"
        path                    = /Users/Shared
        browseable              = yes
        guest ok                = no
        read only               = no
        create mask             = 777
        directory mask          = 777





From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Sat Dec  7 15:46:01 2002
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Sat, 7 Dec 2002 17:46:01 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] RPM controlled? (Re: Removing previous kernels)
In-Reply-To: <1039293281.30115.113.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
References: <16654-87684@sneakemail.com> <200212062033.31784.mmartin@amath.washington.edu> <1039293281.30115.113.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <200212071746.01057.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

With RPM, using your words, Karl, a unique prefix is allowed to represent the 
full package name, as it was with commands in VMS.  However, packages names 
have distinct parts, one of which is the version number.

RPM refuses to install packages that conflict with other packages unless 
explicitly instructed to ignore the conflicts.  Newer versions of the same 
package will replace the old package if installed with the "-U" flag or a 
package that conflicts with a completely different package can be forcibly 
installed using the "--force" directive.  Have I answered your question or 
just danced around it?

On Saturday 07 December 2002 14:34, Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> If that is not the case, that the kernel package's name is different
> from that of other kernel packages, then I think it's a broken design.
> If that "longer name" to rpm you tell of means adding the package
> version number to the package name, then it's a broken design.  If what
> it does is allow a unique prefix to mean a fully written package name,
> then "alright", that's ok... the kernel packages must have that upstream
> version information encoded in them like I say above.
>
> With "dpkg", if two separate packages contain non disjoint file sets, or
> subsets of their file sets are not disjoint, the newer package is
> required to "Conflict" with the older one, and may optionally "Replace"
> it.  Does RPM have this?

Actually I think it's LPD ( line printer daemon). Another "old Berkeley thing" would be TCP/IP ;)

My printcap points to a remote print spool (more complicated?) and it is still just 2 lines long.

lexmark|lp|lexmark optra color 40:\
        :lp=:sh:rm=printslave:rp=AUTO:sd=/var/spool/lpd/lexmark

Granted if you don't have a postscript printer you have some extra hoops to jump through, but it's not that tough.

  Let me begin by thanking all of you who suggested that the screwy display
on my workstation, "caddis", due to the video card going to the Great Bit
Bucket. I just put in a replacement card (ATI Xpert 2000 32M SDRAM AGP) and
the display is back where it used to be. At least the card died a quick
death and didn't suffer too long. I did, but that's a different story. :-)

  Which brings me to my two questions.

  1) This is a Red Hat 7.3 box running the 2.4.19 kernel and XFree86-4.0.2.
When I rebooted the box, kudzu recognized that the 3D Labs Permedia was
removed and the ATI Xpert 2000 inserted in its place. "Cool!", thought I,
"that's easier than hand-tweaking the files as in days of yore." Except, ...

  When I tried to startx, the server crashed and burned because it could not
find the screen section. Well, I edited /etc/X11/XF86config-4 and replaced
the two references to 3D Labs with references to ATI Xpert. Now it works
just fine. So, why didn't kudzu change /etc/X11/XF86config-4 when it
recognized that the hardware had changed?

  I'm sure there's a rational explanation and I'd like to be clued in to it.

  The editing of the config file is the reason for my second question.

  2)  I was initially logged in as a user and I wanted to switch to another
console to log in as root. This would let me work on one console and test on
another. For as long as I've run linux I could switch to a different console
with alt-Fn. Except today. No way I could open a second console!
"Golleeeey," I said to myself, "sumptin' ain't copasetic here-bouts."

  What might be mis-configured that would prevent me from switching
consoles?

TIA,

Rich

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sat Dec  7 19:13:39 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sat, 7 Dec 2002 19:13:39 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Switching consoles & video card
In-Reply-To: <3DF2B717.6090500@pacifier.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212071806180.12582-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <3DF2B717.6090500@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <200212071913.39713.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Saturday 07 December 2002 19:05, Kyle Accardi wrote:

>
> > console to log in as root. This would let me work on one console and test
> > on another. For as long as I've run linux I could switch to a different
> > console with alt-Fn. Except today. No way I could open a second console!
> > "Golleeeey," I said to myself, "sumptin' ain't copasetic here-bouts."
> >
> >   What might be mis-configured that would prevent me from switching
> > consoles?
>
> I've always used ctrl-atl-Fn.  I notice in the sawfish window manager (at
> least) alt-fn changes workspaces.

Depends where you do this from. Ctrl+alt+fn takes you out of an X session to a 
console. Then you switch between consoles with Alt+fn. alt+f7 to get back to 
X. If you have two separate X sessions going, as two different users, 
Ctrl+alt+f7/f8 to switch back and forth.

/etc/inittab controls the default number of consoles, look for these lines:

# Run gettys in standard runlevels
1:2345:respawn:/sbin/mingetty tty1
2:2345:respawn:/sbin/mingetty tty2
3:2345:respawn:/sbin/mingetty tty3
4:2345:respawn:/sbin/mingetty tty4
5:2345:respawn:/sbin/mingetty tty5
6:2345:respawn:/sbin/mingetty tty6

This is the usual default. If these are missing, or goofed up, it could be 
related. But something has to go way out of its way to change inittab.
--

Bratgrrl Computing
www.bratgrrl.com

From bsr at spek.org  Sat Dec  7 23:53:42 2002

Subject: [PLUG] flickering monitor advice?
Message-ID: <1039334021.3308.29303.camel@obelisk.spek.org>

Hello,
  This isn't a Linux-specific related question, but I hope a few people
here might have some insight or advice.

  I recently moved my home office setup to a different side of the room
as well as removed a few of the power strips I had in my Rube Golberg 
extension cord.  Everything works great except that the image both of my
monitors now flickers and shakes whenever the coffee pot heater kicks on
(I believe anyway, it's hard to tell since it's across the room and it's
pretty quiet).  Neither the coffee pot or computer monitors have changed
power circuits (both are on different breakers), only their relative
orientations and number of power strips inline has changed.

  The coffee pot is a pretty simple affair, no motors, no moving parts
(that are electrically actuated) AFAIK, just a clock to turn it on at
specific times and a thermostatically controlled hot plate.

  I'm guessing it's a power filtering issue as several of the power
strips I had inline before were of the filtering kind, and now they're
gone - but there still is one filtering power strip and two filtering
UPSes that the power has to go through to get to a monitor.  

Does this sound reasonable, or am I wasting my time looking into finding
some kind of serious power filtering device?  

thanks,
--Brent

> gone - but there still is one filtering power strip and two filtering
> UPSes that the power has to go through to get to a monitor.  
> 
> Does this sound reasonable, or am I wasting my time looking into finding
> some kind of serious power filtering device?  

First, I'd check the voltage at the power strips.  Make sure it is at least 
115.  Also make sure that hot and neutral aren't reversed at either the 
coffee pot or computer wall outlets.

While it's true that the surge suppressors (MOVs) in the strips and UPS will 
wear out, the filter should not.  Is it possible to unplug the coffee pot 
long enough to determine if it is the source of the interferance?

--
Kyle Accardi






From barryb at proaxis.com  Sun Dec  8 01:18:44 2002
From: barryb at proaxis.com (Bill Barry)
Date: Sun, 8 Dec 2002 01:18:44 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] flickering monitor advice?
In-Reply-To: <1039334021.3308.29303.camel@obelisk.spek.org>; from bsr@spek.org on Sat, Dec 07, 2002 at 11:53:42PM -0800
References: <1039334021.3308.29303.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <20021208011844.A23315@feynman>

Do you have the monitor and computer plugged into the
same power strip? If not, try that. Sometimes if they
are plugged into different places that have different
paths to ground you can greatly increase the noise
pickup. For instance you may have the computer plugged
into a ups and the monitor not plugged into the same ups.
This can sometimes be a problem.

There is a discussion of this problem here
http://documents.epanorama.net/documents/groundloop/basics.html

Bill

From judah at opusnet.com  Sun Dec  8 11:16:04 2002
From: judah at opusnet.com (Aaron Baer)
Date: 08 Dec 2002 11:16:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] How to remove old kernels
In-Reply-To: <1039368872.3693.12.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1039368872.3693.12.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1039374964.10551.18.camel@localhost.localdomain>

Yes.. that would be fine.. use the rpm -e command and the kernel you
wish to remove. Grub should not be effected at all (it will know that
you've removed the other kernels) and there is no need to reboot once
you've removed the older kernels.

example

rpm -e kernel-2.4.18-18.7.0

A-

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Dec  8 13:43:54 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 8 Dec 2002 13:43:54 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Easiest way to get printing going (ideally on Debian)?
In-Reply-To: <200212080740.28385.mmartin@u.washington.edu>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212061721420.6749-100000@appl-ecosys.com> <1039330351.30119.212.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net> <200212080740.28385.mmartin@u.washington.edu>
Message-ID: <200212081343.54301.aschlemm@attbi.com>

CUPS is pretty nice although I had to remove from my workstation and go 
back to using LPRng instead. The one feature that seems to cause some 
problems is that one of the remote printers I need to use is on a 
remote BSD system running "apsfilter". Every time I send a print job 
via CUPS to the remote printer there's an extra large margin at the top 
of every page and there's always an extra blank page associated with 
every print job.

CUPS worked great with my locally connected inkjet. The one feature that 
I wish CUPS supported was a simple non-filtered forwarding only queue 
like what the old-style BSD "lpd" and LPRng support. Without any local 
filtering my remote print jobs come out great. Again this may be some 
sort of problem with apsfilter I don't know but it only happens if CUPS 
does any sort of local filtering first. My own reasoning is that is 
sort of silly to do any sort of filtering of Postscript data when a 
program generates Postscript data by default and the printer the data 
is going to already handles Postscript data albeit by using 
"apsfilter".

"apsfilter" does smart filtering of the printer data and it figures out 
what filter to apply based upon the print data it receives. The remote 
printer is a PCL-only HP laserjet. I get good printer output whether I 
send Postscript data from Linux boxes or native printer data from 
Windows boxes. I just don't know what sort of mess CUPS is making when 
it filters the Postscript generated printer data locally before 
forwarding it to a remote printer. Whatever Postscript data it sends 
Ghostscript doesn't seem to handle it as well the raw Postscript data 
that all of my KDE programs generate when I print something.

I admit to staying away from any custom CUPS setup and use SuSE's YaST2 
program to configure CUPS which might be some of my problems. SuSE 
allows LPRng or CUPS to be used but they are mutually exclusive so if 
CUPS is chosen LPRng is automatically uninstalled as it CUPS if LPRng 
is chosen. With all of the SuSE's configuration stuff spread out across 
multiple files in /etc/sysconfig I figure I'll have an easier time 
upgrading if I use YaST2 as much as possible. So for now I'm using 
LPRng on my primary workstation and I use CUPS on some standalong boxes 
that have a locally connected printer.

Tony

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Sun Dec  8 13:21:47 2002
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Sun, 8 Dec 2002 15:21:47 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] trying to debug program  --  no core file
In-Reply-To: <1039380603.1147.3.camel@enlightenment>
References: <1039377172.1089.1.camel@enlightenment> <200212081344.56368.mmartin@u.washington.edu> <1039380603.1147.3.camel@enlightenment>
Message-ID: <200212081521.47739.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

Yeah, I know.  It's especially helpful if a run takes a long time.

Okay, I'll at least give you some information related to your original 
question.  What I have to say pertains to C/C++ and I can't vouch for how 
much will apply to other languages.  The behavior of a program when there's a 
segfault depends on the signal handler assigned to the SIGSEGV signal.  If 
the program doesn't define a handler for the signal, then the default handler 
is used.  The default signal handlers are "implementation-dependent", 
according to the references I consulted, and I believe that they are part of 
the C library.

If you absolutely want a core dump on SIGSEGV, it sounds like you'll have to 
implement a handler that exhibits this behavior.  I could be wrong about 
where the default handlers live but what I've written should at least give 
you some idea of what you need to do.  Unless your code takes a long time to 
run or it doesn't exhibit the problem in the debugger (which at least used to 
be a problem sometimes), I still think that just running your code from 
within gdb will be easiest.

In case you're interested, the sources I looked at were

"A Book on C" by Kelly and Pohl
"C A Reference Manual" by Harbison and Steele
"Beginning Linux Programming" by Mathew and Stones

The man pages related to signals might also help you.

Good luck,

Mark

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Dec  8 14:00:52 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun, 8 Dec 2002 14:00:52 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] trying to debug program  --  no core file
In-Reply-To: <1039380603.1147.3.camel@enlightenment>
References: <1039377172.1089.1.camel@enlightenment> <200212081344.56368.mmartin@u.washington.edu> <1039380603.1147.3.camel@enlightenment>
Message-ID: <200212081400.52842.aschlemm@attbi.com>

Does the program consistantly crash? If so you could just run in gdb and 
then look at the stack trace when the program crashes. Other things to 
consider is what signal is occuring when the program crashes. Not all 
signals have a default action of creating a core file when they are 
raised.

The "signal" man page in section 7 of the manpages shows all of the 
signals and the default action associated with them. You can use the 
following command to see the pages:

man 7 signal

Tony

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sun Dec  8 18:58:23 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Sun, 08 Dec 2002 18:58:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] flickering monitor advice?
References: <1039334021.3308.29303.camel@obelisk.spek.org> <3DF38B91.1020808@pacifier.com> <200212081350.02311.aschlemm@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <3DF406CF.2060001@pacifier.com>

Anthony Schlemmer wrote:
> Just curious as to how long MOVs usually last? I've read this too but 
> how doesn't one go about finding out if the MOVs in a power strip are 
> still in a usable condition? I have some power strips that are 5-6 
> years old and the indicator lights that supposedly indicate the surge 
> suppression circuits are intact still illuminate when the power is 
> supplied to the strip.


Can't say how long, depends on how many spikes you get (how many joules 
they've absorbed).  Read somewhere that 2-3 years is about it.  There is no 
practical way to know that they are still working.  They are sacrificial 
components, poor little guys.

Here in Portland, the service seems pretty decent.  My folks live in 
Connectitcut and seem to lose a few appliances a year due to brown-outs and 
surges.

Safe bet that the MOVs in your outlet strips are shot.  You can replace them 
if you know what you are doing.

--
Kyle Accardi




From sandbox at pacifier.com  Sun Dec  8 19:12:06 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)

Brent Rieck wrote:
> On Sun, 2002-12-08 at 01:18, Bill Barry wrote:
> 
>>Do you have the monitor and computer plugged into the
>>same power strip? If not, try that. Sometimes if they
>>are plugged into different places that have different
>>paths to ground you can greatly increase the noise
>>pickup. For instance you may have the computer plugged
>>into a ups and the monitor not plugged into the same ups.
>>This can sometimes be a problem.
> 
> 
> Bill,
>   Thanks for the hints about ground loops.  They're not plugged into the
> same UPS, I'll move them around so one computer/monitor is on one UPS
> where I can.  One of the monitors services 2 and sometimes 3 computers
> (via a KVM), all of which I've found out by trial and error cannot all
> be plugged into the same UPS.  Do you think plugging the KVM, monitor
> and the most-used computer into one UPS will be effective?  Or will the
> other computers that are connected through the KVM screw with the
> grounding when they're plugged into other UPSes?


If the flickering CRT is intermittent, a ground loop seems less likely.
If the flickering is constant, then perhaps a ground loop.

What was it that told you not to plug all PCs into the same UPS?  Were you 
tripping a breaker?

The KVM switch will bond all the chassis' together through the shield of the 
cables.  Maybe you have one machine with a hot chassis?

You mentioned that one of the outlets is ungrounded.  It'd be nice to fix 
that: the simple way would be cut power to the outlet, remove it and see if 
there are three wires coming into the box.  If so, replace the outlet with a 
grounded one.  If not, you need to run a ground from the breaker panel.

To keep all this on-topic, chant "linux is as linux does" for the duration 
of your troubleshooting endeavor.

Cheers,
Kyle Accardi







From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Dec  8 19:52:21 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sun, 08 Dec 2002 19:52:21 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] RPM controlled? (Re: Removing previous kernels)
References: <16654-87684@sneakemail.com> <3DF12167.1050507@pacifier.com>	 <200212062033.31784.mmartin@amath.washington.edu> <1039293281.30115.113.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <3DF41375.1070002@dimstar.net>

Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:

>Debian's "dpkg" does not have a separate "upgrade" and "install"
>concept.  When you install something for which a version is already
>there, it "simply" performs an upgrade.
>
Which could be bad. Replacing some libraries with newer version can 
break some software.

If I WANT multiple kernel packages installed, then I use -i and install 
the second kernel package. It puts kernel, modules and whatnot in kernel 
name specific locations and filenames. Grub or lilo get's updated with 
the additional kernel so I have the choice at boot time.

The same goes for certain libraries. There have been times where I 
needed library.so.2, but my distribution came with library.so.3. Linking 
didn't work, and there was much teeth nashing as I tried to figure out 
how it worked.

Finally, I was able to -i (install) the additional library, alongside 
the existing, newer library, and everything worked.

In some cases, source would have worked as well, but in others, building 
from source complained about the missing library (linked or not) too. 

-- 
Russ Johnson
Stargate Online
http://www.dimstar.net

From russj at dimstar.net  Sun Dec  8 19:59:04 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Sun, 08 Dec 2002 19:59:04 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Kernel removal
References: <1039217317.8903.79.camel@localhost.localdomain> <200212062113.51491.mmartin@amath.washington.edu>
Message-ID: <3DF41508.1050306@dimstar.net>

Mark Martin wrote:

>You guys are making this WAY too complicated.  When you install a new kernel 
>package on an RPM-based system (assuming that you're using lilo),
>
>1. Install the corresponding kernel package(s) using the -i flag.  (-U is 
>superfluous but generally harmless.)
>
No, -U isn't "superfluous but generally harmless". -U will cause RPM to remove the current kernel and modules. -i causes the kernel to be installed along side the current kernel. Most of the time, this is OK, and everythings works as expected. There is a rare occurence of bad installation, where the new kernel won't load. If you don't have the old kernel on the system anymore, then you get to fix it after using a boot disk. 

>5. If the system comes up without difficulty, you'll probably want to make the 
>new kernel the default kernel (if the RPM package hasn't already done this 
>for you).
>
If you only had one kernel, -U *WILL* replace the known good kernel with 
the new kernel, and make it the default.

>6. If you want to remove the old kernel, use RPM with the -e flag and a long 
>enough version of the old kernel package name to distiguish it from any other 
>installed kernel package names.
>
If you used -U, then this is done during the install of the new kernel.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Dec  9 00:06:05 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 09 Dec 2002 00:06:05 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] trying to debug program  --  no core file
In-Reply-To: <1039380603.1147.3.camel@enlightenment>
References: <1039377172.1089.1.camel@enlightenment>
	 <200212081344.56368.mmartin@u.washington.edu>
	 <1039380603.1147.3.camel@enlightenment>
Message-ID: <1039421165.7303.13.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Sun, 2002-12-08 at 12:50, Josh Zeckser wrote:
> On Sun, 2002-12-08 at 11:44, Mark Martin wrote:
> > This doesn't answer your question but how about running the program in gdb?
> > 
> 
> Actually, I am trying to run it in gdb. It just helps to have a core
> file to feed to gdb.

You can get a core file by using the right "ulimit" invocation.  Check
the shell man page or info.  In Bash, you can type "help ulimit" and get
a brief.

I've found that the most useful way to run GDB is to run it under XEmacs
(I've never gotten it to work under GNU Emacs), so you can have source
level debugging.  I cannot vouch for other distros, but I do know that
if you "apt-get install xemacs21" on Debian, it will Just Work right off
the net.  Basicly, you open your main.c, put the cursor inside main(),
then type "M-x gdb", and follow the prompts.  Once gdb is running, you
can put the cursor back into your code, and use "M-x gdbsrc-mode", then
use the toolbar to set a breakpoint.  Hop over, and run the code, and
you'll have step and trace, follow the arrow and highlight through your
source code.





From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Dec  9 00:38:28 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 09 Dec 2002 00:38:28 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Cscope, SIGSEGV, do_coredump, GNU libc info
In-Reply-To: <200212081521.47739.mmartin@u.washington.edu>
References: <1039377172.1089.1.camel@enlightenment>
	 <200212081344.56368.mmartin@u.washington.edu>
	 <1039380603.1147.3.camel@enlightenment>
	 <200212081521.47739.mmartin@u.washington.edu>
Message-ID: <1039423108.7293.47.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Sun, 2002-12-08 at 13:21, Mark Martin wrote:
> Okay, I'll at least give you some information related to your original 
> question.  What I have to say pertains to C/C++ and I can't vouch for how 
> much will apply to other languages.

Well, for other languages that compile to real CPU assembler object
code, the similar is certainly possible -- that is, the program could
attempt to access RAM that is outside of the area allocated to itself,
and then the operating system would trap that attempt and ... Hmmm.  The
question we must answer is whether the program gets sent a SIGSEGV if it
has not registered a handler for it.  I do know for sure that the core
file is produced by kernel code, and not the C library.  Without
resorting to a manual...

Alright, I've got my XEmacs visiting the kernel-source-2.4.18, it's
loaded with "cscope" support, and I've got cscope indexes built. 
(apt-get bought me all of that, and it Just Works) I use the Cscope menu
to select "find symbol", and type "segv".  I find a bunch of references
to a "segv:" label in "signal.c", but none of them are for i386, so I
try again.  Let's try "sys_segv" once. Nothing.  Hmmm...  Next I try
"find egrep pattern", for "segv".  It's grinding away...

Ok, I find "goto give_sigsegv;" in "arch/i386/kernel/signal.c", and hit
enter on the top one to go take a look.  Here's what I find lower down:

give_sigsegv:
	if (sig == SIGSEGV)
		ka->sa.sa_handler = SIG_DFL;
	force_sig(SIGSEGV, current);

So now I put my cursor on "force_sig", and use the "find symbol" again
to track it down.  There's a bunch of hits... let's try again with "find
global definition".  Ok, this time only one hit, in "kernel/signal.c" on
line 693...  I track on into "force_sig_info", same file.  The comment
here says:

/*
 * Force a signal that the process can't ignore: if necessary
 * we unblock the signal and change any SIG_IGN to SIG_DFL.
 */

Now on into "send_sig_info", we find... our way on, through several
functions... and I've lost the trail.  I must find out where the process
actually becomes active, and where it checks for pending signals then
actually calls the handler or does the core dump.  Let's try another
tactic.  "find egrep pattern" for "core"... and scan by eyeball... Ah,
here.  "arch/i386/kernel/signal.c", line 683:

  if (do_coredump(signr, regs))

Alright, and there's a switch checking for signal names!  Let's "find
global definition" for "do_coredump" now.  Ah, and here's the kernel
actually creating a core file!  You'll notice that it's checking
"current->rlim[RLIMIT_CORE].rlim_cur" to see if you're "rlimit" for core
files is set high enough to make a core the size this one will be.

> The behavior of a program when there's a 
> segfault depends on the signal handler assigned to the SIGSEGV signal.  If 
> the program doesn't define a handler for the signal, then the default handler 
> is used.  The default signal handlers are "implementation-dependent", 
> according to the references I consulted, and I believe that they are part of 
> the C library.

A signal handler is generally code you write yourself.  It's sort of
rude for a library to take over a signal on you, unless that's well
documented.  (libgpm had issues wrt this, IIRC)

http://www.pdxlinux.org/cgi-bin/info2www?file=dir&query=%28libc%29Signal+Handling

> If you absolutely want a core dump on SIGSEGV, it sounds like you'll have to 
> implement a handler that exhibits this behavior.

There are some interesting SEGV handlers in some of the GNU software. 
The emacsen trap it and save your buffers before they crash, for
instance.  That's a lifesaver when you're using a development version to
develop a development version. :-)  The "Bug Buddy" dialog in Gnome is
done with a SEGV handler also.  I believe (IIRC) that KDE also has a
similar common widget.

> "C A Reference Manual" by Harbison and Steele
> "Beginning Linux Programming" by Mathew and Stones
> 
> The man pages related to signals might also help you.

8-)

I highly recommend the GNU Lib C manual!

The book I learned C from was called "Workout C".  It was a very good
textbook.  It came with a C compiler for DOS.

Subject: [PLUG] Tramp over fsh ?
In-Reply-To: <E18L9y0-0006IY-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>
References: <1039289407.30115.75.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>
	 <1039375920.30119.221.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

Message-ID: <1039424650.7296.58.camel@bittersweet.intra.hegbloom.net>

On Sun, 2002-12-08 at 14:03, Russell Evans wrote:
> No Karl, only you possess such rare knowledge. I suggest you stop posting as
> alas it is only pearls to the swine.

Well, then, are they crunchy enough?

"tramp" is a remote file access deal for the emacsen that uses "scp" to
let you transparently edit remote files.  Once it's installed, you can
use a file name of the form: "/[user at host]/path/to/file", and it will
find that file and let you edit.  When you save, it copies it back
over.  This is very useful, since you don't have to run XEmacs on the
server whos conffile you are tweaking.  It only needs to run an sshd,
and you need key based (password free) access.

"fsh" is a Python program that multiplexes a single SSH connection.  If
you need to issue multiple ssh commands, you can use "fsh" instead of
"ssh".  It calls "ssh" internally, and sets up an 8 bit clean pipe to a
"fshd" on the other end.  Thereafter, your ssh commands are run through
that one pipe.  It's faster, since you don't have to set up and tear
down the connection each time.  It works very well with CVS, as the
"CVS_RSH" program.  In fact, that is what it was designed for.

I could not get "fcp" to work as a replacement for "scp" in "tramp".  I
did not have time to mess with it, and was wondering if anyone else had
figured it out already or not?

<munch/> <munch/>  Hey, these aren't bad!  What are they?
