From sharbours at yahoo.com  Thu Dec 12 16:13:48 2002
From: sharbours at yahoo.com (Sean, Sharon and Kyle Harbour)
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 16:13:48 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] video conferencing - Some tips that might help
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCMEMICDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <20021213001348.51360.qmail@web14409.mail.yahoo.com>

Start reading the howtos on H323 applications. If you are trying to
funnel multiple workstations through a single nat or proxy, it's not
going to be fun, if it will work at all. A workaround: Give your
machines behind the proxy static nat entries, each one with a unique
Internet IP address, and it can probably be made to work, but it's
not very secure because of the large number of ports you have to open
for the dynamic port assignments they use. Does anybody else know of
an easier/better/more secure way to get multiple client
videoconferencing to work correctly? Here at my work we are using
some of the latest video bridge equipment with special Cisco PIX
proxy code for the h323 traffic, and it works, but not reliably. The
main problem, as I understand it, is that in some cases when the
clients start to negotiate a connection, the internal IP (e.g.
10.0.0.55) of the NATted machine is passed out to the external
machine along with a semi-random port number to call back on. The
external machine then tries to establish a connection back to the
private address it received, on the random port, and, of course, it
all goes nowhere really really fast. The Cisco stuff gets around it
by using a 'fix-up' protocol on the firewall to sniff the outgoing
packets in real time, and then rewrite them with a good Internet IP
and fixed port. It sort of works, not quite there 100 percent yet, at
least with the mix of multi vendor equipment we use.

Sean Harbour

From sandbox at pacifier.com  Thu Dec 12 18:26:21 2002
From: sandbox at pacifier.com (Kyle Accardi)
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 18:26:21 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] tree to html
Message-ID: <3DF9454D.7000900@pacifier.com>

...or unix tinker toys

Trying to write a bash script (perl solutions will not be suffered)
that will htmlize a directory listing in a nice tree-like way.

First approach used `find` and if the filename wasn't a directory,
I echoed a few &nbsp's to indent it.  But when your directory has more than 
two levels, that approach falls appart and you are looking at keeping track 
of how deeply you are nested so you can output the proper indentation. 
Gnarly stack ops in bash dude.  Some other day.

So, Plan B:
Htmlize the output from `tree`.

$ tree TESTNEST/
TESTNEST/
|-- Dir-Three
|-- Dir_One
|   |-- five way.txt
|   |-- one.txt
|   `-- two.jpg
|-- Dir_Two
|   |-- four.bin
|   `-- three.html
|-- application-info
|   `-- user.applications
`-- dir-four

Unfortunately, when you supress the cute ascii graphics |-` the output 
looses its indentation, like so

$ tree -i TESTNEST/
TESTNEST/
Dir-Three
Dir_One
five way.txt
one.txt
two.jpg
Dir_Two
four.bin
three.html
application-info
user.applications
dir-four

not much of a tree.  So then I tried using `tr` to delete the cute ascii 
graphics, but of course that also corrupts filenames.


QUESTION:  Is there a better tool to A) Provide a tree-like output, and 2) 
substitute strings instead of single chars.

If I could substitute "|--" with "&nbsp", I'd be a little happier.

--
Kyle Accardi

> ...or unix tinker toys

Well, perl is THE unix tinker toy, but if you don't want to do things the
easy way...

> First approach used `find` and if the filename wasn't a directory, I
> echoed a few &nbsp's to indent it.  But when your directory has more
> than two levels, that approach falls appart and you are looking at
> keeping track of how deeply you are nested so you can output the
> proper indentation.  Gnarly stack ops in bash dude.  Some other day.

It seems like you could just use `find .` and check to see if the current
output string is a substring of the following output string and if so
store it as $CURRENT_DIR and indent appropriately moving down the
tree.  You could use sed to split on the / and see what comes out that
way, too.

It all seems rather complex when perl and tree do it fairly nicely.

> So, Plan B:
> Htmlize the output from `tree`.

Did you try `tree -H`?  Was that just not what you needed?

You could modify the source so that -H puts out something more like what
you wanted.  I'm not a master C programmer and I took a look and saw that
I could do it without too much effort at all.

> QUESTION:  Is there a better tool to A) Provide a tree-like output, and

I think modifying tree to give what you want is probably the easiest
route.

> 2)  substitute strings instead of single chars.
> 
> If I could substitute "|--" with "&nbsp", I'd be a little happier.

It's called sed, sir.

one new one. This didn't work. DOS fdisk would not work correctly on the
linux partitions. It could see them, but would not erase them. By this
time, GRUB had been hosed, so I booted with the linux rescue diskette I
made when I first installed RH 8.0. I used its fdisk to write an empty
partition table. Then I went back to DOS fdisk, and successfully created
a single partition (that's the way the machine came originally). I ran
format /s, put the rescue CD back in, rebooted and it did it's thing,
writing all the files to the hard drive.

Any ideas about what step I skipped, or what I might have done to the
machine would be appreciated.

[F1/Delete/Tab/....] and go into BIOS diag routines to test the
system -- or at least have a bootable CD with diag tests which
actually matches the hardware in the system.

From alex at daniloff.com  Thu Dec 12 21:25:41 2002
From: alex at daniloff.com (Alex Daniloff)

Subject: [PLUG] best server motherboard?

> > Did you try `tree -H`?  Was that just not what you needed?
> 
> My tree don't have no -H, what does yours do?

from `man tree`:
       -H baseHREF
              Turn  on  HTML  output,  including HTTP references.
              Useful for ftp sites.  baseHREF gives the base  ftp
              location when using HTML output. That is, the local
              directory may be `/local/ftp/pub', but it  must  be
              referenced       as       `ftp://hostname.organiza-
              tion.domain/pub' (baseHREF should  be  `ftp://host-
              name.organization.domain/').  Hint:  don't use col-
              orization and/or ANSI lines with this  option,  and
              don't give more than one directory in the directory
              list.

I'm using tree v1.3.  I have the source tarball and could probably rustle
up the URL from which I retrieved it.

> >>If I could substitute "|--" with "&nbsp", I'd be a little happier.
> > 
> > It's called sed, sir.
>

> moment.  What's with the sir?  Is that snide for punk?

Added -H to print the tree in HTML format.
Added -L to set the maximum level of directories to print.
Added -R to recursively reestart the search at the level given by `-L' option
(adding as well `-o 00Tree.html').

From jeme at brelin.net  Thu Dec 12 21:12:53 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Thu, 12 Dec 2002 21:12:53 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] PLUG meeting
In-Reply-To: <86r8cpuasa.fsf@red.stonehenge.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0212122039130.20004-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>

On 10 Dec 2002, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
> >>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:
> Jeme> Capitalists are those who exploit the labor of others for
> Jeme> profit.  They believe that the value of an item is the greatest 
> Jeme> price at which a buyer can be found.  That's greedy.
> 
> Hmm.  Sounds like you've been on the wrong end of that equation far
> too often, or you have a narrow view of capitalist.

I'm not really thinking about myself.  I've been fairly lucky to often be
employed by people who aren't making a profit and, thus, paying me more
than my labor's value.

But the bulk of people ARE on the wrong end of that "equation".

> Without introducing emotion-laden words like "exploit", let's call it:

Well, "exploit" is the word used with regard to copyrighted work in the
TRIPS treaty and often used in economics texts to describe the extraction
of profits by withholding from the public.

>     Capitalists produce products and services using labor and raw goods,
>     motivated by the profit made as the difference between what they buy
>     the labor and raw goods and what they can sell it for in a fair
>     market.

I agree with everything but the chosen verb.  Capitalists don't
"produce" anything at all.  They simply come by to collect the proceeds
and dole them out as miserly as possible so that as much is left in their
pocket at the end as possible.  Assuming no subsidies on the raw goods,
the profit is made by withholding payment to labor.

As I quoted in another message on plug-talk just ten minutes ago, Wilhelm
von Humboldt had something to say about people who work FOR others under
coercion such as wages:

  We may admire what he does [his skill and craft], but we must despise
what he is [for he is a machine owned by a capitalist].

> The difference between the leaders in a capitalist and socialist
> society is that a capitalist is motivated by money (which buys power),
> and a socialist is motivated by power.

Wow, talk about narrow views.

The difference between capitalist and socialist society is that a
capitalist society has leaders (see the Thomas Jefferson quote in my
previous message in this thread) and a socialist society does not
necessarily.

What form of power does a person working toward the broad distribution of
power want to keep for himself?  If a person seeks personal power, he is
not a socialist.

In the words of Carl Estabrook,

  To be an anarchist, one must first be a socialist.

In other words, you have to believe in the ability of people to rule
themselves individually before you can remove the tyranny of external
rule.

> Other than that, there's really no difference.  Both lead to
> corruption.

Only if you allow the consolidation of power.  A social-democratic
movement seeks first and foremost the distribution of power.

I swear, you sound like that nut Eric S. Raymond in Revolution OS where he
freaks out and says some nonsense like, "Communism is being FORCED to
share or you get a bullett in the back of your head and they push you into
an unmarked grave or you get life in the gulag or something!"  He has no
idea what he's talking about.  If I had to GUESS, I would think he's sort
of confusing Stalinism with some myth foisted on him by propaganda films
in the 1960s (like the Ad Council's massive "The American Way Of Life"
series).

Freedom and capitalism do not go hand-in-hand.  Moreover, socialism does
not require an ominous and overbearing State to keep it running (but I
think a fair argument can be made that capitalism does).

> There's nothing inherently wrong with motivation, or power, or money,
> or buying and selling on an open market.

Money and power are the same thing under capitalism (i.e., unaccountable
private tyranny).  I don't see how "buying and selling on an open
market" is a motivation for anything at all.

> And I find it hard to not laugh when the people who most claim that
> "capitalists are evil" are the same ones that argue for collective
> bargaining and unions, which is just a different form of corruption,
> manipulating the supply/demand curve on the labor side rather than the
> finished goods/services side. :)

Why is that funny?  If one side should have power over the other, should
it not be the side with the interests of the people doing the work rather
than the side of the owners riding upon their backs?

The curve is already manipulated by private power.  Unionism is just an
attempt to counter-balance the violence of wage-slavery with a democratic
process.

It's true that labor unions can become corrupt, but this is through
willful destruction of the democratic processes that labor movements
attempt to make common by the owners and bosses who despise them.  Unions
that stay democratic do not consolidate power at all and so there is no
corrupting force or motivation.

> I'm for full disclosure and a free market, in case it's not obvious.

Well, if you could find a society that actually developed and moved
forward under free markets and private ownership, I'd be interested to see
it.  Every nation upon which free market principles have been forced today
is living in dire poverty.  The industrialized nations operate under a
system whereby massive amounts of public money is funnelled directly into
the hands of a privileged few in order to prop up their empires.

> I'll trade my two chickens for your pig.  Please keep the government
> out of that.

To me, that last sentence is a non-sequitor.

J.

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu Dec 12 22:04:21 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 12 Dec 2002 22:04:21 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Machine won't boot
In-Reply-To: <3DF95604.9CF07F52@attbi.com>
References: <3DF95604.9CF07F52@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <1039759462.2163.4.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

This usually happens because:

   1) Settings are to aggressive in the BIOS

   2) The memory is having an issue

   3) (Though not as often) A processor is overheating/malfunctioning

Assuming that the BIOS is set to boot to an alternative medium, it is a
hardware issue.

I would first return the BIOS to "fail safe" settings and work your way
up from there.

Machines kind of seem to get in a rut after awhile. When one starts to
shutdown/reboot regularly, funny things can happen until you smooth them
out again.


-Cooper

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Fri Dec 13 00:33:56 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: 13 Dec 2002 00:33:56 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] wow, dust that baby off and she still works!
Message-ID: <86znrawc5n.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

In the process of my recent data archeology, I was led to believe that
I might have some old mbox files lying around.  I didn't find them on
my current box, but I thought they just might still be on my
_original_ computer, a 1986-era AT&T PC6300.  It originally came with
an 8 MHz 8086, which was rare back in those days.  I later replaced
the CPU with a NEC V20 or V30 or something, which was a little bit
faster.  It was still in use as recently as 1997, but ever since my
wife got back from grad school with a Pentium 133 box (currently a
firewall) it has been in either a closet or an attic.  For the last 5
years it has sat untouched, gathering dust in the far end of the
attic.

Well, what's to lose!  So I haul it out, plug it in and fire it up.
Monitor comes on (a still-sharp green monochrome), but it hangs at
detecting the HD, a 20 meg "Hardcard".  No problem, I remember well
that the drive had a stiction problem, so I bang it a few times and as
it comes free I can hear it whir up to speed.  Reset button restarts
the boot up.  Hey, it is working!

So, it boots up Microsoft MS-DOS version 3.10, but the autoexec.bat
takes it right to Procomm Plus.  The machine ended its useful life
doing duty as essentially a remote terminal that I could dial-in to
the office with from my apartment.  Alt-Z doesn't seem to get me out.
Maybe I don't have the keyboard plugged in all the way.  Next time I
boot, I just blitz it with Ctrl-C's to interrupt the autoexec.bat.  I
get a prompt.  Must get rid of the damned PCPLUS, so I start wondering
how the hell I used to edit things on this box.  Edlin!  Well, I crank
that up, it starts up, but no "help".  I manage to delete the last two
lines: a CD to the PCPLUS directory and the execution of PCPLUS, but
don't remember how to save.  "w" seems to be the right thing, but it
doesn't seem to work.  I "q" to quit, but I lose the changes.  I try a
few more times, without luck.  Then I remember my normal editor on
this machine was "microemacs", so I run \etc\me c:\autoexec.bat, and
it starts up!  Wow, old home week!  Nuke the two offending lines, save
with the familiar emacs commands and reboot.

I look around.  For a while in the mid-90's, it had been in my
father's possession.  So there are a smattering of his files.  A
supercalc spreadsheet program.  An old DOS Word.  But no mbox's.
Damn.

I also had noticed that there was an ethernet card plugged in the
back.  That must have arrived shortly before it was retired.  I don't
remember ever getting it to work, but I had completely forgotten it
was even there.  I'd even asked Eric Harrison once about NIC's for
these old boxes.  When I plugged in the RJ45, the link light went on.
There is a directory tree on the HardCard copied from an install
floppy.  I look around.  It is apparently an NS2000, whatever that is.
It's got drivers for w95 and NT.  Run the setup program, but the
diagnostics fail, something about an SRAM failure, but I am not sure
the base I/O port is set correctly, so I give up.

Hmm.  I remember a box of floppies, and find them on the shelf.  This
is the first box of double-sided, double-density 360K floppies I ever
owned.  The FUJI Film floppy disk, labelled MD/2D, came in a nice
robust cardboard box.  I probably haven't touched them in even longer
than the machine.  I open the drive latch and give a quick puff of
breath to disarrange the dust a little, and stick in the first floppy.
DIR A:, I type, and I get an error: Abort, Retry, Ignore.  I type "r"
for retry and it works.  The rest of the disks work too, and not just
to read the directories, I pkxarc'd several .arc files to see what was
inside and _that_ all worked.  Annoying thing is I didn't find the
files I was looking for.  Maybe they don't actually exist.  But
frankly, I am amazed it still works.  And those 16 year old floppies!
Pretty impressive.  Now that I've got the poor thing warmed up, it's
probably off back to the remote corner of the attic again.  Sad, so
sad.

-- 
Russell Senior         ``I've seen every kind of critter God ever made,
seniorr at aracnet.com      and I ain't never seen a meaner, lower, more
                         stinkin' yellow hypocrite than you!'' 
                                        -- Burl Ives as Rufus Hennessy

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Dec 13 09:31:23 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 09:31:23 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] Spam Questions
In-Reply-To: <3DF8F411.E082641F@anodizing.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212130926450.17707-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Thu, 12 Dec 2002, Abraham Zwygart wrote:

> I was in a meeting with upper management that are really upset about
> spam.  I am trying to come up with some ideas on how to stop it or
> at least reduce it ( i am getting over 40 spam messages a day).  We
> have a redhat linux pop 3 email server and lots of windows nt pc. Is
> there something that can I can by to put on the linux box?

Here's a rough outline of the architecture I've got at work:

* MTA: Sendmail 8.12
* Local mailer: procmail

We've got MIMEDefang[1] compiled against the sendmail 'milter'
library. MIMEDefang, a large unwieldy Perl thingee with a C wrapper,
runs in a sort of daemon mode (see: mimedefang-multiplexor), waiting
for messages to scan.

In our setup, MIMEDefang has two subsidiary processes it uses to scan
mail: sophie[2] and SpamAssassin[3]. Sophie scans for viruses,
SpamAssassin for, er, spam. Actually, we don't actually call
SpamAssassin right now; we need to lock down some policies first.

When sendmail receives an inbound message via SMTP, but before it
accepts the message for local delivery or relaying, it hands the
message off to MIMEDefang. MIMEDefang writes the message to a temp
file, unpacks any MIME attachments, and then runs sophie against the
temp file(s) to check for viruses.

If a virus is found, we can do a number of things:

* bounce the message, since we're still within the SMTP transaction 
  and the message hasn't yet been accepted for delivery,

* add a simple warning header but otherwise deliver it as-is,

* rewrite the message to remove the offensive part(s), perhaps 
  replacing the infected part with a 'Virus Alert' notification, and 
  deliver the rewritten message, or

* deliver it as-is.

We currently opt for the rewrite response, though we expect to start
bouncing any and all viruses fairly soon.

If the message isn't infected, then it's is available for spam
checking. If the message is found to be spam, we've got the same
options available as we do when there's a virus: bounce, add a header,
rewrite, or deliver.

Once a message has been accepted for local delivery, then each local
user will then have the ability to invoke spamassassin and procmail
using his/her own rules and disposing of the message as he/she sees
fit.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

[1] http://www.roaringpenguin.com/mimedefang/

[2] http://www.vanja.com/tools/sophie/, which in turn is dependent on 
    the Sophos AntiVirus software: http://www.sophos.com/

[3] http://spamassassin.org/





From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Dec 13 09:46:49 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 09:46:49 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] /var/mail/user1 to be forwarded
In-Reply-To: <MEEKKAPIMDJAJLIOBCHCEENICDAA.bmdimaculangan@bhpi.com.ph>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212130935480.17707-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 13 Dec 2002, BMDimaculangan wrote:

> I have a user who have existing account in our server
> (user1 at mycompany.com). The mails of this user is then forwarded to
> another email address (user1 at newcompany.com) using aliassing.
> Unforunately, aliassing was done after some of the mail was
> delivered, and I need the mail in /var/mail/user1 to be forwarded to
> user1 at newcompany.com. How is that accomplished? Please help.

  cat /var/mail/user1 | formail -s /bin/mail user1 at newcompany.com

All the messages will be there, but the headers and body of the 
originals will appear in the body of the sent messages, and they'll 
all appear to have come from whomever ran formail (e.g., root).

Probably better would be just to tar/zip his inbox and ship it to him 
as a file. Then his mail client can just read the mailbox.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

	 <3DF9F949.7187C083@attbi.com>

Did you run "fdisk /mbr" (the DOS version) before you rebooted?  This
will rewrite the master boot record, deleting the linux boot loader and
installing the DOS boot loader.  There must also be a boot flag set for
DOS.

Good Luck

Derek Loree

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Dec 13 10:45:54 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 10:45:54 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] tree to html
In-Reply-To: <3DF9454D.7000900@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212131044520.17707-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Thu, 12 Dec 2002, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> First approach used `find` and if the filename wasn't a directory, I
> echoed a few &nbsp's to indent it.  But when your directory has more
> than two levels, that approach falls appart and you are looking at
> keeping track of how deeply you are nested so you can output the
> proper indentation.  Gnarly stack ops in bash dude.  Some other day.

If the filenames have no spaces, then the loop isn't too tough:

  for f in $(find . | sort); do
    echo $f | sed -e 's![^/]\+/!\&nbsp;\&nbsp;!g' -e 's!$!<br>!'
  done

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Dec 13 14:46:53 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri, 13 Dec 2002 14:46:53 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] tree to html
In-Reply-To: <3DFA50F1.2070203@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212131414580.17707-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Fri, 13 Dec 2002, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> 	for f in "$(find . | sort)"; do
> 	  echo "$f" | sed -e 's![^/]\+/!\&nbsp;\&nbsp;!g' -e 's!$!<br>!'
>    	done
> 
> perhaps you could help me grok the sed command, though
> 
> you're substituting everything before a / with &nbsp;&nbsp and
> tacking <br> to the end, but my reference doesn't talk about the
> plus sign.  Is that to indicate multiple substitutions?

  sed -e 's![^/]\+/!\&nbsp;\&nbsp;!g'

My Rosetta Stone, where C == command line, E == English translation of 
command line, and N == misc. notes.

  C: sed -e
  E: Hey, sed. I need you to do something for me.

  C: 's!!!'
  E: I'd like you to do some text substitution for me.
  N: Perl just stole this notation, since it was familiar to sed-ites.

  C: [^/]\+/
  E: Look for one or more characters (excluding a forward slash) that
     are followed by a forward slash.
  N: The '+' isn't universally honored by all sed implementations. I 
     know that Sun's sed can't grok it. GNU sed might be unique. In 
     fact, now that I look through the sed texinfo and man pages, I 
     see that the '+' isn't even documented. Wierd. I guess I at some 
     point extrapolated from, e.g., the expr syntax.

  C: \&nbsp;\&nbsp;
  E: Replace that text with "&nbsp;&nbsp;".
  N: The & needs to be escaped lest sed interpret it as what the 
     sed(1) man page calls "the special character &" that refers
     "to that portion of the pattern space which matched."

  C: g
  E: Do that replacement as often as you can on the text you're
     reading.

> And the bangs don't jibe with my book which says "applies the
> command to all lines except the selected ones".

The bangs are just separators for the s/// command; I could just as 
easily have used commas, slashes, carats, hashes, or what-have-you. I 
like exclamation marks because I rarely have them in the text I'm 
matching, unlike forward slashes, which occur all the time in 
filenames.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Fri Dec 13 18:25:26 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: 13 Dec 2002 18:25:26 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SCSI tape soft error LOGGING - HOW?
In-Reply-To: <20021214013142.525532FEA6@joseph.doink.com>
References: <20021214013142.525532FEA6@joseph.doink.com>
Message-ID: <1039832726.3292.70.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Okay, Keven, here you go...

If I understand your question correctly, you are saying, ``Hey, a friend
of mine has this really cool thing on his Solaris box where it outputs
soft tape error messages /var/log/syslog, how can I do the same?''

In that context, here's how...

Let's say that you are using 'tar' to make your backup. Here's how:

tar cvf /dev/st0 / 2>>/var/log/syslog

The important thing here to see is the '2>>/var/log/syslog' part of the
command. This will *append* any messages bound for channel two (error
channel) to the /var/log/syslog file.

If I have mis-interpreted your message please let me know.


Best,


Cooper

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Dec 14 12:06:14 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat, 14 Dec 2002 12:06:14 -0800 (PST)
Subject: [PLUG] tree to html
In-Reply-To: <3DFB836B.4080404@pacifier.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212141135370.17707-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sat, 14 Dec 2002, Kyle Accardi wrote:

> find $1 . | sort | while read f; do
>    href_str='<a href="'"$f"'">'
>    echo -n $href_str
>    echo "$f" | sed -e 's![^/]\+/!\&nbsp;\&nbsp;!g' -e 's!$!</a><br>!'
> done
> 
> 
> but yields a leading underline, like
> <a href="./Dir_Two">&nbsp;&nbsp;Dir_Two</a><br>

I think I'd take a different tack. (Actually, at this point, I'd use 
Perl -- but you've already ruled that out, so ...)

Point one: be careful where you use single (non-interpolating) and 
double (interpolating) quotes.

Point two: I'm unclear how you really want the output to appear. My 
guesses may be way off the mark.

Point three: the output from this script snippet isn't great :-)


find $1 | sort | while read f; do
  # grab the file/directory name, sans leading path
  fname=$(basename $f)
  # see how deep in the directory tree we are by counting
  # the number of /'s in $f
  depth=$(expr $(echo $f | sed 's![^/]!!g') : '/\+')
  # add leading spaces, two per / in $f
  for n in $(seq 0 $depth); do
    echo -n '&nbsp;&nbsp;'
  done
  # build the html, plain font for files, bold for directories
  if [ -d "$f" ]; then
    echo "<b><a href='$f'>$fname</a></b><br>"
  else
    echo "<a href='$f'>$fname</a><br>"
  fi
done

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

> right place?  Any more suggestions?
>
> Thanks....

Have you looked in /etc/syslog.conf to see where the various messages are 
being written? The information that your seeking might be written into a file 
that your not expecting. In most cases, and this might not be correct 
depending on the kernel and driver, the message should be a *.kern message 
and probably written to /var/log/messages.

In any case, you might want to look in syslog.conf to make sure.

From revans at e-z.net  Sat Dec 14 13:27:36 2002
From: revans at e-z.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Sat, 14 Dec 2002 13:27:36 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] SCSI tape soft error LOGGING - HOW?
In-Reply-To: <200212141236.46084.stevea@nwtechops.com>
References: <20021214065019.F24DF2FEA6@joseph.doink.com>
    <200212141236.46084.stevea@nwtechops.com>
Message-ID: <E18NJng-0005FA-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

CONFIG_SCSI_CONSTANTS:

The error messages regarding your SCSI hardware will be easier to
understand if you say Y here; it will enlarge your kernel by about
12 KB. If in doubt, say Y.


CONFIG_SCSI_LOGGING:

This turns on a logging facility that can be used to debug a number
of SCSI related problems.

If you say Y here, no logging output will appear by default, but you
can enable logging by saying Y to "/proc file system support" and
"Sysctl support" below and executing the command

   echo "scsi log token [level]" > /proc/scsi/scsi

at boot time after the /proc file system has been mounted.

There are a number of things that can be used for 'token' (you can
find them in the source: drivers/scsi/scsi.c), and this
allows you to select the types of information you want, and the
level allows you to select the level of verbosity.

If you say N here, it may be harder to track down some types of SCSI
problems. If you say Y here your kernel will be somewhat larger, but
there should be no noticeable performance impact as long as you have
logging turned off.



Maybe http://evlog.sourceforge.net/why_not_just_use_syslog.html 

CONFIG_EVLOG:

This enables support for enterprise level event logging based upon
the draft POSIX 1003.25 standard. Enabling this feature does not affect
the operation of the sysklogd package in any way. In order to fully
utilize this feature user must also install the companion evlog package
in user-space.

For more information see http://systemras.sourceforge.net





Thank you
Russell

surprised no one has suggested that yet.

However, I too would do it in Perl.

>>>>> "Paul" == Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com> writes:

Paul> On 13 Dec 2002, Randal L. Schwartz wrote:
Paul> cat /var/mail/user1 | formail -s /bin/mail user1 at newcompany.com
>> 
>> Aha.  A useless use of cat.

Paul> :-)

Paul> Actually, I don't know enough about various shells to predict how
Paul> input redirection would interact with formail's '-s' switch: would
Paul> stdin go to formail or to mail? Not wanting to spend much time testing
Paul> it under various shells, and hating to become one of those 'of course
Paul> you use bash' bigots, I punted and set up a pipe.

formail -s /bin/mail user1 at newcompany.com <foo

The < is always applied to the command before the command starts.
Therefore, it could never have been data to "formail", and therefore
never anything to do with /bin/mail.  formail doesn't even know,
or care, that redirection has happened, and would have to work really
hard to find out.

Paul> If there's a clear rule about when redirection gets set up in *nix 
Paul> shells, I'd be happy for someone to set me straight.

Hopefully, I just did.

install.

Anyone have a quick way to work around this crazy boot loader?

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Mon Dec 16 12:01:07 2002
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 14:01:07 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Even root can't write to /tmp?!
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212161205560.29750-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212161205560.29750-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <200212161401.07994.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

The problem that I just described is a good reason to put /tmp and /var on 
separate partitions.

It doesn't necessarily sound like a hardware problem to me.  If it's a 
hardware problem, you'd expect to see errors related to I/O on the drive 
listed in /var/log/messages.

Here's another suggestion that could be completely misguided.  (I'm sure 
someone will correct me quickly if it is.)  If /tmp lives on an ext2 
filesystem, try checking the file attributes of /tmp using lsattr.  Maybe the 
"i" attribute somehow got turned on for the directory.

Mark

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Mon Dec 16 12:06:13 2002
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 14:06:13 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Even root can't write to /tmp?!
In-Reply-To: <1040070001.29223.32546.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212161205560.29750-100000@shell1.aracnet.com> <1040070001.29223.32546.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <200212161406.13045.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

One easy thing you can do that might indicate whether you have a trojaned 
version of df is to verify the rpm package that df is part of.  This, of 
course, will only work if the hypothetical attacker hasn't modified the 
checksums recorded in the RPM database or some such.  The command df is in 
the fileutils package.  So, just type

rpm -V fileutils

to verify the package.  See the man page for rpm for the meaning of the 
output.

Mark

On Mon, 2002-12-16 at 12:06, Mark Martin wrote:
> One easy thing you can do that might indicate whether you have a trojaned 
> version of df is to verify the rpm package that df is part of.  This, of 
> course, will only work if the hypothetical attacker hasn't modified the 
> checksums recorded in the RPM database or some such.  The command df is in 
> the fileutils package.  So, just type
> 
> rpm -V fileutils
> 
> to verify the package.  See the man page for rpm for the meaning of the 
> output.
> 
> Mark

Just an FYI, some of the more recent root kits install trojaned RPMs
(and/or update RPMS to keep other crackers from exlpoiting the same
holes they used to get in) and if this is the case rpm -V will not find
it.  The best thing to do, assuming you don't have tripwire configured
and installed (or something similar) is to boot say, Knoppix from CD and
use that to mount and inspect your old partitions.  I recently read
about a list of "known-good" md5sums for binaries across a range of
default UN*X Installs (OpenBSD, RedHat, FreeBSD, etc.  there were more,
but that's what I remember) that might be useful.

-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>




From shahms at shahms.com  Mon Dec 16 12:55:11 2002
From: shahms at shahms.com (Shahms King)
Date: 16 Dec 2002 12:55:11 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Even root can't write to /tmp?!
In-Reply-To: <200212161406.13045.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

	 <1040070001.29223.32546.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
	 <200212161406.13045.mmartin@u.washington.edu>
Message-ID: <1040072111.313.33.camel@ltsp.mesd.k12.or.us>

As long as we're listing "quick and dirty ways to tell if you've been
hacked that might not always work" the best one I've found by far is: 

$ find / -name ...
(using a trusted find, of course) as many, many rootkits still create a
directory called '...' to hide stuff in.  The replaced binaries, of
course, don't list this directory, and even uncompromised binaries may
not list it (it is, after all hidden, and beyond that, how many people
pay close attention to the '.' and '..' entries already present in every
directory?)
-- 
Shahms King <shahms at shahms.com>

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Dec 16 13:32:23 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: 16 Dec 2002 13:32:23 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Even root can't write to /tmp?!
In-Reply-To: <1040068313.29224.32340.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212161135420.28450-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
	 <1040068313.29224.32340.camel@obelisk.spek.org>
Message-ID: <1040074342.12804.22.camel@bittersweet.hegbloom.net>

On Mon, 2002-12-16 at 11:51, Brent Rieck wrote:
> On Mon, 2002-12-16 at 11:39, Phil Tomson wrote:
> > cp: can't create regular file, permission denied
> > 
> > What gives?
> > 
> > Phil
> 
> Have you checked to see if /tmp has space available? 

He has done so implicitly.  It would have said "no space left on device"
if there was not any.  Instead, it says "permission denied".  My guess
is that the "/" is mounted read only.

I have been using "tmpfs" for /tmp with great success.  It works very
well, and there's no need to clear it on reboot.  You can read about it
in the kernel documentation:

http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/kernel-doc-2.4.18/Documentation/filesystems/tmpfs.txt.gz

Here's what I have in my "/etc/fstab":

/dev/shm	/tmp	tmpfs	size=128m,mode=1777	0	0

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Mon Dec 16 14:06:07 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 14:06:07 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Even root can't write to /tmp?!
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212161327350.626-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212161327350.626-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <200212161406.07759.aschlemm@attbi.com>

If you have exploitable services running on the box that are wide open 
then the box can be hacked on a dialup connection just like it can on 
an ethernet connection. Before I had a broadband connection and was 
using a dialup PPP connection I would see several port probes hit my 
system's firewall when it was connected for any length of time.

If the system is being used as a dialup client, you probably don't need 
to be running much in the way of any services on the system.

Tony

From lemming at attbi.com  Mon Dec 16 17:33:38 2002
From: lemming at attbi.com (Mark Morgan)
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 17:33:38 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] Working around GRUB
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0212161701230.7121-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <3DFE7EF2.40708@attbi.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> On 16 Dec 2002, Aaron Baer wrote:
> 
>>Booting into single user with grub.. 
>>http://www.redhat.com/docs/manuals/linux/RHL-7.3-Manual/custom-guide/s1-rescuemode-booting-single.html
> 
> 
> In other words, not without the password?

Hmm. Well, if you had set the GRUB password, yes.

If you need to get by it, you could use a rescue disk and reinstall the 
master boot record.  I haven't tested this for passwd recovery, but it 
should work.

The first CD of the RH install.

You might not even have to use the 7.3 CD, but even an 8.0.

Follow directions to get to the rescue prompt.

# grub
grub> root (hd0,0)  # Which partition your /boot is at:
                     # This is the same hdc1
grub> setup (hd0)   # This will write the boot sector
grub> quit

Now you shouldn't have to worry about the pesky password.

-Mark

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Mon Dec 16 17:22:31 2002
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 19:22:31 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Even root can't write to /tmp?!
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212161736360.14315-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212161736360.14315-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <200212161922.31952.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

Only root can set this attribute using the chattr command.  See the man page 
for details.  Maybe your box was cracked after all, unless you can imagine a 
context where you or some other authorized user might have accidentally set 
it.

Mark

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Mon Dec 16 18:08:07 2002
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Mon, 16 Dec 2002 20:08:07 -0600
Subject: [PLUG] Hacked?  More info
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212161750110.14315-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212161750110.14315-100000@shell1.aracnet.com>
Message-ID: <200212162008.07583.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

You've been cracked, without a doubt.  If you haven't already, I strongly 
suggest unplugging the box from the phone line in case the cracker set up 
jobs to dial out and perform some nefarious tasks.  If you know someone on 
the list who is good at forensics, maybe they'd be willing and interested in 
taking a look at it for you before you wipe it.  Otherwise, I suggest 
carefully retrieving whatever important personal files that you can using a 
rescue disk (which won't have trojaned commands), wiping the drive (also 
using a rescue disk), and reinstalling the system.  Check any personal files 
that you want to save very thoroughly to make sure that you aren't going to 
compromise the system with them.  You also might want to change your 
passwords on other boxes where you have might have the same or similar 
passwords.  Furthermore, I suggest setting up firewalling on the system 
before reattaching to the network, eliminating any unnecessary services, and, 
of course, choosing completely different passwords.

If you're interested, you might use a floppy to transfer chkrootkit to the 
system to see what you can learn.  I sent the URL in another message in this 
thread.

I know that some of these are appallingly obvious and I've probably missed 
something vital (that someone else will undoubtedly let me know about soon).  
Sorry that it ended up this way and best of luck in cleaning up the mess.

Mark

P.S. It might not be all bad.  At least it gives you an opportunity to 
upgrade. ;-)

>>>>> "Jeme" == Jeme A Brelin <jeme at brelin.net> writes:

Jeme> On 16 Dec 2002, Aaron Baer wrote:
>> Booting into single user with grub..
>> http://www.redhat.com/docs/manuals/linux/RHL-7.3-Manual/custom-guide/s1-rescuemode-booting-single.html

Jeme> In other words, not without the password?

If I understand your problem, then you should be able to supply a
kernel parameter at boot, e.g.:

  kernel /boot/vmlinuz-X.Y.Z root=/dev/hdaN init=/bin/bash

which will give you a root shell with no password.  Then, all you have
to do is remount your root partition read/write and edit /etc/passwd.
I think that will work.  It seems to on my Debian crashbox.

From creswick at cs.orst.edu  Tue Dec 17 01:50:25 2002
From: creswick at cs.orst.edu (Rogan Creswick)
Date: Tue, 17 Dec 2002 01:50:25 -0800
Subject: [PLUG] 4GB Address space ?

> Is that physical memory, or virtual memory?  Can it address more than         
> that amount of virtual memory, but only 4GB at a time, or what?

Since it is a 32 bit architecture, I'm pretty sure it can only address
4 gigs of virtual memory (2^32 == 4gig). I _think_ this is
per-process, so each process could have a 4gig memory space, but I
could easily be wrong there.

From mmartin at u.washington.edu  Tue Dec 17 07:10:05 2002
From: mmartin at u.washington.edu (Mark Martin)
Date: Tue Dec 17 07:10:05 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Hacked?  More info
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212170640430.28607-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212170640430.28607-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <200212170843.35324.mmartin@u.washington.edu>

Why was a port related to linuxconf open to the world?  You want multiple 
layers of security.  Two of these layers should be a firewall and up-to-date 
versions of all software behind the firewall.  Since you can block all 
connections initiated outside a machine with a single iptables command, there 
really is no good excuse for not blocking ports that the outside world has no 
business seeing.

Mark

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Dec 17 07:52:03 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Tue Dec 17 07:52:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] 4GB Address space ?
In-Reply-To: <20021217095025.GA2583@silver.CS.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0212170748390.25927-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

4G per process (actually 3 of user space, and 1G of kernel space, you can
hack the kernel to redistribute this a bit, up to about 3.6G user space).
If you enable the 36-bit extension (Intel PAE), you can use >4G RAM up to
64G, but still only 3G per process, so a fully loaded PAE machine with 64G
RAM can run 21 processes of 3G each at the same time, and the remaining 1G
is for the kernel.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Tue Dec 17 11:31:03 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: Tue Dec 17 11:31:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Lurker Lurker Lurker
Message-ID: <1040153412.12812.70.camel@bittersweet.hegbloom.net>

I tell you three (3) times --- If you have not yet looked at "Lurker",
you really really really should do it now.  Don't use old Nescape
Navigator though, use a recent Mozilla or Galeon.  You'll find that the
XML version of the pages works very well.

You will really enjoy the tree view it gives for email threads.  When a
link is yellow, that means it's the start of a thread or that it's a
place where someone changed the subject when they replied to another
message.

http://lists.pdxlinux.org/lurker/message/1040047266.12812.16.camel%40bittersweet.hegbloom.net.xml

For those of you who would rather look at a program than watch
television, have a look at the Lurker source code!  It's a beautiful
site to behold.  This is well written Quality software and a coding
example well worth learning from.  The authors are very well organized;
the code is actually documented and easy to read.  Follow the URL's in
the comments and learn a LOT about B-Trees and AVL trees, for instance.

Some problems I encountered, but think I've fixed:

 o Apache "mod_speling" interferes with Lurker's CGI setup.  It hooks
   the request process and delivers a "Multiple choices" error when you
   try to access a page that's not been generated yet, but for which
   there is already one with the same prefix; that is, written by the
   same person and thus having the same Message-Id prefix.  Turning off
   "mod_speling" fixed the problem.

 o lurkerd uses "fcntl" advisory locking on the mbox files, but I don't
   think that "pipermail" (from Mailman) is doing any locking.  I wonder
   if that's going to cause any trouble or not?  The Debian Policy Manual
   mandates that mbox locking be done in an NFS safe fashion using a
   certain algorithm and a "$MBOXNAME.lock" file.  Perhaps lurkerd should
   be patched to support that?  I wonder if "procmail" can use fcntl style
   locking or not?

Any feedback or ideas concerning Lurker and the PLUG lists?

On Tue, 2002-12-17 at 11:52, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> Karl M. Hegbloom wrote:
> > I tell you three (3) times --- If you have not yet looked at "Lurker",
> > you really really really should do it now.  Don't use old Nescape
> > Navigator though, use a recent Mozilla or Galeon.  You'll find that the
> > XML version of the pages works very well.
> 
> 
> Using mozilla 1.0.1
> http://lists.pdxlinux.org/lurker/
> 
> "Your web browser does not appear to support XSL"
> 
> What is XSL, and what niftiness am I missing?

What is Google and why don't you ask there?

Mozilla (and thus Galeon) supports XML / XSLT, so you can click the link
for the XML version if you like, or just let the redirect take you to
the HTML version.  The difference is that with the HTML version, the
"xsltproc" is run on server side, but with the XML version, the browser
downloads the .xsl stylesheets, and renders the XML into HTML itself, on
client side.

  - verification at restore time is a must.

    Restore Utility), when I recover I got as far as

    work yet.  The last error I got was a kernel panic when

From kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net  Tue Dec 17 20:55:04 2002
From: kyle_hayes at speakeasy.net (Kyle Hayes)
Date: Tue Dec 17 20:55:04 2002
Subject: [PLUG] 4GB Address space ?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0212170748390.25927-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0212170748390.25927-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
Message-ID: <200212172054.00284.kyle_hayes@speakeasy.net>

On Tuesday 17 December 2002 07:51, Fedor G. Pikus wrote:
> 4G per process (actually 3 of user space, and 1G of kernel space, you
> can hack the kernel to redistribute this a bit, up to about 3.6G user
> space). If you enable the 36-bit extension (Intel PAE), you can use >4G
> RAM up to 64G, but still only 3G per process, so a fully loaded PAE
> machine with 64G RAM can run 21 processes of 3G each at the same time,
> and the remaining 1G is for the kernel.

Er, sort of.  From what I understand on the Linux kernel mailing list, the 
actual feasible amount is 16GiB.  This is due to the size of the page 
tables apparently.  They take up too much room for 64GiB in the standard 
kernel mapping space.  I didn't follow the whole thing very carefully, so 
YMMV.  16 or 64GiB, if I ever have a computer even capable of having that 
much RAM, then I'll worry about it :-)

As Fedor says, each user process is limited to a maximum of 4GB of virtual 
memory, but physical memory can be larger (weird, yes, but what do you 
expect from this many layers of patches on the x86 architecture?).  In 
addition, the kernel is mapped into the memory space of each process.  
That takes some away from the space the process can use.  You can 
configure the ratio of kernel space to user space from 1:3 to 3:1.  I 
think it is normally set for 1:3 which, as Fedor said, is 1 GiB of space 
for the kernel mappings and 3GiB for the user process.

Where do the extra bits come from to form the full 36-bit address?  Is that 
something you stick into the page table entries somewhere?  Another of the 
CRx registers?

Best,
Kyle

  lsof -i :515

Is there anything already bound to that port?

>>>>> "Rich" == Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com> writes:

Rich>   I had to shut down my client workstation to replace the video
Rich> card. Since it came back on the network we can no longer print
Rich> _anything_ from it. The printers are physically attached to the
Rich> server host, and the client's been configured properly before.

Rich>   On the no-longer-functioning machine there is no
Rich> /usr/sbin/printers so I don't know how to diagnose the problem
Rich> and fix it. I've stopped and restarted cupsd but that makes no
Rich> difference.

Rich>   Has anyone some suggestions I can try?

Here are some things to try:

 1) understand how the system works;
  
 2) think about how all the parts of the system interact;

 3) think about what parts might have stopped working;

 4) check and confirm that they are still working the way they are
    supposed to;

 5) when you find something that is not working, fix it and then go to
    step 1. Repeat until desired function is restored.

http://www.fsconsortium.com

On the main page you will find links to subscribe as consultant and/or agent.

Free Software Consortium is a multinational consortium established to link the
companies and the independent consultants that use and promote free software.

One of the bigger obstacles to the development of the free software services
market is the fear of many companies to establish contracts with independent
consultants who do not have support of a well known Company, Corporation or
Consortium.  Questioning quality, support, experience and capability to
successfully complete a project are the companies manager's main concerns when
considering the option of migrating their systems to free software.

Like you, we know the excellent quality that Free Software offers.
We have complete confidence that Free Software is going to be the platform of
the future. That is why it's so important to work and consolidate together to
solve the problem mentioned above.

Free Software Consortium intends to fill this void joining the best free
software companies and consultants at the national and international level.

By joining to Free Software Consortium you or your company will have the
following benefits:

1. Possibility of being hired by other Consortium members.
2. Possibility of hiring other Consortium members.
3. Use of the Consortium image and name with your clients.
4. Use of the Consortium's resources like Publicity Brochures, Business Cards,
Banners for presentations and events, financial presentations, publicity
articles for the press and magazines, support via mailing list and forums with
the Consortium's members, marketing and communication assistance, CD's and
manuals from the Consortium, site and mail hosting (yourarea.fsc.cc) and other
future services.
5. Representation of the FS Consortium in your area to share administrative,
legal and marketing resources between the Consultant members in your area.

Free Software Consortium will establish a contract with an Agent company which
will have exclusive representation in it's area, in charge of organizing the
consultants in the area.  This Agent company will provide the administrative
services, marketing and sales with the local customers.

>From the business generated by the Free Software Consortium, the Agent company
will receive 20% of the value of the contract, and the Consultant or 
Consulting
company will receive 80%.

The Free Software Consortium is developing a new business model and invites 
you
to join as a founding member and contribute in developing this new business
model.  We need your valuable help to give us ideas and comments. Please write
to info at fsconsortium.com


Thank you for your attention.

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu Dec 19 21:08:03 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Dec 19 21:08:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] How to remove module when device is busy?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0212192041540.10547-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
References: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0212192041540.10547-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>
Message-ID: <1040361256.2714.12.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Tyler,

For the ne2000 module, you will need to bring down your ethernet device
first:

   ifconfig eth0 down
   rmmod ne2000

For the rest, try using the -r switch to remove the stack the module
might be in. The sb16.o module, for example relies on at least two other
modules that are loaded in the stack.

If that doesn't work, try to figure out the module stack manually and
work your way down. You can do this by looking at the depmod (module
dependancy) information in /lib/modules/[kernel_version]/modules.dep.
Work your way from the top down.

It may be, as is likely the case with the ne2000 module, that the module
is in use. This will make removing the module impossible.

You can, however, prevent the module from loading at the next boot by
editing the appropriate lines in /etc/modules.conf and/or
/etc/modules.autoload.


-Cooper

On Thu, 2002-12-19 at 20:55, Tyler F. Creelan wrote:
> Hi everyone -
> 
> A module I installed for a modem is causing kernel panics and I'm trying
> to remove it using modconf. However, when I try this I get the error
> "Device or Resource busy." I get the same error when trying to remove
> several other modules I don't want anymore, like ne2000 and apm. How do
> I work around this?
> 
> Also, is there a method to capture the results of a kernel panic, besides
> writing it down by hand? Via a serial link, for example?
> 
> Thanks,
> 
> Tyler

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Thu Dec 19 21:11:03 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Thu Dec 19 21:11:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] How to remove module when device is busy?
In-Reply-To: <Pine.GSO.4.44.0212192041540.10547-100000@eel.ENGR.ORST.EDU>

From jason at vancleve.com  Fri Dec 20 05:55:05 2002
From: jason at vancleve.com (Jason Van Cleve)
Date: Fri Dec 20 05:55:05 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Re: tree to html
References: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0212152114520.24333-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <12D60128.3010203@vancleve.com>

Jeme A Brelin wrote:
  >
  > Tables are made for tabular data, not layout control.

That statement is true, but until CSS came around, tables were all we
had:  and for some things, they still are.  If I were to adhere to your
statement, Jeme, I would not be a very effective Web developer.
Positioning in CSS is still relatively young, so you have compatibility
problems to begin with, whereas HTML tables--while still hopelessly
flawed--are yet much more mature and stable.  And consequently there are
a number of tricks which can still only be done effectively with
tables--especially if you prefer "stretchy" sites to fixed-width
layouts, like me.

My question, though, is whether CSS is the answer to the layout problem.
    I don't think so.  I just don't see the descriptive language in CSS
to handle complex layout.  Just to get firmly off-topic, it's too easy
to become enamoured of some interface or other and to use it
inappropriately--hence the problem with HTML in general.  So the issue
with CSS, as usual, is scope.  I think we should separate "layout" from
"style"; and positioning on the page, especially "absolute" positioning,
seems to transcend mere "style".  Moreover, absolute positioning implies
overlapping rectangles, rather than concentric ones, so the whole
paradigm of HTML is warped here, if not altogether adulterated.  Don't
get me worng, absolute positioning, espressed both in pixels and
percentage of the client window dimensions, without using tables, is
something HTML always needed.  I just don't think it should be done with
CSS either.  If you have a rectangle, the inner spacing around its
contents is a "style" attribute easily enough; but to control the
placement of that rectangle (DIV tag) with its style looks right 
backward to me.  It's one way of doing it, sure, but it seems like bad 
design, in my opinionation.

But then my solution would be to cast off HTML entirely, tattered and
war-torn standard that it is.  A simpler, leaner browser interface
should be possible with XML (I know HTML now conforms to XML, but it
still sucks hopelessly) and CSS, with its own language for positioning
things sensibly and flexibly, and without all the style-based tags.
Anyone seen such a creature?

--Jason





From hapibeli at attbi.com  Fri Dec 20 07:12:03 2002
From: hapibeli at attbi.com (Dirk Ouellette)
Date: Fri Dec 20 07:12:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] No printing in RH 8
Message-ID: <1040397053.1407.762.camel@localhost.localdomain>


As root, do one of the following:

  lsof -i :515

Is there anything already bound to that port?
Paul


Here is my machines answer;

root]# lsof -i :515
bash: lsof: command not found
[root at localhost root]# /sbin/lsof -i :515
bash: /sbin/lsof: No such file or directory








From heinlein at attbi.com  Fri Dec 20 07:40:05 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Fri Dec 20 07:40:05 2002
Subject: [PLUG] No printing in RH 8
In-Reply-To: <1040397053.1407.762.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212200733420.15869-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On 20 Dec 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> Here is my machines answer;
> 
> root]# lsof -i :515
> bash: lsof: command not found
> [root at localhost root]# /sbin/lsof -i :515
> bash: /sbin/lsof: No such file or directory

On my RH 8 box, I get this:

  [heinlein at debs heinlein]$ which lsof
  /usr/sbin/lsof
  [heinlein at debs heinlein]$ rpm -qf /usr/sbin/lsof 
  lsof-4.63-2

It's a handy utility; I'd recommend installing it if you're not short 
of disk space.

If you can't install lsof, you can still use netstat:

  netstat -anl | grep -w 515

That'll at least tell you if your machine is already trying to listen
to something on port 515 -- though, unlike lsof, it won't tell you
what program is bound to the port.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From rshepard at appl-ecosys.com  Fri Dec 20 09:38:03 2002
From: rshepard at appl-ecosys.com (Rich Shepard)
Date: Fri Dec 20 09:38:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Aspire to Crudeness -- December 18 (fwd)
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212200933320.13898-100000@appl-ecosys.com>

                      Aspire to Crudeness -- Issue Thirty

  December 18, 2002

  by Don Marti, Editor in Chief of Linux Journal
     _________________________________________________________________

                 This Week's Sponsor: Programmer's Paradise

    Programmer's Paradise- your best source for Linux development tools!

   New this month - The Intel C++ Compiler 7.0 for Linux adds increased
   levels of Linux support and provides improved compatibility with GNU
   C/C++. The Intel Fortran Compiler 7.0 for Linux offers wider support
   of Linux distributions and the ability to handle Big Endian files.
   See: www.programmersparadise.com/intel/lj:
   http://www.programmersparadise.com/intel/lj
     _________________________________________________________________

   After the Elcomsoft acquital, now what?

   If the debate over the misnamed Digital Millennium Copyright Act
   (DMCA) has taught us anything, it's how productive you can be with a
   decent helping of pigheaded optimism. Remember a year ago, when Dmitry
   Sklyarov went home to Russia? On Tuesday, his employer, Elcomsoft, was
   acquited in the first DMCA criminal case.

   On December 14 of last year, Danny O'Brien wrote:

     They said that a bunch of geeks waving placards would do nothing to
     free DMITRY SKYLAROV. And they said that whining about obscure
     Net-torturing provisions in already drafted legislation would
     change nothing. And we believed them, too. It's lucky that other
     people are more foolishly optimistic than that. After all, it'd be
     fair to claim that adverse publicity of the Skylarov case
     contributed heavily to everyone's DMCA poster-boy being released
     yesterday: especially Adobe's boycott-prompted wish that Dmitry's
     prosecution be dropped. And while UK government defeats during the
     final stages of legislation are almost unheard of, the data
     retention clause in the Anti-Terrorism Act was one of the few to
     get shot down. Out goes the condition that ISP logs can be kept and
     examined for detecting any crime. Now, as heavily lobbied by those
     "aery-faery" and naive civil libertarians, it has to be proper
     *terrorist* crime. Mr Blunkett, in conceding the amendment,
     commented that the logs would have to be kept anyway, to see
     whether they were terrorists or not, and "that is how stupid the
     Liberal Democrats [and their Tory supporters, presumably] are."
     Let's see how stupid the human rights judges, and the Data
     Protection folk are when they get to work on this. Meanwhile,
     here's to another year of stupid protestors and their clearly
     impossible victories.

   http://www.ntk.net/2001/12/14/:
   http://www.ntk.net/2001/12/14/

   "Clearly impossible victories." That's right. Put that in your pipe
   and smoke it, all you apolitical "geeks should stick to code"
   weiner-heads.

   Here's to another victory. Two weeks ago, in this newsletter, I
   predicted:

     "Power lawyer Joseph Burton will get Elcomsoft off in the first
     criminal DMCA trial by appealing to the jury's reason and sense of
     fairness. The prosecution will be unable to justify this irrational
     law, and won't try -- they'll use dumb, simplistic "copying is
     stealing" analogies that will make the jury feel patronized, and
     that Burton will defeat with fair use examples. This will infuriate
     DMCA proponents and cause a huge party in San Francisco."

   It happened. The jury voted to acquit Elcomsoft.

   Look at the news reports at http://news.google.com/news?q=elcomsoft:
   http://news.google.com/news?q=elcomsoft and you'll see that there are
   two possible interpretations of this.

   Interpretation 1: The acquital was a breathtaking Jury Nullification
   of the DMCA, showing once and for all that ordinary Americans won't
   stand for counterintuitive laws that take power away from ordinary
   people and give it to the copyright cartels. Yes, a jury can vote to
   acquit if they just think a law is unjust. Prosecutors can never bring
   a DMCA case again, except against someone who is also a real
   infringer, since the law violates readers' expectations of access to
   copyrighted works they own.

   Interpretation 2: The acquital was a fine feat of lawyer-fu by Joseph
   Burton, but fair use was never an issue -- whether or not Elcomsoft
   made a "willful" violation of the law was. Innovators had better watch
   out because future DMCA prosecutions can come at any time!

   The Business Software Alliance now _seems_ to advocate Interpretation
   1 publicly! In a statement, the organization said, "The DMCA has clear
   criminal penalties that can and should be imposed in cases of direct
   or attempted theft of software and other digital content." (
   http://www.bsa.org/usa/press/newsreleases//2002-12-17.1398.phtml ):
   http://www.bsa.org/usa/press/newsreleases//2002-12-17.1398.phtml

   So I asked for a clarification. BSA spokesperson Jeri Clausing
   replied, "WE would like to see the criminal provisions applied in any
   case of alleged violation of the DMCA."

   Any case. That's right, BSA members don't want to pay their own
   lawyers to bring a civil case -- they want your and my tax dollars to
   pay to suppress fair use.

   But realistically, this isn't going to happen. Prosecutors tried the
   DMCA, and failed. DMCA proponents can't spin this verdict to make it
   look like just a technicality. US Attorneys won't touch another DMCA
   criminal case with an eleven-foot pole unless they can hang something
   else on the defendant too. They won't jeopardize their win/lose
   records by attacking another DMCA-only defendant with this weak law.
   Look at how the prosecutor slunk away in shame after this one.

   So DMCA proponents desperately don't want you to believe
   Interpretation 1. They want you to believe Interpretation 2. But I
   know the "technicality" interpretation is all wrong because the jury
   was AWAKE and INTERESTED at the end of the trial. The definition of
   "willful"? What a stretch! Only the law reporter for the Dubuque Star
   could be interested in this. For the love of God, people, the jury
   asked for a copy of the DMCA! The foreman said, in what I'm sure will
   be this week's most quoted quote of the day, "Under the eBook formats,
   you have no rights at all, and the jury had trouble with that
   concept."

   How much The Jury Thought the DMCA Is Bogus do you need here? Will
   this do you?

   The Jury Thought the DMCA Is Bogus.

   The Jury Thought the DMCA Is Bogus.

   The Jury Thought the DMCA Is Bogus.

   After carefully comparing both interpretation 1 and interpretation 2,
   I have come to the conclusion that Interpretation 1 is true, this is a
   huge win for our side, and we should all (1) party, and (2) take
   further action in the New Year.

   Action? Glad you asked. I'm not going to wait for another DMCA
   prosecution -- see the part about the eleven-foot pole above. Here's
   what I'm planning to do. Please join me.

   In prosecuting this case, and justifying the prosecution of this case,
   the DMCA proponents have said that it's about infringement (well, they
   say "stealing" but that's not the correct term here. Ask your local
   librarian where in the reference section they keep Black's Law
   Dictionary if you don't believe me.) If this is about prosecuting
   infringers, make it about prosecuting infringers, right? Which brings
   us to...

   DMCA reform now! We must strike while the iron is hot! And the iron is
   like center-of-the-Earth hot here, people!

   If the DMCA is about infringement, let's hold them to it, and make it
   about infringement.

   Look up your Representative in Congress, get on his or her announce
   list, and commit to attending his or her first constituent meeting of
   the new year. Why the House? Because the Senate gets more money from
   the DMCA-mongers, and because DMCA reform started in the House last
   time, although it was too late to go anywhere.

   Here is my Representative's Town Hall page:
   http://www-eshoo.house.gov/townhall.html:
   http://www-eshoo.house.gov/townhall.html

   I am going to hit reload on that sucker until a meeting happens, then
   I'm going to go, invite all my freedom-loving friends to go, and ask
   for DMCA reform. In the meantime, you should never ask for something
   unless you can write down what you want in one page, so see below for
   a sample letter.

   Now, let me make one thing very clear. None of your DMCA reform
   advocacy is wasted, if anyone hears about it, because anyone could end
   up on a jury.

   Even if we don't _get_ DMCA reform, loudly _calling_ for DMCA reform
   is going to do what the DVD cases and Dmitry's arrest did -- get the
   problems with the DMCA out in the public's face, and call the whole
   idea of banning fair use in the name of copyright into question.

   You know how it was just "the DMCA" in the paper until Dmitry's
   arrest, then it became "the controversial DMCA"? That's because we
   previously made noise about the DVD cases! Even though one of the DVD
   cases ended unfavorably, and the other is still in the legal system,
   your vocal cords were not damaged in vain.

   So here's what I want, and you should ask for it too ( change the
   California stuff to something relevant to your Representative. Then
   get down to that constituent meeting!)

   The Honorable Anna Eshoo
   698 Emerson Street
   Palo Alto, California 94301

   Dear Representative Eshoo:

   The recent acquital in the trial of the software firm Elcomsoft shows
   that a jury of our fellow Californians believes the anticircumvention
   provisions of the Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) are unfair.
   It is now clear that the DMCA needs reform.

   The anticircumvention provisions should be applied only in the case of
   actual copyright infringement, not as a weapon for copyright-holding
   industries to use against innovators who develop new software for
   business and education.

   While a few vocal lobbyists for the publishing industry defended the
   prosecution of Elcomsoft, others say that the DMCA has gone too far in
   prosecuting software developers instead of actual copyright
   infringers. William Pollock, founder of No Starch Press, wrote last
   year, "While I am certainly opposed to the illegal copying and sale of
   books, I think the government should spend more time prosecuting the
   real offenders: The people and companies who make and sell illegal
   copies of books, not the software tool developers."

   Representative Zoe Lofgren's Digital Choice and Freedom Act of 2002
   was a welcome reform that would have allowed the DMCA's
   anticircumvention provisions to apply only in the case of actual
   infringement, while removing the law's chilling effect on software
   innovators who deliver useful products.

   Please join our 16th district neighbor in sponsorship of this
   legislation when the 108th Congress convenes next month. It is a
   necessary reform to support the innovation and free speech that are so
   vital to our area.

   Sincerely,
   Donald B. Marti Jr.

   Linux Journal is hiring a staff writer.

   If you want to work for Linux Journal, please see the job posting
   at:http://linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=6520:
   http://linuxjournal.com/article.php?sid=6520

   I can't say what I'm hoping to assign to this person, but let me warn
   you that this job will get you used to doing "less /proc/cpuinfo"
   instead of "cat /proc/cpuinfo"

   Microsoft to port to Linux?

   This is the most bogus Linux story since "(name of Linux company here)
   is the new Microsoft". Let me tell you why.

   First of all, there are basically three ways to do server software.

   1. 100% Pure Java. Obey Sun. Count on "write once, debug everywhere"
   to make it possible to deploy on multiple platforms with minimal pain.
   Key advantage are: "It's not Microsoft" and "There are lots of
   relatively inexpensive contract programmers who can do this".

   2. Whatever Microsoft wants you to do this year. You get a
   full-featured integrated development environment in exchange for tying
   yourself to APIs that are more and more difficult to port away from.
   If you use their tools out of the box without paying specific
   attention to portability, you're locked in. One Unix programmer
   pointed that use of Microsoft Foundation Classes in a large C++
   project made the planned "port to Linux" a near-total rewrite instead.
   I'm not saying that you can't use Microsoft tools to do a portable
   program, just that once you decide to do so you're basically following
   choice number 3, which is...

   3. Target a cross-platform environment, not a single platform. (I have
   a whole rant about "targets" and "platforms" and why one should rarely
   be the other.) This is probably the best decision, since it gives you
   the most flexibility. You can make a choice to deploy on another
   platform relatively easily. If you've practiced good habits, many
   would say more easily than with Java. However, there's still a
   question of which cross-platform toolkit.

   But we were talking about Microsoft and porting to Linux, which is a
   story with surprising endurance.
   http://news.google.com/news?q=microsoft+linux+meta:
   http://news.google.com/news?q=microsoft+linux+meta

   Which way do you think they wrote their server software? In Java?
   Naah. With plans all along to port it? Naaah. So they've almost
   certainly got a bunch of essentially unportable software.

   Rewrite? They could afford to -- they certainly have done several
   products that have the same name, different internals. But in that
   case they're basically releasing a brand-new product with none of the
   testing record of the old ones.

   They can cheat, and graft a big Windows compatibility layer into their
   software so it runs natively but slowly on Linux, but in that case,
   they're essentially giving you Windows for no charge. So why not just
   cut the price of Windows, and reduce the amount of coding they have to
   do for the same result?

   Much more likely than "Microsoft to port to Linux" is "Microsoft OS OS
   license fees to fall under price pressure from Linux". Let's see the
   analysts research that one.

   Finally, AUP frenzy

   In the last issue of this newsletter, I complained about ISP
   Acceptable Use Policies (AUPs) that ban you from setting up a public
   WiFi access point. Michael "mikeraz" Rasmussen from the Personal Telco
   Project of Portland wrote in to say,

   "Qwest is concerned with harmful (cracking, spamming) or legally
   sticky (abusive, threatening, pornographic, illegal) content. No
   mention is every made of bandwidth usage by persons other than the
   Qwest customer. All mentions of objectionable use fall into the two
   categories just described.

   "In short, legal use of bandwidth is permitted without respect to the
   party/computer doing the using.

   "Frankly I'm surprised there is no reference to 'not for resale.'

   "The AUP does not address or mention bandwidth sharing."

   Hooray for Qwest, and thanks, mikeraz.

   --
   Don Marti:
   mailto:dmarti at ssc.com

On Thu, 2002-12-19 at 21:01, Robby Russell wrote:
> I am looking for a company that will allow me to run dns on my machine and
> they will basically run transfers from my machine on regular intervals. I
> have one that allows 5 free domain names, but I'm well over 10 now and
> want to use one service for this...
>

There's something we could do on the PLUG server to make it help pay for
itself.  I think we'd want a faster box for it then though...

I've got a patch for BIND 9 that will make doing this sort of thing a
little easier.  It makes the named.conf "include" directive accept a
directory or a file, rather than only a file.  If you give it the name
of a directory, it includes every file in that directory.  This way, the
named.conf snippet for a particular domain can be just dropped into a
file of it's own to add it.  That will make management of boxes with
lots of DNS domains a little more modular.





From felix.1 at canids.net  Fri Dec 20 10:05:05 2002
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Fri Dec 20 10:05:05 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Re: tree to html
In-Reply-To: <12D60128.3010203@vancleve.com> on Sun, 06 Jan 1980 14:54:48 +0100.
Message-ID: <200212201447.gBKElXN03098@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Jason Van Cleve <jason at vancleve.com>:
> My question, though, is whether CSS is the answer to the layout problem.

The fundamental flaw of the xhtml/css model is the
assumption that you can separate form from content, style
from substance, etc.  It's not that it's impossible to do
so, the problem is there isn't necessarily a _right_ way to
do so, and an insistence that everyone conform to a
particular idea of what's content and what's presentation is
going to cause problems.

xhtml/css is an improvement over table-layout html, but it's
still far from right.  css2 has some narrow assumptions
about page layout that puzzle me.  I often find that what I
have in my mind for layout, something I think is simple and
device-independent and easy to do in, say, PostScript, turns
out to be impossible to get right in css2.  So I end up
dreaming to css2's limitations, which usually means I do
very minimal designs that don't really need much of css2's
capabilities.

Device-independent layout is a hard problem.  I think it's
going to need a full programming language to do a good job
of it.  PostScript could do it easily, it already solves
most of the problems.  Someone just needs to spend some time
designing a structure for generic separation of data from
presentation.  That's the easy part.  The hard part is
convincing people to use it.
--

I believe you're not going to find a really cheap SSL cert that's
recognized by all browsers - I went looking a few months ago and the
cheapest I found was around $150/year; I'll see if I can find my notes
if you're interested.  Overall I think an extra $100/year isn't
unreasonable to pay so customers don't get scary looking dialog boxes
popping up.  If it's just for internal use, or with groups that can
handle an explanation of what the scary dialog box is, you can generate
your own one for free, you don't get a 3rd 'neutral' party that will
confirm that you are who you say you are, but you will get SSL
encryption.

--Brent

On Fri, 2002-12-20 at 12:34, Kyle Accardi wrote:
> Matt King wrote:
> 
> > Yeah it's for commercial use, so I can't have scary dialog boxes coming
> > up.  
> 
> Doesn't seem to bother my bank,
> https://www.pcbanking.washingtonmutual.com/logon/

The reason it does that is because the Issued to CN (Common Name) does
not match the domain name you are visiting when you access their site. 
If you select "View Certificate", you'll see that it is in fact signed
by Verisign.

They could fix it by adding their "pcbanking.washingtonmutual.com" to
one of the standard X.509 version 3 extension fields:

See: Section 4.2.1.7  Subject Alternative Name

http://www.pdxlinux.org/doc/RFC/proposed-standard/rfc2459.txt.gz

try /usr/bin/cupsconfig

Don't seem to have a tool for switching between the two (RH7.3), but both of 
those apps are in my gnome menu (Programs | System)

When launching the CUPs tool, I get this:

	CUPS must be running in order to use this configuration tool.
	Please start CUPS by running
		"/sbin/service cups start"
	as root.

	If you are currently running a different print server (such as 		
	LPRng), you may have to turn it off before CUPS can be started, e.g.
	by running
		"/sbin/service lpd stop"
	as root.

	To switch print systems permanently, use
		"/usr/sbin/alternatives --config print"

So there's some clues.  Also, type
	#apropos cups

xinetd  824 root    6u  IPv4   1817       TCP *:printer (LISTEN)

Dirk

In-Reply-To: <1040173844.12804.83.camel@bittersweet.hegbloom.net>
