I've just installed Mandrake 9...

Something strange that i've noticed is that every other time I boot up
this machine the mouse doesn't work - it apparently conflicts with the
modem.  I'm using a PCI modem and mouse plugged into the aux port.

The following link was made for /dev/modem:
/dev/modem -> /dev/tts/4

What the heck is /dev/tts/4 (does it mean serial port 4)?  I'm used to the
serial devices being named something like: /dev/ttyS0 (I guess I'm behind
the times :)

/proc/pci lists the following for the modem (this is the bootup where the
mouse works, though):
  Bus  0, device  11, function  0:
    Serial controller: US Robotics/3Com 56K FaxModem Model 5610 (rev 1).
      IRQ 5.
      I/O at 0xd000 [0xd007].

I also notice that looking into /proc/interrupt that the mouse has
interrupt 12, though I'm not too sure what ioport addresses it's on.

It would seem that perhaps  the pnp bios is assigning IRQs
or I/O ports differently on differently each time it boots (?)

Phil

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Dec 21 09:53:03 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat Dec 21 09:53:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] No printing in RH 8
In-Reply-To: <1040432828.1311.770.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212210951280.7364-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>

On 20 Dec 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:

> root]# /usr/sbin/lsof -i :515
> COMMAND PID USER   FD   TYPE DEVICE SIZE NODE NAME
> xinetd  824 root    6u  IPv4   1817       TCP *:printer (LISTEN)
> 
> Adding the /usr did the trick, and thus my machine's answer.

I haven't seen xinetd used as an lpr launcher before...

You'll want to poke around /etc/xinetd.conf and /etc/xinetd.d/* and 
look for something that looks as if it launches lpr or cups.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From bspears at easystreet.com  Sat Dec 21 10:14:03 2002
From: bspears at easystreet.com (Bill Spears)
Date: Sat Dec 21 10:14:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] No printing in RH 8
In-Reply-To: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0212210951280.7364-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
References: 
	<Pine.LNX.4.44.0212210951280.7364-100000@glenfiddich.cse.ogi.edu>
Message-ID: <1040465647.3744.25.camel@apollo.spears.org>

On Sun, 2002-12-22 at 01:52, Paul Heinlein wrote:
> On 20 Dec 2002, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> 
> > root]# /usr/sbin/lsof -i :515
> > COMMAND PID USER   FD   TYPE DEVICE SIZE NODE NAME
> > xinetd  824 root    6u  IPv4   1817       TCP *:printer (LISTEN)
> > 
> > Adding the /usr did the trick, and thus my machine's answer.
> 
> I haven't seen xinetd used as an lpr launcher before...
> 
> You'll want to poke around /etc/xinetd.conf and /etc/xinetd.d/* and 
> look for something that looks as if it launches lpr or cups.
> 
> --Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>
> 
> 

You're right about  lpr, but xinetd does launch cups-lpd if you tell it
to by setting disable=no. lpd is launched by default during boot, but
this can be changed by running "redhat-switch-printer" which makes all
the changes to the alternatives system so that cups is started and so
that lpr, lpq etc work.

From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Sat Dec 21 11:25:05 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Dec 21 11:25:05 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Athlon performance
In-Reply-To: <1040465316.3802.14.camel@apollo.spears.org>
References: <1040465316.3802.14.camel@apollo.spears.org>
Message-ID: <1040498637.12265.14.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Sat, 2002-12-21 at 02:08, Bill Spears wrote:
> According to RH up2date, a kernel rpm built for the athlon (this machine
> is actually a Duron) is available. Will I get much of a performance gain
> by installing it and are there any gotchas I should know about?

Yes you'll get a little boost in performance - but the kernel is really
only one small part of performance... optimizing the big apps on the
system causes a greater increase in speed.

Gotchas:

RH Compiled the kernel likely with a bajillion wierd patches.  I like
compiling my own kernel - I know exactly what is in it, what is enabled,
and nothing I don't want is there, eating up a few KB of RAM.

The kernel would likely be compiled with GCC 3.x in order to get any
real Athlon optimizations.  I haven't had any problems with GCC 3.2
compiling kernels... but some have.

From info5 at csl.cc  Sat Dec 21 18:36:05 2002
From: info5 at csl.cc (Consorcio Software Libre)

Subject: [PLUG] [Off-Topic] Free Software Consortium in search of Consultants and Agents in your area.

We would like to invite you to be a founding members of the FSC either as a
Consultant and/or an Agent.

http://www.fsconsortium.com

On the main page you will find links to subscribe as consultant and/or agent.

Free Software Consortium is a multinational consortium established to link the
companies and the independent consultants that use and promote free software.

One of the bigger obstacles to the development of the free software services
market is the fear of many companies to establish contracts with independent
consultants who do not have support of a well known Company, Corporation or
Consortium.  Questioning quality, support, experience and capability to
successfully complete a project are the companies manager's main concerns when
considering the option of migrating their systems to free software.

Like you, we know the excellent quality that Free Software offers.
We have complete confidence that Free Software is going to be the platform of
the future. That is why it's so important to work and consolidate together to
solve the problem mentioned above.

Free Software Consortium intends to fill this void joining the best free
software companies and consultants at the national and international level.

By joining to Free Software Consortium you or your company will have the
following benefits:

1. Possibility of being hired by other Consortium members.
2. Possibility of hiring other Consortium members.
3. Use of the Consortium image and name with your clients.
4. Use of the Consortium's resources like Publicity Brochures, Business Cards,
Banners for presentations and events, financial presentations, publicity
articles for the press and magazines, support via mailing list and forums with
the Consortium's members, marketing and communication assistance, CD's and
manuals from the Consortium, site and mail hosting (yourarea.fsc.cc) and other
future services.
5. Representation of the FS Consortium in your area to share administrative,
legal and marketing resources between the Consultant members in your area.

Free Software Consortium will establish a contract with an Agent company which
will have exclusive representation in it's area, in charge of organizing the
consultants in the area.  This Agent company will provide the administrative
services, marketing and sales with the local customers.

>From the business generated by the Free Software Consortium, the Agent company
will receive 20% of the value of the contract, and the Consultant or 
Consulting
company will receive 80%.

The Free Software Consortium is developing a new business model and invites 
you
to join as a founding member and contribute in developing this new business
model.  We need your valuable help to give us ideas and comments. Please write
to info at fsconsortium.com


Thank you for your attention.


Free Software Consortium
http://www.fsconsortium.com
info at fsc.cc




From kevinc at dOink.COM  Sat Dec 21 18:57:03 2002
From: kevinc at dOink.COM (Kevin Cosgrove)
Date: Sat Dec 21 18:57:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Can't access CDROM 
In-Reply-To: <20021221170232.D8BB22FEA6@joseph.doink.com> 
Message-ID: <20021222024349.C43A12FEA6@joseph.doink.com>

On 21 December 2002 at 9:02, Kevin Cosgrove <kevinc at dOink.COM> wrote:

> I've been playing around with backup/recovery software on a spare 
> computer.  My last test, like all but one previous test, was a 
> failure.  So, I popped in my Mandrake auto-install floppy and the 
> Mandrake CD.  The auto-install program can't access the CDROM 
> anymore.  I tweaked my BIOS to boot from CDROM before floppy and put 
> in a boot CD.  Neither my Mandrake boot CD nor my Redhat boot CD are 
> recognized as boot media.
> 
> Any ideas how I can get my CDROM working again?  I won't be able to 
> recover this machine without it.

I figured it out.  My reasoning is that if the restore left my IDE 
drive in a weird state, and the CDROM is on the same IDE bus, then 
fixing the state of the hard disk could allow the CDROM to work.  I 
booted tomsrtbt from floppy, ran 'mke2fs -j' and 'mkswap' for all my 
hard drive partitions, ejected and reloaded a CD, and mounted a CD 
while still running tomsrtbt.  All was well at that point.  Now the 
CDROM drive can be accessed by other boot sequences as well.

TTFN....






From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Sat Dec 21 19:30:05 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Sat Dec 21 19:30:05 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Linux Ethernet Status, Diagnostic, and Setup Utilities
Message-ID: <1040528195.1367.52.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

All,

Some of you remember the days when we could set the Ethernet device's
EEPROM flags with a DOS-based utility. Well, here's a collection of
Ethernet device utilities for Linux:

  http://www.scyld.com/diag/index.html#mii-diag

I greatly improved network transfer speed on the internal subnet hosts
by using the mii-diag utility to set the devices to full-duplex. A side
benefit of this is that my NFS clients are more responsive during heavy
load as they are not working so hard on the Ethernet transfer.

Note that mii-diag worked on both the Tulip and the RealTek without
modification. Several other models are supported.


-Cooper

covered.  I made a lot of assumptions, but nothing too weird, I think.

On 21 Dec 2002, Cooper Stevenson wrote:
> I am forwarding this from one of my clients. What do you make of this?
> 
> I'm trying to install XINE for DVD playback.  I have
> compiled/installed xine-lib and dependencies without problem, but now
> I cannot compile the xine-ui.  Errors out at the end as follows:
> 
> Making all in Imlib-light
> make[3]: Entering directory
> `/home/moreland/DL/xine-ui-0.9.13/src/Imlib-light'
[snip]
> gcc -DHAVE_CONFIG_H -I. -I. -I../.. -I../.. -I../.. -I../../readline
> -I../../readline -I../../src -I../../src -I../../src/common
> -I../../src/common -I../../src/xitk/xine-toolkit
> -I../../src/xitk/xine-toolkit -I/usr/local/include -g -O2 -O3 -pipe
> -fomit-frame-pointer -falign-functions=4 -falign-loops=4
> -falign-jumps=4 -mpreferred-stack-boundary=2 -fexpensive-optimizations
> -fschedule-insns2 -fno-strict-aliasing -ffast-math -funroll-loops
> -finline-functions -mcpu=athlon -Wall -D_FILE_OFFSET_BITS=64 -c
> cache.c -fPIC -DPIC -o cache.lo

OK...

> cc1: warning: changing search order for system directory
> "/usr/local/include"
> cc1: warning:   as it has already been specified as a non-system
> directory

This is saying that /usr/local/include is already included as a system
directory, but by explicitly stating it, you're putting it at the end of
the search instead of at the beginning with the other system include
directories.  This is basically just a search-order thing says to use the
explicitly denoted directories first in the case of a name conflict, but
also effects how the include files are referenced in the source.

> In file included from Imlib.h:4,
>                  from cache.c:3:
> Imlib_types.h:1:22: X11/Xlib.h: No such file or directory
> Imlib_types.h:2:23: X11/Xutil.h: No such file or directory
> Imlib_types.h:3:23: X11/Xatom.h: No such file or directory
> Imlib_types.h:4:21: X11/Xos.h: No such file or directory
> Imlib_types.h:8:34: X11/extensions/shape.h: No such file or directory

That's your real error right there.

The following:

> In file included from Imlib.h:4,
>                  from cache.c:3:
> Imlib_types.h:73: parse error before "Pixmap"
[snip]
> Imlib_types.h:113: field `x' has incomplete type
> Imlib_types.h:135: confused by earlier errors, bailing out

to there is all just errors resulting from trying to use data from headers
that weren't included.

> make[3]: *** [cache.lo] Error 1
> make[3]: Leaving directory
> `/home/moreland/DL/xine-ui-0.9.13/src/Imlib-light'
> make[2]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
> make[2]: Leaving directory `/home/moreland/DL/xine-ui-0.9.13/src'
> make[1]: *** [all-recursive] Error 1
> make[1]: Leaving directory `/home/moreland/DL/xine-ui-0.9.13'
> make: *** [all-recursive-am] Error 2

And that all means that it's dumping out of the compile process and
putting you back where you were.

Seems to me like your X11 headers aren't where your system wants them to
be or are referenced in such a way in the source as to not be
found.

Where are your X11 headers?  (Try `locate Xos.h`)

If they're in /usr/local/include/X11, then you might want to remove the
-I/usr/local/include from the Makefiles (or wipe the directory, dump out
the tarball again and run the confugure without explicitly including
/usr/local/include).  This leaves /usr/local/include in its proper
position in the search path.

If they're somewhere else, make sure the somewhere else is either a system
include or explicitly defined in that massive gcc command.  You may have
to use a --with-x= flag on your configure script.

If they're not on your system at all, then you either don't have X or
didn't compile it yourself.  If that's the case, then get the X11
development package for that distribution and insall it.

J.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sun Dec 22 18:15:04 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sun Dec 22 18:15:04 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Getting MySQL running
In-Reply-To: <3E0659A9.AD5B407F@attbi.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212221806340.20142-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sun, 22 Dec 2002, Richard Steffens wrote:

> mysql_install_db
> safe_mysqld --user=mysql &
> 
> The first command seems to have worked; at least there weren't any error
> messages. The second command starts, and then stops. Here's what I get:
> 
> --------------------------
> [root at nec bin]# safe_mysqld --user=mysql &
> [1] 26422
> [root at nec bin]# Starting mysqld daemon with databases from
> /var/lib/mysql
> 021222 16:26:11  mysqld ended     
> --------------------------

Look in /var/lib/mysql/$(hostname).err. There are many possible 
causes, a couple of which are

1. The 'mysql' user doesn't have r/w privs to /var/lib/mysql or the 
   files in /var/lib/mysql/mysql. A simple chown will fix you up.

2. You're using the innodb table format (*.MYI) but haven't added the
   requisite innodb_* settings into my.cnf. See the InnoDB stuff in 
   the online MySQL manual for a generic set of settings.

3. It's linked to a library it can't find. Run ldd against the mysqld 
   binary to find out.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Sun Dec 22 22:46:03 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Sun Dec 22 22:46:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Ethernet Activation Question
In-Reply-To: <1040620805.1443.2.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0212222241350.12872-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

First of all, you control the order of what's eth0 and what's eth1, this
is done in modules.conf, like this:
alias eth0 3c509
alias eth1 off

Now PCI card (3COM in this example) will be eth0, and eth1 will be
disabled. If you give the module for eth1, they'll both be active.
As far as what's configured on boot, this is controlled by scripts in
/etc/sysconfig/network-scripts. You should have ifcfg-eth0, ifcfg-eth1,
etc for every interface you want to come up on boot. Each file has stuff
like IP address, netmask, etc. Pay attention to the gateway settings, only
one of your interfaces should provide the default route, so in
/etc/sysconfig/network don't forget to specify GATEWAY and GATEWAYDEV.
Look at "route -n" output, you should have exactly one default route.

On 22 Dec 2002, Robbert van Andel wrote:

MPlayer is hard to install, bu only if the RPMs from FreshRPMs.net don't
want to install on your system, or they don't have the ones you want.
I'd ignore the security vulnerability thingie, unless you're installing it
on some school system full of nosy students.
MPlayer can play just about anything you can throw at it, and most of the
time it figures out what codecs to use all by itself. On the other hand,
if you want to use its GUI, it's cumbersome, and if you need to ask a
question to developers, don't bother, here is the universal answer sheet:
1) Go RTFM (use this answer if this is the first time you ask the
question)
2) Go RTFM you asshole (use this answer second and all other times)

On Sun, 2002-12-22 at 22:45, Fedor G. Pikus wrote:
> First of all, you control the order of what's eth0 and what's eth1, this
> is done in modules.conf, like this:
> alias eth0 3c509
> alias eth1 off
> 
> Now PCI card (3COM in this example) will be eth0, and eth1 will be
> disabled. If you give the module for eth1, they'll both be active.
> As far as what's configured on boot, this is controlled by scripts in
> /etc/sysconfig/network-scripts. You should have ifcfg-eth0, ifcfg-eth1,
> etc for every interface you want to come up on boot. Each file has stuff
> like IP address, netmask, etc. Pay attention to the gateway settings, only
> one of your interfaces should provide the default route, so in
> /etc/sysconfig/network don't forget to specify GATEWAY and GATEWAYDEV.
> Look at "route -n" output, you should have exactly one default route.
> 
> On 22 Dec 2002, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> > I have a webserver that has an onboard nic (eth0) and a pci nic (eth1).
> > I disabled eth0 in bios because the NIC would not work with Red Hat
> > 7.3.  When I booted the computer, both nics were discovered by Red Hat,
> > with eth0 active and eth1 inactive.  I was unable to pass any traffic on
> > eth0 (obviously), so I removed it and activated eth1.  I actually
> > removed eth0 because on every boot, eth0 would be activated and eth1
> > would be inactivated.  Now, I have only the one NIC and whenever I boot,
> > eth1 is inactive.  What do I need to do to make eth1 activate on boot?

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Mon Dec 23 01:31:03 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Mon Dec 23 01:31:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Ethernet Activation Question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.21.0212230101450.4850-100000@shaft.bitmine.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0212230122060.12872-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

One passes parameter to the kernel at boot.
I've only done it in a PC which had two cards of the same make, the
parameter there was something like this:
ether=5,0x220,eth0 ether=3,0x280,eth1
so you tell the kernel which one is eth0 and which is eth1 by IRQ, not by
card model (I don't know if you can tie eth0 to the card model or not,
does not seem to be any place for it in the syntax of ether option).
The simplest way to find the IRQ and IO address is to boot the kernel
without thethe parameters, run ifconfig and see what you have there, it's
under Interrupt: and Base address:.
Of course if cards get moved around (or on PCI bus IRQs get reassigned)
you're kind of screwed, so I suggest keeping an entry in lilo to boot the
kernel without these options (just in case probing the old IRQ under new
configuration hangs the kernel). With GRUB it's less of a problem because
you can edit its bool lines duiring boot.


On Mon, 23 Dec 2002, Jeme A Brelin wrote:
> This reminds me of a question related to a problem I had several months

> I'm trying to set up a way to connect to a server and start gnome

> out.  I've read several websites on using ssh-agent or ssh -X, etc.  
> The problem is, I'm not able to see the session start on my local
> machine, although I'm able to start it on the other machine.  None
> of the documentation I found tells me how to start use gnome
> remotely while I'm currently using gnome on my local machine.

> machine, while I'm using gnome on it?

I'm a bit unclear as to what you want to do:

1. Run a single GNOME app on <remotehost> and have it display itself 
   on <localhost>?

2. Run a full GNOME desktop, window manager included, on <remotehost> 
   and have it display itself on <localhost>?

If you're looking for #1, please post to the list the shell commands 
you've been using to launch the remote application. We'll help you 
decipher the output and/or error messages.

If you're looking for #2, then ssh by itself isn't the tool you need. 
If <remotehost> is not on your local, trusted LAN, you'll want to look 
a VNC or TightVNC. If it is on your LAN, and you've got some bandwidth 
to spare, then you can use X directly.

Either way, let us know.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Mon Dec 23 11:02:03 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Mon Dec 23 11:02:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Libranet fun for the holidays
Message-ID: <200212231102.14066.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

Here's a quick Libranet report, for anyone who's been thinking of giving it a 
try. Libranet is a user-friendly Debian distribution; under the hood, it's 
good ole Debian 3.0, Woody. It's a great desktop Linux, everything pretty 
much just works: CD burners, multimedia, all the usual huge glop of 
productivity apps. 3d hardware acceleration is still a pain, nVidia drivers 
are the biggest pain of all. 

It recognized my Wacom tablet and Epson scanner with no problem, had no 
trouble with onboard sound.

The default WM is IceWM. On my old Celeron 333, it's peppier than anything 
else I've had on it. There is no custom install, there are only package 
groups to select, not individual packages. There is a base install option, 
then add individual packages later.

2.0 is available for free, 2.7 costs $59.95. Not much in the way of 
documentation, just use Debian docs I guess. For me it's worth the money to 
get up and running quickly, with a minimum of hassle. IceWM, for example, can 
be a real chore to customize and configure; having it install in a usable 
configuration is a nice time-saver. Installation itself is fast n easy, none 
of the famous Debian pain and agony. Stable as all heck, I've been pounding 
on it since the first of the month on two desktops and one laptop, no 
stability issues at all. As near as I can tell, it's Debian with a good 
installation and nice useful desktop stuff added, without gumming up the 
underlying system with all kinds of crazy stuff, the way the other major 
distros like to do.


-- 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Carla Schroder
Bratgrrl Computing
www.bratgrrl.com
This message brought to you by
Libranet 2.7 and Kmail
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Dec 23 19:47:02 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: Mon Dec 23 19:47:02 2002
Subject: [PLUG] X Forwarding across SSH, Xnest
In-Reply-To: <1040627744.2930.3.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1040627744.2930.3.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <1040701597.20275.25.camel@bittersweet.hegbloom.net>

On Sun, 2002-12-22 at 23:15, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> In other words, how do I use the remote gnome session on my local
> machine, while I'm using gnome on it?

You probably don't need to run a full gnome session on the remote
machine.  Set up your SSH so that X forwarding is on.  (RTFM; breifly,
use the -X switch when you connect, provided it's allowed server side.) 
Then, after you ssh over, you should be able to just start X programs,
and have them connect transparently across the ssh tunnel to the X
server in front of you.  If you turn on compression in the ssh, you'll
get better performance across low bandwidth connections.

If you really do want to run an entire session that way, you can try
using "Xnest" - again, RTFM - and an XDMCP capable display manager
running on the other end.  If you need that to happen across a secure
connection, then learn how to forward ports through your SSH tunnel. 
It's all in the SSH manual, but you'll have to put the peices together
yourself.  I think it can be done, but I've never tried it. 
Alternatively, you could run the Xnest at that end, with "-query
localhost" there.  I don't know how well that works.  That will
certainly work over a default SSH with -X enabled.

 me at myhost:~/% Xnest -query xdmcp-host





From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Mon Dec 23 20:48:03 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: Mon Dec 23 20:48:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] SSH Question
In-Reply-To: <104067681201@leo.hosting4u.net>
References: <104067681201@leo.hosting4u.net>
Message-ID: <1040705240.15568.7.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Mon, 2002-12-23 at 12:53, robbert at vafam.com wrote:
> I'm trying to run a full ssh gnome session from my local machine.  I'm able to ssh in using the command ssh-agent gnome-session 192.168.1.150.  After logging in, I get an error, something to the affect "You are already running gnome on 192.168.1.101:0."  The question I have is how do I run this remote gnome session on 192.168.1.101:1?  I was able to do it locally, running two gnome sessions, one under F7 and one under F8 (sorry, I don't know the correct terminology, just that I get to my gnome session by pressing F7 and get to other screens by using the other function keys).  I do no know what I need to add to the gnome-agent command parameters to get the remote gnome session to start under F8.
> 
> Any suggestions?

Yep.

I'm assuming you're using some sort of key system for ssh authentication
that doesn't require you to intervene at all.

Well, either way, this'll work.

Start your SSH session in an xterm in Display :1.

When you start that second X session which will be running things on the
other machine, use a special .xinitrc that either ssh's in to the other
system like so:

ssh -X -C 192.168.1.150 /opt/gnome/bin/gnome-session

(assuming there you have passphrase-less key authentication set up)

or starts an xterm from where you can run ssh yourself (and be there to
type in your passphrase).

I hope you're getting what I'm saying - if you want to run gnome in the
second X server, run SSH from a terminal on that second server.

Then all will work well.

I, personally, use TightVNC for remote access of systems... it's
definitely a bit quicker than actual X over lower-end connections
(10BaseT and down) but for faster connections (100Mbps type stuff) I
find running X apps over an ssh tunnel is faster.  YMMV.

From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Dec 23 20:55:05 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: Mon Dec 23 20:55:05 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Remote Xnest over SSH uHOWTO
In-Reply-To: <104067681201@leo.hosting4u.net>
References: <104067681201@leo.hosting4u.net>
Message-ID: <1040705681.20275.31.camel@bittersweet.hegbloom.net>

Log into the remote machine, with "ssh -X".

Run "xauth list" and "echo $DISPLAY".

Get the magic cookie for your DISPLAY, and run:

xauth add localhost:N MIT-MAGIC-COOKIE ...

... replacing N with an arbitrary display number for the Xnest's
display, and the ... with the cookie listed previously.

Run:

Xnest :N -cookie ... >/dev/null 2>&1 </dev/null &

... and wait for it to appear.

Now you can connect to it like:

xterm -display localhost:N

You could run an entire Gnome session on it if you wanted to.  If that
remote host is running GDM, KDM, or XDM, you could probably run:

Xnest :N -query locahost

... and not need the Xauth magic and the -cookie argument to Xnest.

From judah at opusnet.com  Mon Dec 23 23:24:02 2002

Subject: [PLUG] SSH Question

You might also just try something like this.. one of my favorites.. 

ssh -X -C -f machine.name application

ssh -X -l root -f machine.name up2date

-C compression
-X forward X 
-l username
-f the last parameter is the application you wish to run.. 

Do not run this with & to put into the background as it will do that on
it's own.. This will send the desired application back to your local X
server through an ssh tunnel.. 

A-

There is a non-hacky way to obtain Russian keyboard
input, as you can see: ??????

This was obtained by changing a line in
/etc/X11/XFree86Config-4 from 

Option      "XkbLayout"          "us_group3"

to

Option      "XkbLayout"          "ru"
Option      "XkbOptions"         "grp:shift_toggle"

an acquired language, me for example, are accustomed
to the qwerty keyboard, and can type more easily with
a different keyboard mapping than the one used by the
Russians. Is there an easy way to do that? For
example,  ?, the Russian symbol for F, should be on
our F key, but it's on our A key. That's the key I
pressed to obtain it after switching alphabets.

From jeme at brelin.net  Tue Dec 24 00:06:03 2002
From: jeme at brelin.net (Jeme A Brelin)
Date: Tue Dec 24 00:06:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] FrontPage Extensions Setup
In-Reply-To: <1040712343.1359.38.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On 23 Dec 2002, Robbert van Andel wrote:
> I'm following the instructions on setting up front page extensions,
> yet am running into a problem.  I figured it would be safer to patch
> the server for the extensions instead of having the stall script do
> it.  Following the instructions, I type:
> 
> patch ?p0 <fp-patch-apache_1.3.19

Well, since you're using patch with -p and redirecting from a file,
perhaps you could show us your current working directory?

(By the way, how was this mail sent?  Your - isn't a -.  Our encodings are
not entirely compatible here, but they are down below where you've pasted
the error output.)

> I then get the following error:
> 
> ./mod_frontpage.c.rej
> can't find file to patch at input line 872
> Perhaps you used the wrong -p or --strip option?
> The text leading up to this was:
> --------------------------
> |--- ./src/include/httpd.h.rtr	Mon Feb 26 07:18:42 2001
> |+++ ./src/include/httpd.h	Mon Feb 26 07:21:15 2001
> --------------------------
> File to patch: 
> 
> This is not in the instructions on installing front page extensions.

Of course it's not in the instructions, it's an error!

Where is the ./src/include/httpd.h relative to your working directory?

patch expects ./src/include/httpd.h to exist.  This is a relative path
(i.e., relative to where you run the command).

You can either change the argument to -p or change your working directory
to suit that relative path.

Is that the only file modified by the patch?

From judah at opusnet.com  Tue Dec 24 10:33:02 2002
From: judah at opusnet.com (Aaron Baer)
Date: Tue Dec 24 10:33:02 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Making a RPM from a tarball
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212240852260.10004-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212240852260.10004-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <1040754741.5769.13.camel@localhost.localdomain>

I put together a spec file for this .. but there is something wrong
during the configure process on my machine and I don't feel like
figuring it out more than I already have.. if things are kosher this
should work for you issuing the command 
rpmbuild -ba /path/to/spec/file/dosemu.spec

This seems to be a handy quick reference for building rpms.. 

http://erizo.ucdavis.edu/~dmk/notes/RPMs/Creating_RPMs.html

the following is the spec file.. dosemu.spec.

A-


# RPM specfile for dosemu 

%define nam 	dosemu
%define ver	1.1.4

Name:     	dosemu
Version: 	1.1.4
Release:	1.1.4
Copyright:	GPL/LGPL
BuildRoot:	/var/tmp/%{nam}-%{ver}-root
Docdir:         /usr/share/doc
URL:		http://www.dosemu.org/
Epoch:		0
Source0:	dosemu-1.1.4.tgz
Summary:	Dos Emulation
Group:		Applications/Accessories

%description
DOSEMU stands for DOS Emulation, and is a linux application that 
enables the Linux OS to run many DOS programs - including some 
DPMI apps. Linux is a powerful, "Unix-like" freeware Operating System.

%files
%defattr(-, root, root)
%doc COPYING ChangeLog README
/usr/lib/*.so.*
/usr/bin/*
/usr/share/man/man1/*
/usr/share/man/man7/*
/usr/lib/pix/*


%package -n dosemu-devel
Summary:	Pilot development header files.
Group:		Development/Libraries
Requires:	%{nam} = %{PACKAGE_VERSION}

%description -n dosemu-devel
This package contains the development headers that are used
to build the dosemu package. 

%files -n dosemu-devel
%defattr(-, root, root)
/usr/include/*
/usr/lib/*.so
/usr/lib/*.a
/usr/lib/*.la


# $RPM_COMMAND is an environment variable used by the Ximian build
# system to control the build process with finer granularity than RPM
# normally allows.  This specfile will function as expected by RPM if
# $RPM_COMMAND is unset.  If you are not the Ximian build system,
# feel free to ignore it.

%prep
case "${RPM_COMMAND:-all}" in
dist)
%setup  -q -D -n dosemu-1.1.4
    ;;
all)
%setup  -q -n dosemu-1.1.4
    ;;
esac
case "${RPM_COMMAND:-all}" in
dist|all)
    ;;
esac

%build
MAKE=${MAKE:-make}
RPM_COMMAND=${RPM_COMMAND:-all}
DESTDIR=${DESTDIR:-"$RPM_BUILD_ROOT"}
ARCH=%{_target_platform}
export MAKE RPM_COMMAND DESTDIR ARCH
case "$RPM_COMMAND" in
prepare|all)
    #./configure --prefix=/usr --sysconfdir=/etc --mandir=/usr/share/man
--infodir=/usr/share/info --localstatedir=/var
    ;;
esac
case "$RPM_COMMAND" in
clean|all)
    if [ "/" != "$DESTDIR" ]; then
	rm -rf "$DESTDIR"
    fi
    ;;
esac
case "$RPM_COMMAND" in
build|all)
    ${MAKE}
    ;;
esac

%install
MAKE=${MAKE:-make}
DESTDIR=${DESTDIR:-"$RPM_BUILD_ROOT"}
# export DESTDIR
case "${RPM_COMMAND:-all}" in
install|all)
    ${MAKE} install prefix=${DESTDIR}/usr sysconfdir=${DESTDIR}/etc
mandir=${DESTDIR}/usr/share/man infodir=${DESTDIR}/usr/share/info
localstatedir=${DESTDIR}/var mandir1=${DESTDIR}/usr/share/man/man1
mandir7=${DESTDIR}/usr/share/man/man7
    ;;
esac

%clean
DESTDIR=${DESTDIR:-"$RPM_BUILD_ROOT"}
export DESTDIR
case "${RPM_COMMAND:-all}" in
clean|all)
    if [ "/" != "$DESTDIR" ]; then
	rm -rf "$DESTDIR"
    fi
    ;;
esac



==============================

On Tuesday 24 December 2002 10:28, David Fleck wrote:
> I'm building a new desktop machine soon. I pretty much know what
> components I want in it.  One thing that concerns me, though, is noise
> levels - I'd like the machine to be as quiet as possible.  (I've just
> finished fixing up a Sparcstation2 with OpenBSD 3.2, and while it looks
> spiffy holding up my monitor, it is LOUD!)
>
> So- any recommendations for quiet fans / power supplies / drives (or ways
> to muffle existing ones - I'd like to be able to leave the Sparc turned on
> without getting evil looks from the spouse).

Be sure to check out http://www.hardwareguys.com/, in addition to the many 
suggestions you're going to get for quiet components.  Inferior power 
supplies are one of the biggest sources of trouble in a system. PC Power & 
Cooling makes great power supplies, and they have quiet models. CPU fans are 
the other main source of noise. Here's a couple of links:

http://www.endpcnoise.com/cgi-bin/e/scan/fi
http://fredrik.hubbe.net/silence/cpu.html

I wish for a separate drive bay module, that can be parked any where 
convenient, and the main box stuffed away in a cabinet.

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Tue Dec 24 11:06:03 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Tue Dec 24 11:06:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] OT: comparative noise levels
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0212241008300.32133-100000@linux.sourballs.org>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0212241056590.12872-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On Tue, 24 Dec 2002, David Fleck wrote:
> So- any recommendations for quiet fans / power supplies / drives (or ways
> to muffle existing ones - I'd like to be able to leave the Sparc turned on
> without getting evil looks from the spouse).

I've just built a new PC for myself, and it's much quieter than any PC I
had before, even though it's much more powerful. What you want is quiet
fans, which means large fans. So, first of all I recommend the Zallman CPU
cooler (you can get them at Fry's or CompUSA, they are $25 at Fry's). It's
a large copper heatsink made out of thin fins which open up to the top
like a fan. The fan is mounted on a bracket, not bolted to the heatsink,
and hovers over the CPU. It's a large 80mm fan and only rotates at 1500
rpm. Next is the power supply fan, power supplies with larger fans will be
quieter, check out supplies with horizontally mounted fan (fan mounted at
the bottom of the supply instead of the back), there's more room for a
larger fan this way. I have Antek 420W supply, and it's reasonably quiet.
Finally, I discovered that 80mm case fans are almost inaudible, because
they also rotate slowly, so I put quite a few of them, and now I'm going
to line my case on the inside with sound-insulating material they sell at
Fry's (it's probably also very heat-insulating, but with 5 case fans I
don't need heat dissipation through walls).

Wilsonville, Oregon 97070           | http://www.pikus.net/~pikus/

Subject: [PLUG] Ethernet Activation Question
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0212230122060.12872-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0212230122060.12872-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

On Monday 23 December 2002 01:30, Fedor G. Pikus wrote:
> One passes parameter to the kernel at boot.
> I've only done it in a PC which had two cards of the same make, the
> parameter there was something like this:
> ether=5,0x220,eth0 ether=3,0x280,eth1
> so you tell the kernel which one is eth0 and which is eth1 by IRQ, not
> by card model (I don't know if you can tie eth0 to the card model or
> not, does not seem to be any place for it in the syntax of ether
> option). The simplest way to find the IRQ and IO address is to boot the
> kernel without thethe parameters, run ifconfig and see what you have
> there, it's under Interrupt: and Base address:.
> Of course if cards get moved around (or on PCI bus IRQs get reassigned)
> you're kind of screwed, so I suggest keeping an entry in lilo to boot
> the kernel without these options (just in case probing the old IRQ under
> new configuration hangs the kernel). With GRUB it's less of a problem
> because you can edit its bool lines duiring boot.

Hmm, I've run into this somewhere.  I think that it is actually the ports 
that control it.  At least for ISA cards!  I had a problem with this with 
some firewalls once.  There was a discussion of this on the kernel list a 
long time ago, but I cannot seem to find it in Google right now...

<from memory>
I think the probing part is done separately from the assignment to a 
specific ethX.  Once the probes are done and the right drivers are set up, 
I believe that the kernel assigns the ethX entries based on increasing 
port number.  Again, this is for ISA. Not sure about PCI.
</from memory>

You'd have to look a the code or find something in a kernel book or online 
to be sure.

Best,
Kyle

non-Latin keyboard through the inclusion of

Option      "XkbLayout"          "ru"

in the XFree86 configuration file. This gave me the
characters I wanted, but I would have preferred for
them to be arranged on different keys.

Perhaps there already is an alternative file, say
"ru-alt," that would meet my needs. The documentation
for XFree86 is so confused that I can't find out what
the legal choices are. If there were such a choice, I
would invoke it instead of "ru."

If nothing is already available for this purpose, I
would attempt to make such a file, and make it
available to the open-source community:

haven't helped me much. If I made my own file, I could
either use it to replace "ru," or (more likely) give

From athlonrob at data.4t3.com  Sat Dec 28 00:59:03 2002
From: athlonrob at data.4t3.com (AthlonRob)
Date: Sat Dec 28 00:59:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] OT: comparative noise levels
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0212241008300.32133-100000@linux.sourballs.org>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0212241008300.32133-100000@linux.sourballs.org>
Message-ID: <1040923714.18112.9.camel@duron.stpaultel.com>

On Tue, 2002-12-24 at 10:28, David Fleck wrote:

> So- any recommendations for quiet fans / power supplies / drives (or ways
> to muffle existing ones - I'd like to be able to leave the Sparc turned on
> without getting evil looks from the spouse).

Watercooling!

If you went with watercooling on a non-overclocked PC, you could keep
the whole beast quite cool with three fans - two 120mm's and the CPU
fan.  If you buy a nice 120mm fan, they'll be near silent (I saw 21db
fans a year or two back when I was digging in to this).  Water pumps are
generally near silent, as well... which leaves the loudest part of the
system being drives and the PSU... both of which can be quieted, too.

The PSU can be quieted down either by buying a 'silent' psu (I think
Zalman has one) or converting it to watercooling (google about - there's
an article for that one)...

The drives can be quieted down by - for the hard drive, buy one of those
drive kits that suspends the drive on rubber bands and for the CD type
drives - buy the spendy ones, they're generally quiet already (my DVD
drive is virtually silent and my CD-RW drive is just a little bit louder
than that - the Creative 52X drives you find for $40, on the other hand,
are like chain saws).

For a quiet PC, watercooling is the most effective means available...

--

Email and Jabber:                  |    one can never be free.
athlonrob at data dot 4t3 dot com  |




From felix.1 at canids.net  Sat Dec 28 01:02:03 2002
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Sat Dec 28 01:02:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] A "C" error
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212251700570.14854-100000@appl-ecosys.com> on Wed, 25 Dec 2002 17:07:55 PST.
Message-ID: <200212280900.gBS90rP06655@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>:
> fsmsystem.h:610: two or more data types in declaration of DB'

theory 1, you're missing a terminating semicolon on the
declaration prior to this, so it looks something like
    struct a {int a1;}
    struct b {int b1;} bvar;

theory 2, there's a #define that's doing something
non-obvious to the line.  run it through cc -E and see what
the actual code is.

theory 3, dunno.  use repeated subdivision, keep deleting
half of the input, until the problem code is isolated.  it
may be obvious then.

On Thu, 2002-12-26 at 15:08, Paul wrote:
> I would like to have my mail server send me an instant message when I get mail. I don't really care which system (Yahoo, AIM, ICQ, etc). Are there any command-line driven clients out there? How about text based client that could run as a daemon and accept command-line calls to send a message?

Last I looked there was a Jabberd transport that IM'd people when they
got email  - but that would likely require you run jabber as your IM
client.

I haven't looked too much in to it as it looked to be a bit of a PITA to
get going, but I suppose if you could ID the person it IM'd you could
set yourself up with an ICQ transport and have it IM via that (there are
also Yahoo, MSN, AIM, and other transports available).

That said, yes, there are cli IM clients, but I don't know how you'd
implament them to IM you when you got an email.

One of the more popular is centericq but there are several others
available.  I would suggest using google and freshmeat.

From felix.1 at canids.net  Sat Dec 28 11:09:03 2002
From: felix.1 at canids.net (Felix Lee)
Date: Sat Dec 28 11:09:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] emacs: search-and-replace regex
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212281025550.24260-100000@appl-ecosys.com> on Sat, 28 Dec 2002 10:31:05 PST.
Message-ID: <200212281907.gBSJ74m07733@paper-wolf-solo.tigerfood.org>

Rich Shepard <rshepard at appl-ecosys.com>:
> insensitive or not at the user's option), but not a search-and-replace using
> a regex such as .DB.

M-x query-replace-regexp, also known as C-M-%, also in
menu-bar "Search".

It's described in the Emacs manual here
  http://www.gnu.org/manual/emacs/html_node/emacs_103.html

On Thu, 2002-12-26 at 15:08, Paul wrote:
> I would like to have my mail server send me an instant message when I get mail. I don't really care which system (Yahoo, AIM, ICQ, etc). Are there any command-line driven clients out there? How about text based client that could run as a daemon and accept command-line calls to send a message?

You could install a .procmailrc file that split off a copy of each
message, looked at it to grab information from it and see if it's
important enough, then called a Perl program to send the IM.  There are
Perl modules for doing that.

Jabberd is running on jabber.pdxlinux.org.  You can use that if you
don't expect to send HUGE numbers of IM's through it, otherwise, you
should run one on your mail server.

I think it was.  I don't know what was the matter.  I did a runlevel
downa and up, and now it's working again.

I have the box set up so that "telinit 2" is safe to run remotely. 
Runlevel 2 is everything off except for SSHd and devfsd.  I then
manually restart devfsd, killall getty, manually restart sshd, then
telinit 4, and bring it all back online.  I do this after major
upgrades, where libc has been rebuilt.

Whatever it was is Just Working again.

From heinlein at attbi.com  Sat Dec 28 14:56:03 2002
From: heinlein at attbi.com (Paul Heinlein)
Date: Sat Dec 28 14:56:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Squirrelmail
In-Reply-To: <20021228090153.748bda00.paul@pflnet.ws>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212281448590.5752-100000@pecos.madboa.com>

On Sat, 28 Dec 2002, Paul wrote:

> I installed Red Hat 8. I downloaded and installed Squirrelmail
> 1.2.10. I made the suggested changes to php.ini and the required
> settings in httpd.conf (to enable php processing). I expanded the
> squirrelmail tarball, made "apache" the owner of created directory
> structure. I confirmed that the data and attachment directories are
> there. I didn't do much with the default config.php file outside of
> rename it and put my domain name in it.

The interaction between PHP and SquirrelMail is complex. I've 
encountered situations where the default Red Hat php.ini file would 
disallow functionality needed by SquirrelMail. In particular, you 
might want to play with the 'short_open_tag' and 'file_uploads' 
directives in /etc/php.ini.

--Paul Heinlein <heinlein at attbi.com>

  No, but I will.

  There are several constructs that apparently worked under the VC++
compiler that are not acceptable to gcc. Doesn't surprise me, but it's
taking a while to discover them and fix 'em up.

  I read just recently (and I don't recall just where I read it) that if an
application to be ported to linux used the Microsoft Foundation Classes in
the original it has to be rewritten. Apparently those, too, are
non-standard. As my grandmother used to say, "So? What else is new?".

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Sat Dec 28 17:24:03 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Sat Dec 28 17:24:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Adding windows hdd to grub
In-Reply-To: <1041123750.1432.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1041123750.1432.4.camel@localhost.localdomain>

On Saturday 28 December 2002 17:02, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> title Windows 98
>         root {hd1,0}
>         makeactive
>         chainloader +1
>         boot

Is this exactly as it's written in your conf file? I believe you need 
parentheses, not curly braces around (hd1,0)

also Windows need to be on the first hard drive. Either swap drive cables, or 
do this:

" If you have installed DOS (or Windows) on a non-first hard disk, you
have to use the disk swapping technique, because that OS cannot boot
from any disks but the first one. The workaround used in GRUB is the
command `map' (*note map::), like this:

     grub> map (hd0) (hd1)
     grub> map (hd1) (hd0)"

'info grub' is good and thorough, if you haven't tried it already.

From cryonv at onlinemac.com  Sat Dec 28 22:34:02 2002
From: cryonv at onlinemac.com (Piet van Weel)
Date: Sat Dec 28 22:34:02 2002
Subject: [PLUG] A "C" error
In-Reply-To: <1041118416.21515.33.camel@bittersweet.hegbloom.net>
Message-ID: <000701c2af04$3a3f9290$e6fcfea9@beta>

Hmmm...

Just wondering... and not sitting in front of my linux laptop...

#ifndef __adb
	#define __adb
 typedef struct pADB{int unused;} ADB; // line 610
#endif

I'm curious if the #ifndef is correctly stated...

#ifndef __adb
	{
	#define __adb
	typedef struct pADB {int unused;} ADB; // line 610
	}
#endif

The first one states that if __adb is not defined then #define it. The
next step... since #ifndef was taken care with the #define, then it
would be to typedef the struct. Then it would take care of the #endif.
Which by itself is no biggie... and the linker would have just oversaw
the minor error.

As it occurs in your program, I'm assuming that ADB is already defined.
Then #ifndef would be false... then the program would try to typedef the
struct again. Hence the error on line 610 of typedef-ing an already
existing struct.

The fixed version (I think) would do the #ifndef then if it was true; it
would do the #define and the typedef. Then it would exit at the #endif
statement. 

As it would occur in your program, I'm assuming that ADB is already
defined. Then #ifndef would be false, and the program would continue
onward. :)

If this fixes it please let me know... :) Of course if it doesn't let me
know also...

Piet

From karlheg at hegbloom.net  Sun Dec 29 02:02:03 2002
From: karlheg at hegbloom.net (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: Sun Dec 29 02:02:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] XEmacs mailer from Galeon for mailto URL's
Message-ID: <87r8c1m9e8.fsf@bittersweet.hegbloom.net>

I always run XEmacs with my "xg" script, that runs XEmacs with "-f
gnuserv-start", if it's not already there, otherwise calls
"gnuclient"...  Anyway, that means my XEmacs has a "gnuserv" ready
willing and able, so the "gnudoit" command can be used from Galeon to
handle "mailto:" URL's.  Here's the command for Galeon's mailer
setting...

 gnudoit '(require (quote url)) (url-mailto "%u")'

Now I can click the "reply to" clicker in Lurker and reply to a
message!  Excellent.

From aschlemm at attbi.com  Sun Dec 29 10:47:03 2002
From: aschlemm at attbi.com (Anthony Schlemmer)
Date: Sun Dec 29 10:47:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] A "C" error
In-Reply-To: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212251700570.14854-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
References: <Pine.LNX.4.44.0212251700570.14854-100000@appl-ecosys.com>
Message-ID: <200212291046.18372.aschlemm@attbi.com>

The other thing you can try is to rewrite the the statements like so and 
see if it makes any difference: 

#ifndef __adb
        #define __adb
        struct pADB {int unused;};
        typedef struct pADB ADB;
#endif

As far as I know there is nothing wrong with declaring both the struct 
and typedef in the same statement and you can probably find examples of 
this in the various C header files that exist on most Linux systems. 
The above statements compile under GCC 3.2 with no errors. 

Tony

Recently I asked for advice about using Russian fonts
in X-Windows. I have solved this by editing the
XFree86 configuration file, although this solution
only works for Netscape. Netscape provides mail, news,
and Web services, so that's most of what I would need
to do using a non-Latin font. However, I considered it
desirable to have at least basic text-editing
capabilities, too.

I opened an xterm window with a font argument (-fn).
For some reason it's also necessary to use
$xmodmap yawerty.koi8.xmm

(I have only one regular user on my system, so quite a
few things are present in my home directory that on
many systems would be installed system-wide.) At any
rate, invoking Pico then brings up an editing window,
and Cyrillic text entered into it is displayed
properly and can be saved. I would be greatly
surprised if "lpr"  
would print such a file properly, but I think I know
where to go for help on this.

Having issued "xmodmap," if I go back to Netscape the
text doesn't look right. One can reset the X-server to
fix this, but it would be more convenient to issue a
command that simply undid the effect of xmodmap.

OpenOffice has localized versions for many languages.
The Linux version for Russian is not available for
download, so I have ordered it for $3.49. 

Vim and Emacs are supposed to be capable of
internationalization. I should know how to use these
clients better anyhow, so I'll look into this. At
present files containing non-Latin text look like a
bunch of garbage when displayed by these clients.

In a sense I have "solved" my problem, but the general
issue of installing and using fonts of various kinds
interests me.Some linguists have returned in despair
to M$ after their discouraging experiences with
non-Latin fonts in a UNIX environment.

Or if you add "typedef struct ADB ADB", perhaps?  IIRC, the "typedef"
namespace is disjoint from the "struct" namespace.  Also IIRC, gcc 3.2
set to use the newest C standard will accept the original syntax, just
as a C++ compiler would.  Am I correct in that?

would assume that means it has not been translated yet.  I doubt they
are charging money for it.

Works for me in xemacs21-mule (Debian "testing").  I use the "M-x
dictionary" command, and have the Russian translation dictionaries
installed in my "dictd", and the entries are displayed in cyrillic when
I look up a word.  I assume that if you visit a file using "C-u C-x C-f"
and enter the appropriate coding system, that you can edit Cyrillic text
also.

From seniorr at aracnet.com  Sun Dec 29 13:20:05 2002
From: seniorr at aracnet.com (Russell Senior)
Date: Sun Dec 29 13:20:05 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Traceroute doesn't work
In-Reply-To: <1041195276.1404.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1041195276.1404.8.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <867kdszfo1.fsf@coulee.tdb.com>

>>>>> "Robbert" == Robbert van Andel <robbert at vafam.com> writes:

Robbert> I am having issues running traceroute on my RedHat 7.3
Robbert> machine.  When I'm logged in as root, I try to do a
Robbert> traceroute to a website like yahoo.com or vafamsound.com (my
Robbert> webserver) and am not getting anything but time outs on each
Robbert> hop.  when I traceroute to my linksys router, I get one hop
Robbert> (obviously) that shows a good traceroute result.  Why does
Robbert> this tool not work?  (I can use tracert on Windows and get to
Robbert> these two sites with no problem).

There are multiple ways that a traceroute can work.  Some traceroutes
use ICMP packets while others use UDP packets.  Sometimes ICMP packets
are administratively filtered.  If you want to check a particular TCP
port, you can use tcptraceroute, as in:

  $ tcptraceroute yahoo.com 80

Sometimes a regular ping or traceroute will appear to show a site is
unreachable, but that is because some router in between is dropping
ICMP.  The tcptraceroute utility can help in those cases.

RH7.3 starts an ipchains firewall by default from /etc/rc5.d that, if I 
remember correctly, filters ICMP. If you haven't disabled this you can do an 
ipchains -L from a root shell to see if there are any unexpected rules 
filtering traffic.

this should be (hd1)	/dev/hdb grub likes parens not curly braces.

> 
>  
> #boot=/dev/hda
> default=1
> timeout=10
> splashimage=(hd0,0)/boot/grub/splash.xpm.gz
> title Red Hat Linux (2.4.18-18.8.0debug)

> title Red Hat Linux (2.4.18-18.8.0)
>         root (hd0,0)
>         kernel /boot/vmlinuz-2.4.18-18.8.0 ro root=LABEL=/ hdc=ide-scsi

> title Windoze
>         rootnoverify [hd1,0]
should be 

map (hd0) (hd1)
map (hd1) (hd0)
rootnoverify (hd0,0)

note that the maps occure before the booting, and secondly that
everthing is using parens and not brackets.
>         makeactive
>         chainloader +1
>         boot
>         #----
>         map (hd0) (hd1)
>         map (hd1) (hd0
> 

and if I were doing this for win98, the way I would do it is.
title=Win
map (hd0) (hd1)
map (hd1) (hd0)
root (hd0,0)
chainloader +1

and that should work

Run this code through preprocessor (gcc -E) and try to compile the output,
which will be a C file with no #defines or any other preprocessor
directives. If it does not compile and you can't figure out why, post the
lines on which you get the error. If you see why it does not compile then
try to figure out why preprocessor generated the result you got instead of
what you expected.

> Are there distros that are better-suited for dual booting, laptops or Thinkpads
> in particular?

Can't speak to XP, but I've had no trouble installing Linux on a
Thinkpad 390X (400 MHz Celeron, 96 Mb RAM, PCMCIA ethernet card, combo
floppy/CD drive). The first one I tried was the RH 7.1 version
distributed by the K12LTSP project. I didn't try dual booting that one.
Next, I cleaned that one off, reinstalled Win98 from the IBM supplied
recovery CD, and did a network install of Debian woody. No problems to
speak of there, either as far as the installation itself went. (I had
trouble getting the ability to add filters to the GIMP, but it probably
doesn't relate to dual booting). Dual booting from Lilo worked with no
problems. Finally, I cleaned that off, reinstalled Win98 again, and
installed RH 8.0. No problems dual booting with GRUB. 

> What XP system files should be backed up first?

Can't help you with that one. I'm hoping that Win98 is the last MS OS I
have to put up with. I haven't bought a new machine with the latest
thing from Redmond installed for a few years, now.
 
> Should I do a "laptop" install or "custom?"

In each case, I selected "everything" when the time came to choose which
kind of installation. I'm using the machine as a learning experience,
mostly, although now that I have the RH version of the GIMP, I can, and
do use the LoG filter that I was able to add.

From pluglist at bratgrrl.com  Mon Dec 30 09:28:03 2002
From: pluglist at bratgrrl.com (Carla Schroder)
Date: Mon Dec 30 09:28:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Re: Windows in Grub
In-Reply-To: <1041260631.1358.21.camel@localhost.localdomain>
References: <1041260631.1358.21.camel@localhost.localdomain>
Message-ID: <200212300929.08948.pluglist@bratgrrl.com>

On Monday 30 December 2002 07:03, Dirk Ouellette wrote:
> I returned hdb to hd1 in grub and Windows booted fine. Now I need to
> figure out how to get Windoz to accept my D-Link DFE 530TX+ nic which
> Linux recognized and uses just fine. My win 98 hdd has no screen for
> such a nic and can't seem to locate it.
> Dirk

You need either the driver disk for the D-Link card, or download the drivers. 
Even Win2k doesn't have a driver for it, it's always a separate install. Be 
sure to check Device Manager, if there is an entry for your card delete it 
before installing the new drivers, or windows gets confused.

Subject: [PLUG] Why is grep truncating output?
Message-ID: <200212301155.59222.scott_list@mischko.com>

I'm using RedHat Linux 7.3 with 2.4.18-3 kernel.  When I do ps -ef | grep ' ' 
(or grep for other things) it truncates the output to 80 columns (and grep 
doesn't match stuff beyond the 80th column either).

If I do set | grep ' ' the output is not truncated.

If I grep a file (grep ' ' .bash_history) I don't get truncated output.

Can someone explain what's going on and how to fix this?

Thanks!
Scott




From russj at dimstar.net  Mon Dec 30 12:10:06 2002
From: russj at dimstar.net (Russ Johnson)
Date: Mon Dec 30 12:10:06 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Why is grep truncating output?
In-Reply-To: <200212301155.59222.scott_list@mischko.com>
References: <200212301155.59222.scott_list@mischko.com>
Message-ID: <3E10A7F8.4090402@dimstar.net>

Tell 'ps' to output wide date like so:

ps awwwx | grep whatever

'w' = wide
'ww' = wider
'www' = widest

Russ

From alex at daniloff.com  Mon Dec 30 13:18:03 2002

From fedorp at wv.mentorg.com  Mon Dec 30 14:20:05 2002
From: fedorp at wv.mentorg.com (Fedor G. Pikus)
Date: Mon Dec 30 14:20:05 2002
Subject: [PLUG] A good 2D-3D gaming video card for =?iso-8859-1?q?Linux=3F?=
In-Reply-To: <200212302119.gBULJd926296@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.31.0212301406340.12872-100000@lorien.wv.mentorg.com>

2D? Pretty much any high-end card will do, Matrox has probably the best
reputation for 2D quality, and good Linux support. 2D parts of Radeon and
NVidia cards are also well suported, and you'd need a really
good monitor to notice the difference in quality, if there is indeed any.
Also, other features like DVI, dual DVI, TV in/out, etc, may be more
important than the tiny differences in 2D quality between different
high-end cards.
For 3D, if you want the ultimate gaming machine running Linux, there is
only one option, one of NVidia's high-end cards (Geforce4 Ti 4600 is the
ultimate in both performance and price, although the next generation of
NVidia cards should be out very soon, at even more ultimate price). Ti
4400 seems like a good compromise, but stay away from all Geforce MX
cards.
You will depend on NVidia's binary drivers. That could be a problem if you
use a development kernel, or patch your kernel with some pervasive enough
patch which breaks the NVidia kernel module (which you'll need to compile
for your kernel from source they provide, unless you use unmodified RedHat
or Suse or Mandrake kernels, in which case you can also compile the
source, or use the module they compiled for you). However, if the binary
drivers work for you, then they work very well.

From iconoklastic at yahoo.com  Mon Dec 30 16:14:03 2002
From: iconoklastic at yahoo.com (Robert Kopp)
Date: Mon Dec 30 16:14:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Vim/Xterm
Message-ID: <20021231001359.90020.qmail@web9603.mail.yahoo.com>

I recently commented on doing 8-bit text editing
(Cyrillic, in this case) in a Linux environment, and
have it mostly figured out. A couple of issues remain.


The award-winning Vim text editor does not display
such characters when it is started up by clicking on
the icon, but there are other ways. You can bring up a
terminal window, then bring up a second terminal
window in the desired font with the command

xterm -fn "-cronyx-courier-medium-    etc.

In this second terminal window, the command

vim filename

will open filename and display foreign characters
properly. (Printing? I use enscript for that.)

Anyhow, if you do something like this pretty often, it
might be a good idea to bring default settings closer
to the task. I am aware that .vimrc is used to set
user defaults for Vim, and it would be nice to set the
font there. But I'm having trouble finding a good
reference for .vimrc, although there are lots of
examples of other people's .vimrc's available.

Instead of, or in addition, to that, it might be nice
to change the xterm default font "permanently." Am I
on the right track? There is a configuration file of
some kind, /etc/X11/app-defaults/Xterm

This contains a stanza of the following kind:

*fontMenu*font4*Label:  Medium
!*VT100*font4:    7x13
*VT100*font4:     7x13euro

Is this the stuff that needs to be changed? Or is it
somewhere else? You can't do much without a terminal,
so I want to do it right.

=====
Robert "Tim" Kopp
http://analytic.tripod.com/

"SAMBA--opening Windows to a wider world."

In-Reply-To: <20021231001359.90020.qmail@web9603.mail.yahoo.com>; from iconoklastic@yahoo.com on Mon, Dec 30, 2002 at 04:13:59PM -0800
References: <20021231001359.90020.qmail@web9603.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <20021230212014.A4822@zaphod.axian.com>

On Mon, Dec 30, 2002 at 04:13:59PM -0800, Robert Kopp wrote:
...
> Instead of, or in addition, to that, it might be nice
> to change the xterm default font "permanently." Am I
> on the right track? There is a configuration file of
> some kind, /etc/X11/app-defaults/Xterm
> 
> This contains a stanza of the following kind:
> 
> *fontMenu*font4*Label:  Medium
> !*VT100*font4:    7x13
> *VT100*font4:     7x13euro
> 
...

This is one of the multitudinous places in which the X resourses
can be set.  I myself prefer to put them in ~/.Xdefaults.
You'll want a line like:

xterm.font: your-favorite-font
XTerm.Font: your-favorite-font

or even:

*Font: your-favorite-font

This last one is pretty pervasive, though.

Ali

From alan at clueserver.org  Mon Dec 30 21:47:03 2002
From: alan at clueserver.org (Alan)
Date: Mon Dec 30 21:47:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] A good 2D-3D gaming video card for Linux?
In-Reply-To: <200212302119.gBULJd926296@gate.daniloff.com>
References: <200212302119.gBULJd926296@gate.daniloff.com>
Message-ID: <1041307794.2074.8.camel@zontar.clueserver.org>

On Mon, 2002-12-30 at 13:19, Alex Daniloff wrote:
> Hello Linix folkz,
> Could somebody please recommend any good
> 2D-3D video card or a chipset name for 
> Linux with at least 64MB or 128MB RAM. 
> It has to be fully supported, be easy in
> installation and configuration without 
> a fuzz. 

There are three options here.

If you are wanting the fastest 2d performance, the Matrox cards seem to
be the best.

If you are going for blazes fast 3d, you are looking at the top end ATI
or nVIDIA card.

If you want to be able to play Unreal Tourniment 2003, then you will
want the nVIDIA.  (It uses some options in OpenGL that are not supported
by ATI yet.)

If you get nVIDIA, you will want their drivers.  (The ones included in
XFree86 work, but are fairly slow.

> I'm building ultimate Linux 
> machine for game programming and other
> very heavy graphical stuff.

Having a fast video card is only one part of the equasion. If you are
wanting fast compiles, you will want to have very fast drives.
(Ultra-scsi raid or something similar.)  Also dual processors will help.
Lots of memory will also help, but unless you have a hacked kernel or
the proper patches, you will see a slow down at about 800 megs or so.
(At least according to the kernel developers I have spoken to.  I don't
have that much in a single machine.)

Linux Journal has had a couple of good articles on building "ultimate
Linux boxes".

-- 
Alan <alan at clueserver.org>




From karlheg at pdxlinux.org  Mon Dec 30 22:16:03 2002
From: karlheg at pdxlinux.org (Karl M. Hegbloom)
Date: Mon Dec 30 22:16:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Vim/Xterm
In-Reply-To: <20021231001359.90020.qmail@web9603.mail.yahoo.com>
References: <20021231001359.90020.qmail@web9603.mail.yahoo.com>
Message-ID: <1041315334.18345.24.camel@bittersweet.hegbloom.net>

On Mon, 2002-12-30 at 16:13, Robert Kopp wrote:
> xterm -fn "-cronyx-courier-medium- 

The Gnome terminal (and the Gnome multi-terminal) both have the notion
of terminal classes.  You can set up a certain font + color
configuration, and associate that with a terminal class, and from then
on, when the terminal is set to that class, it will use those settings. 
This is not the TERM variable, it's the Gnome terminal's terminal
class.  (which may well be a function of the underlying gvt library... 
I've not checked but suspect that's the case.)

From raanders at acm.org  Tue Dec 31 04:56:03 2002
From: raanders at acm.org (Roderick A. Anderson)
Date: Tue Dec 31 04:56:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] Customer Invoicing and Tracking software

Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.4.33.0212310454530.24213-100000@main.cyber-office.net>

On 30 Dec 2002, Benjamin Prew wrote:

> Hey,
> 
> I was looking for a Customer Invoicing and Tracking software, similar to
> Quickbooks, but for Linux.

Probably over-kill and a little 'interesting' to set up is SQL-Ledger 
(http://www.sql-ledger.org).  Requires several extra Perl packages, 
PostgreSQL (RDBMS), and a web server.

> I would like to be able to print invoices and store customer
> information, such as address, phone, e-mail etc.  

Since it uses a RDBMS reports like this are not too difficult but I think 
the latest version has this already or as an hack-on for now.

> I would also like to be able to print mailing labels for multiple
> customers or at least have some way to display multiple customer's
> information.

Since there are ODBC drivers, and friends, for PostgreSQL you can use your
favorite Office Suite (OpenOffice.org, Staroffice) to do this.  There is 
also a DataVision.

> 
> Package        : dhcpcd
> Vulnerability  : remote command execution
> Problem-Type   : remote
> Debian-specific: no
> BugTraq Id     : 6200
> 
> Simon Kelly discovered a vulnerability in dhcpcd, an RFC2131 and
> RFC1541 compliant DHCP client daemon, that runs with root privileges
> on client machines.  A malicious administrator of the regular or an
> untrusted DHCP server may execute any command with root privileges on
> the DHCP client machine by sending the command enclosed in shell
> metacharacters in one of the options provided by the DHCP server.
> 
> This problem has been fixed in version 1.3.17pl2-8.1 for the old
> stable distribution (potato) and in version 1.3.22pl2-2 for the
> testing (sarge) and unstable (sid) distributions.  The current stable
> distribution (woody) does not contain a dhcpcd package.
> 
> We recommend that you upgrade your dhcpcd package (on the client
> machine).
> 
> wget url
>         will fetch the file for you
> dpkg -i file.deb
>         will install the referenced file.
> 
> If you are using the apt-get package manager, use the line for
> sources.list as given below:
> 
> apt-get update
>         will update the internal database
> apt-get upgrade
>         will install corrected packages
> 
> You may use an automated update by adding the resources from the
> footer to the proper configuration.
> 
> 
> Debian GNU/Linux 2.2 alias potato

>

From cooper at linux-enterprise.net  Tue Dec 31 14:51:28 2002
From: cooper at linux-enterprise.net (Cooper Stevenson)
Date: Tue Dec 31 14:51:28 2002
Subject: [PLUG] New Online Material

	<1041373206.988.1.camel@Balrog.jimwebb.net>
	<1041373575.1446.43.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com> 
	<1041374502.988.8.camel@Balrog.jimwebb.net>
Message-ID: <1041375549.1446.59.camel@sparticus.coopnkass.com>

Jim,

> Warning: locale not supported by C library, locale unchanged"

Others can answer this better than I. After having studied this in the
past, the impression I took away was that it's basically a harmless
warning message that may be safely ignored.

[snip]

> If I use a vurtual console I'd press
> Ctrl-Alt-F*.  Why would I want to use this and how would I get back to
> my xwindows?

To get back to X-Windows, press Ctrl+Alt+F7 simultaneously (the seventh
virtual terminal-by convention-is the first X windows display).

You may wish to do this if you want to kill an X-Windows full screen
application that is not behaving. You may also press Ctrl-C at the first
virtual terminal to safely close X-Windows itself.

So if X gives you trouble, there's generally no need to reboot.

Also, if you administrate several machines and actually _like_ the
terminal displays, you can use it. I, for example, prefer the terminal
over X-Windows' X-terms when I am in heavy admin mode.

Other than that there's really no other reason to use the virtual
terminals, it's just handy to know they're there.

-Cooper

From russell-evans at uswest.net  Tue Dec 31 15:02:03 2002
From: russell-evans at uswest.net (Russell Evans)
Date: Tue Dec 31 15:02:03 2002
Subject: [PLUG] computer parts stores?
Message-ID: <E18TVOJ-0007CC-00@drizzle.pdxlinux.org>

ComputerBits is a kind of local, I think they also distribute in Phoenix Az,
computer magazine. A couple of the PLUG members are or were involved with the
magazine. Its main draw for me is that most local computer vendors post a
monthly price sheet of their wares in it. I buy cheep so although I'm not
always
buying, I'm always looking for a deal. The want ads used to be a draw, but with
the down turn in the local economy, it seems most ads are put in by people
looking for work. It also seems people aren't upgrading, or maybe they're using
Ebay,  as much, so the used computer hardware ads don't seem to be as thick
with deals and exotic hardware ( MACs, that strange pretty plastic, fascinates
me). 

Most of the vendors in the last reply, advertise in ComputerBits. ComputerBits
has links and addresses to the vendors it advertises on its site. This makes it
easy to see who's where and the current prices they are charging.  On the
vendor web pages you'll usually find a price sheet that was advertised in
ComputerBits with price adjustments for fluctuations that don't follow a
monthly cycle. Memory and some
hard drives prices, seem to fluctuate daily. The vendor's web page don't
usually track these, so you never know until you hit the store what the day
will bring when buying memory. 

http://www.computerbits.com/ads/advertiser_listing.htm

Thank you
Russell

I'm having a problem with PINE/PICO at work that I'm not having on this

I liked this account's .cshrc parameters, so I simply copied them over to
my work servers' home accounts (which are numerous, but only one is the

on all of my work accounts (or at least the ones that support PICO).  The
difference between the cs.pdx.edu box and mail.saw.net is the OS: the
former uses SunOS 2.8 (solaris 8, whatever) and has no backspace key
issues; the latter uses FreeBSD and seems to choke on the backspace
key.  I tried mounting some tcsh IF statement:
if ($?prompt) then
        # An interactive shell -- set some stuff up
        set filec
        set history = 100
        set savehist = 100
        set mail = (/var/mail/$USER)
        if ( $?tcsh ) then
                bindkey "^W" backward-delete-word
                bindkey -k up history-search-backward
                bindkey -k down history-search-forward
        endif

...but that didn't even help.  So, of course, I've asked some other people
around, and, most people, I've learned, are not experts in low-level shit
like this.

Could anyone help me (without giving me guff about using the C
Shell: It's what I have learned on and I like it thankyouverymuch)?  God
knows I don't want to switch to elm and bash...

Thanks for your insights...

Try putting a stty command in the .cshrc file:

stty erase    #Literal Backspace key, not ^H

> Shell: It's what I have learned on and I like it thankyouverymuch)?  God

  Well, you could switch to bash and keep the pine. :-)

  The disclaimer: I know nothing about csh except that it's a subset of
bash. I know nothing about Solaris and FreeBSD. Anyone who uses pico as the
editor in pine deserves it. ;-)

  Now that the legal stuff is covered, see if either OS has the equivalent
of 'keymaps' (man keymaps). I use this in linux to remap the ctrl and caps
lock keys on the console (it feeds loadkeys). In X, use xmodmap.

HTH,

Rich
